PREFACE
         This code of the City of Jerome, as supplemented, contains ordinances
up to and including ordinance 1239, passed March 18, 2025. Ordinances of the
City adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the
extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City
office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has
been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
 
ORDINANCE NO. 1240
BILL NO. 725
AN ORDINANCE OF THE MAYOR AND COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF JEROME REVISING TITLE 8
AND TITLE 10 OF THE JEROME MUNICIPAL CODE; SPECIFICALLY, CHAPTER 8.08.010
CORRECTING FORMATTING; CHAPTER 8.08.030 AND 8.08.040 CLARIFYING FEES AND THE
NON-PAYMENT PROCEDURE; CHAPTER 10.04.060 UPDATING THE PAYMENT PROCESS;
10.20.040 CLARIFYING THE FEES AND PAYMENT LOCATION; AND PROVIDING FOR AN
EFFECTIVE DATE.
WHEREAS, Title 8 Chapter 08.08.010 needs re-formatting to prevent confusion on
the Definitions of the Chapter; and
WHEREAS, Title 8 Chapter 08.08.030 and 08.08.040 need to be amended to include
court fees and clarify the process the City of Jerome can take for non-payment
of an abatement; and
WHEREAS, Title 10 Chapter 10.04.060 needs to be amended to include court fees,
payment location, and update the process for appeal to the courts; and
WHEREAS, Title 10 Chapter 10.20.040 needs to be amended to include court fees
and the payment location.
IT IS THEREFORE ORDAINED by the Mayor and the City Council of Jerome, Idaho, as
follows:
SECTION 1. Jerome Municipal Code 08.08.010, 08.08.030, and 08.08.040 shall be
amended as follows:
8.08.010: DEFINITIONS:
   GRAFFITI: Any inscription, work, figure, symbol, drawing, mark, or design
that is marked, etched, scratched, drawn, or painted on any real or personal
property or improvement, including, but not limited to, walls, fences, gates,
pavement, buildings, rocks, trees, bridges, streets, sidewalks, and/or signs,
whether such property is public, private, temporary, or permanent, without the
consent of the owners of such property or the owner's authorized agent, and
which inscription, work, figure, symbol, drawing, mark, or design is visible
from any publicly accessible location.
   JUNK VEHICLE: Any vehicle, or parts thereof, which:
   A.   Cannot be safely operated under its own power;
   B.   Is parked in public right-of-way and is not registered or licensed;
   C.   Is missing any one of the following: foot brakes, hand brakes,
headlights, taillights, horn, muffler, rearview mirrors, windshield wipers or
adequate fenders;
   D.   Has been declared salvage, or has been physically damaged to the extent
that the costs of parts and labor minus the salvage value would make it
uneconomical to repair or rebuild such vehicle; or
   E.   Is otherwise in a wrecked, partially dismantled, inoperative, or
dilapidated condition.
This definition shall not include junk vehicles lawfully stored or parked and
screened from view from a public right-of-way pursuant to the operation of a
lawfully conducted business, industry or commercial enterprise.
 NUISANCE: Anything which unreasonably injures or offends the health or senses;
obstructs the free passage, comfortable enjoyment, or customary use of public
or private property; or creates an actual or potential safety, health, or fire
hazard. Nuisances shall include, but shall not be limited to, the following
conditions designated as abatable nuisances and as general nuisances.
ABATABLE NUISANCE: Nuisance conditions that may be abated by the City in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter, specifically including, without
limitation, the following nuisance conditions:
   A.   Nuisance weeds.
   B.   Graffiti, on any surface.
   C.   Snow or ice on any public sidewalk abutting or adjoining any privately
owned premises.
   D.   Vegetation, other than trees, that impedes or obstructs a public
sidewalk or roadway.
GENERAL NUISANCE: Nuisance conditions that may lead to criminal charges without
any prior attempt by the City to obtain abatement thereof, specifically
including, without limitation, the following nuisance conditions:
      A.   Bulky Waste: Stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines,
furniture, appliances, and other waste materials other than construction
debris, dead animals, hazardous materials, or stable matter with weights or
volumes greater than those allowed for containers.
      B.   Construction Debris: Waste building materials resulting from
construction, remodeling, repair, or demolition operations.
      C.   Dead Animal: Any animal, or portions thereof that has expired from
any cause.
      D.   Garbage: Every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or
matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in,
handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay, or decomposition of
meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter
(including, but not by any way of limitation, used tin cans, milk cartons, and
other food containers; and all putrescible or easily decomposable waste animal
or vegetable matter which is likely to attract flies or rodents); except in all
cases any matter included in the definitions of "bulky waste", "construction
debris", "dead animal", "hazardous materials", "rubbish", or "stable matter".
      E.   Hazardous Materials: Any chemical, compound, mixture, substance, or
article designated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or
other governing authority of the State or Federal government to be hazardous as
that term is defined by or pursuant to Federal or State law. Except, however,
that this definition shall not include the incidental leakage of nuisance
materials from registered vehicles lawfully moving or lawfully parked upon a
public right-of-way; the lawful application of pesticides or herbicides for
purposes of controlling pests or weeds; or activity otherwise specifically
allowed by law or by written permit issued by the City or other governing
authority.
      F.   Rubbish: Waste wood, wood products, tree trimmings, grass cuttings,
dead plants, weeds, leaves, dead trees or branches thereof, chips, shavings,
sawdust, printed matter, paper, cardboard, rags, straw, used and discarded
mattresses, used and discarded clothing, combustible waste pulp and other
products such as are used for packing, or wrapping crockery and glass, ashes,
cinders, floor sweepings, grass, mineral and metallic substances and any and
all other waste materials not included in the definitions of "bulky waste",
"construction debris", "dead animal" , "garbage", "hazardous materials" or
"stable matter".
      G.   Stable Matter: All manure and other waste matter normally
accumulated in or about a stable or any animal, livestock, or poultry enclosure
and resulting from the keeping of animals, poultry, or livestock.
      H.   Waste Matter: Used or discarded matter having no substantial market
value, which is exposed to the elements and is not enclosed in any structure or
otherwise concealed from public view, and which consists (without limitation or
exclusion by enumeration) of such matter and material as:
         1.   Rubble, asphalt, concrete, plaster, tile;
         2.   Rubbish, crates, cartons, metal and glass containers; and
         3.   Vehicle bodies and parts.
   NUISANCE MATERIALS: Hazardous, noxious, dangerous, or offensive materials,
including, but not limited to, oil, gasolines, fuel, antifreeze, paint,
pesticides, or herbicides.
   NUISANCE WEEDS: Undesirable plant growth, whether living or dead, which:
   A.   Is over eight inches (8") in height;
   B.   By reason of size, manner of growth, location, or dryness, constitutes
a safety, health, or fire hazard to any person, building, improvement, crop, or
other real or personal property;
   C.   By reason of size, manner of growth, or location, impedes or obstructs
a sidewalk or roadway or any portion thereof; or
   D.   Is designated as a noxious weed by the State of Idaho.
This definition shall not include cultivated grasses and pastures, though such
vegetation may be declared a nuisance where otherwise appropriate. (Ord. 1176,
2019)
8.08.030: ABATABLE NUISANCES; PROCEDURES AND PENALTIES:
A.   Applicability: The procedures set forth in this section shall apply to
abatable nuisances.
B.   Abatable Nuisance Unlawful: It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant,
user, or person in charge or control of any property to create, cause, commit,
maintain, or allow the existence of any abatable nuisance on such property, or
upon any street, sidewalk or public right-of-way abutting such property
including the area behind curbs, sidewalks, parking areas, and property to the
center of alleys and ditches. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to
create, cause, allow, or commit any nuisance upon any public property, right-
of-way, or infrastructure, including sidewalks, streets, gutters, or storm
drains.
C.   Procedure: If it is determined by a Code Enforcement Officer that an
abatable nuisance exists, the Code Enforcement Officer shall cause a notice of
violation and order to abate to be issued to the owner, occupier, and/or person
in control of such property. Such notice and order shall contain the street
address and parcel number of the property, describe the nuisance existing
thereon, order the abatement of the nuisance, establish the time period for
abatement, specify the penalty for noncompliance, and describe the opportunity
and time for appeal. The Code Enforcement Officer shall issue such notice and
order to the owner, occupier, or person in control of the property on which the
nuisance exists in one of the following ways:
   1.   By personal service upon such owner, occupier, or person in charge or
control of the property; or
   2.   By regular mail to such owner, occupier, or person in charge or control
of the property, at the address shown on the last available assessment roll, or
as otherwise known; or
   3.   By posting such notice and order at a conspicuous place on the property
and publishing one notice in the official newspaper of the City that the
property has been posted in accordance with this chapter and ordering the
owner, occupier, or person in charge or control of the property.
D.   Time Period For Abatement: It shall be the duty of the owner, occupier, or
person in charge or control of any property where any abatable nuisance exists,
to abate such nuisance within five (5) calendar days from the date of personal
service, mailing, or publication, except that the Code Enforcement Officer may
require summary abatement of an abatable nuisance where such condition presents
an imminent or ongoing threat to or impairment of human health or safety.
Abatement of graffiti shall meet the following standards:
   1.   The removal of such graffiti shall not follow the pattern of the
graffiti such that the inscription, work, figure, symbol, drawing, mark, or
design of such graffiti remains apparent.
   2.   The removal of such graffiti by painting over it shall be reasonably
similar or identical to the original color of the surface upon which such
graffiti is applied.
   3.   If the surface is heavily covered with graffiti, the entire surface
shall be repainted.
E.   Appeal: Within five (5) calendar days from the date of service, mailing,
or publication of the notice of violation and order to abate, the owner,
occupier, and/or person in charge or control of the subject property may appeal
to the City Council by filing a written appeal with the City Clerk, which
appeal shall enumerate the grounds for appeal. The City Clerk may schedule such
appeal for hearing at the next regular meeting of the City Council. The City
Council shall consider written and oral testimony from the appellant and shall
affirm, withdraw, or modify the order to abate. The decision of the City
Council shall be final. If the City Council affirms the order, the appellant
shall have five (5) calendar days from the date of such affirmation to abate
the nuisance as ordered.
F.   Criminal Penalties: If, following notice of violation and order to abate,
any person allows the existence of an abatable nuisance, such person shall be
guilty of an infraction, which shall be punishable by a fine of two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) plus court costs. A second violation within a calendar
year of the first violation shall be punishable by a fine of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) plus court costs. A third and any subsequent violation within
a calendar year of the first violation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and
subject to a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or six (6) months'
imprisonment in the County Jail, and/or by both such fine and imprisonment.
Each and every day in which any such violation continues may be deemed a
separate and subsequent violation. Upon conviction for a violation of this
section, the City shall request from the Criminal Court an order of restitution
for any and all costs of abatement and/or other related costs incurred by the
City. Peace officers and Code Enforcement Officers shall have the authority to
issue Idaho uniform citations to violators of this section.
G.   Civil Penalties: In addition to any other penalties described in this
section, the City may also take civil action to obtain an order enjoining the
ongoing maintenance of such property free from nuisance, and/or to recover any
and all costs of abatement, enforcement, litigation, and/or prosecution
including, but not limited to, attorney fees and court costs.
H.   Abatement; Administrative Penalties: In addition to pursuing criminal and/
or civil penalties, and notwithstanding the imposition of any civil or criminal
fine, penalty or imprisonment, the Code Enforcement Officer, after providing
notice and hearing as provided herein, may abate or cause the abatement of any
abatable nuisance; where the owner, occupant, agent or person in control of
property does not comply in all respects with an order to abate, the Code
Enforcement Officer may abate or cause the abatement of such nuisance. The
owner, occupier, and/or person in charge or control of the subject property
shall be billed, assessed, and/or held responsible for any and all actual
expenses of such work, and any related charges, including fees and fines that
may be imposed pursuant to this chapter and/or adopted by fee schedule,
pursuant to the following procedures:
   1.   Recovery Of Abatement Costs And Fees: Within thirty (30) days of
abatement of the nuisance, the City shall send the owner, occupier, and/or
person in charge or control of the subject property, by regular mail, a billing
statement requiring payment to City the costs of abating the nuisance and
administrative fee as established by fee schedule.
   2.   Nonpayment Of Abatement Costs: If full payment is not made to the City
within fifteen (15) days of the mailing of the billing statement requiring
payment of abatement costs and fees, the City may:
       a. .   Levy a special assessment against the subject property pursuant
to Idaho Code sections 50-1008 and 50-334 and/or any subsequently adopted or
otherwise applicable laws. Notice of the special assessment shall be sent by
regular mail to the owner of the subject property, and shall state the address
and parcel number of the subject property, date of abatement action taken, and
state the amount to be assessed, including any applicable administrative and/or
late fees, and shall state that if the assessment is not paid within thirty
(30) days, the assessment will be placed on the Real Property Tax rolls and
will become a lien against such property. If payment to the City Clerk is not
made within thirty (30) days after mailing the notice of special assessment,
the assessment shall be declared delinquent and shall be certified, including a
ten percent (10%) late fee, to the Jerome County Assessor by the City Clerk,
not later than August 1 of each year. Upon such certification, the assessment
shall be placed upon the tax roll and shall thereafter become a lien against
the property described in the notice and shall be collected in the same manner
and subject to the same penalties as other City taxes. Upon payment of the
assessment, fees and penalties in full, the City Clerk shall file a release of
lien with the Jerome County Assessor.
I.   Summary Abatement: Nothing contained herein shall prevent a Code
Enforcement Officer, Peace Officer, or Fire Marshal from requiring,
undertaking, or causing summary abatement of an abatable nuisance where such
condition presents an imminent or ongoing threat to or impairment of human
health or safety.
J.   Noxious Weeds: In addition to other remedies set forth in this chapter,
the Code Enforcement Officer may notify Jerome County of the presence of
noxious weeds.
8.08.040: GENERAL NUISANCES; PROCEDURES AND PENALTIES:
A.   Applicability: The procedures set forth in this section shall apply to
general nuisances.
B.   General Nuisance Unlawful: It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant,
user, or person in charge or control of any property to create, cause, commit,
maintain, or allow the existence of any general nuisance on such property, or
upon any street, sidewalk or public right-of-way abutting such property
including the area behind curbs, sidewalks, parking areas, and property to the
center of alleys and ditches. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to
create, cause, allow, or commit any nuisance upon any public property, right-
of-way, or infrastructure, including sidewalks, streets, gutters, or storm
drains.
C.   Criminal Penalties: If, following notice of violation and order to abate,
any person allows the existence of an abatable nuisance, such person shall be
guilty of an infraction, which shall be punishable by a fine of two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) plus court costs. A second violation within a calendar
year of the first violation shall be punishable by a fine of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) plus court costs. A third and any subsequent violation within
a calendar year of the first violation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and
subject to a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or six (6) months'
imprisonment in the County Jail, and/or by both such fine and imprisonment.
Each and every day in which any such violation continues may be deemed a
separate and subsequent violation. Upon conviction for a violation of this
section, the City shall request from the Criminal Court an order of restitution
for any and all costs of abatement and/or other related costs incurred by the
City. Peace officers and Code Enforcement Officers shall have the authority to
issue Idaho uniform citations to violators of this section.
D.   Civil Penalties: In addition to any other penalties described in this
section, the City may also take civil action to obtain an order mandating the
abatement of such general nuisance and ongoing maintenance of such property
free from nuisance, and/or to recover any and all costs of enforcement,
litigation, and/or prosecution including, but not limited to, attorney fees and
court costs.
    1.   Recovery Of Abatement Costs And Fees: Within thirty (30) days of
abatement of the nuisance, the City shall send the owner, occupier, and/or
person in charge or control of the subject property, by regular mail, a billing
statement requiring payment to City the costs of abating the nuisance and
administrative fee as established by fee schedule.
    2.   Nonpayment Of Abatement Costs: If full payment is not made to the City
within fifteen (15) days of the mailing of the billing statement requiring
payment of abatement costs and fees, the City may:
       a.   Levy a special assessment against the subject property pursuant to
Idaho Code sections 50-1008 and 50-334 and/or any subsequently adopted or
otherwise applicable laws. Notice of the special assessment shall be sent by
regular mail to the owner of the subject property, and shall state the address
and parcel number of the subject property, date of abatement action taken, and
state the amount to be assessed, including any applicable administrative and/or
late fees, and shall state that if the assessment is not paid within thirty
(30) days, the assessment will be placed on the Real Property Tax rolls and
will become a lien against such property. If payment to the City Clerk is not
made within thirty (30) days after mailing the notice of special assessment,
the assessment shall be declared delinquent and shall be certified, including a
ten percent (10%) late fee, to the Jerome County Assessor by the City Clerk,
not later than August 1 of each year. Upon such certification, the assessment
shall be placed upon the tax roll and shall thereafter become a lien against
the property described in the notice and shall be collected in the same manner
and subject to the same penalties as other City taxes. Upon payment of the
assessment, fees and penalties in full, the City Clerk shall file a release of
lien with the Jerome County Assessor.
E.   Summary Abatement: Nothing contained herein shall prevent a Code
Enforcement Officer, Peace Officer, or Fire Marshal from requiring,
undertaking, or causing summary abatement of a general nuisance where such
condition presents an imminent or ongoing threat to or impairment of human
health or safety.
SECTION 2. Jerome Municipal Code 10.04.060 and 10.20.040 shall be amended as
follows:
10.04.060: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A.   Penalty Payment: A single violation of this chapter shall be punishable by
an infraction in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) plus court fees. A
person who has received a notice of violation under this chapter signed by a
law enforcement officer may pay the civil penalty within fifteen (15) calendar
days of its receipt at the Thomas H Borresen Judicial Complex or by mailing the
final amount to the Judicial Complex, as directed on the notice of violation. .
Alternatively, the person receiving the notice of violation may appeal the
violation by appearing before the court.
10.20.040: VIOLATION:
A. Penalty Payment: Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this
chapter shall be deemed guilty of an infraction and shall pay a fine of one
hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court fees. Any person found guilty of a
subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month period shall be subject to a
fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus court fees. Any person found guilty
of a third violation in any twelve (12) month period shall be subject to a fine
of three hundred dollars ($300.00) plus court fees. Any violations of this code
by a business shall be found guilty and pay the fines as stated above
regardless of the registered truck owner.
B. A person who has received a notice of violation under this chapter signed by
a law enforcement officer may pay the infraction within fifteen (15) calendar
days of its receipt at the Thomas H Borresen Judicial Complex or by mailing the
final amount to the Judicial Complex, as directed on the notice of violation.
Alternatively, the person receiving the notice of violation may appeal the
violation by appearing before the court.
PASSED BY THE COUNCIL this 15 th day of April 2025.
SIGNED BY THE MAYOR this 15 th day of April 2025.
CITY OF JEROME, IDAHO

ORDINANCE NO. 1242
BILL NO. 727
 
 
AN ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF JEROME, IDAHO AMENDING ORDINANCE NO. 1229 THE
APPROPRIATION ORDINANCE FOR THE FISCAL YEAR BEGINNING OCTOBER 1, 2024 AND
ENDING SEPTEMBER 30, 2025: APPROPRIATING ADDITIONAL MONEYS FROM EXISTING
RESERVES BY THE CITY OF JEROME, IDAHO, IN THE SUM OF $100,000 AND PROVIDING AN
EFFECTIVE DATE.
 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE MAYOR AND COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF JEROME, IDAHO:
 
   SECTION 1. That Ordinance No. 1229, the appropriation ordinance for the City
of Jerome, Idaho, for the fiscal year commencing October 1, 2024 and ending
September 30, 2025, be and the same is hereby amended as follows:
 
   That the additional sum of $100,000 be appropriated out of the existing
reserves in the Irrigation Fund to be used for authorized activities.
 
 
SECTION 2. This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its
passage, approval and publication.
 
PASSED by the City Council and approved by the Mayor of the City of Jerome,
Idaho this 19th day of August, 2025.

Notes
1 1. IC §50-903 et seq.
1.01.010: ADOPTION:
Pursuant to the provisions of Idaho Code sections 50-903 to 50-906, there is
hereby adopted the "Jerome Municipal Code", as published by Book Publishing
Company, Seattle, Washington. (Ord. 646 §1, 1981)
1.01.020: TITLE; CITATION; REFERENCE:
This code shall be known as the JEROME MUNICIPAL CODE, and it shall be
sufficient to refer to said code as the "Jerome municipal code" in any
prosecution for the violation of any provision thereof, or in any proceeding at
law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to,
amending, correcting, or repealing all or any part or portion thereof as an
addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the "Jerome municipal code".
Further reference may be had to the titles, chapters, sections, and subsections
of the "Jerome municipal code" and such reference shall apply to that numbered
title, chapter, section or subsection as it appears in the code. (Ord. 646 §2,
1981)
1.01.030: CODIFICATION AUTHORITY:
This code consists of all the regulatory and penal ordinances and certain of
the administrative ordinances of the city of Jerome, Idaho, codified pursuant
to the provisions of sections 50-903 to 50-906 of the Idaho Code Annotated.
(Ord. 646 §3, 1981)
1.01.040: ORDINANCES PASSED PRIOR TO ADOPTION OF THE CODE:
The last ordinance included in this code was ordinance 628, passed February 19,
1980. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to ordinance 628, but prior
to adoption of this code, are hereby adopted and made a part of this code:
ordinances 629, 630, 631, 632, 633, 634, 635, 636, 637, 638, 639, 640, 641,
642, 643, and 644. (Ord. 646 §4, 1981)
1.01.050: REFERENCE APPLIES TO ALL AMENDMENTS:
Whenever a reference is made to this code as the "Jerome municipal code", or to
any portion thereof, or to any ordinances of the city of Jerome, Idaho, the
reference shall apply to all amendments, corrections and additions heretofore,
now, or hereafter made. (Ord. 646 §5, 1981)
1.01.060: TITLE, CHAPTER AND SECTION HEADINGS:
Title, chapter and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to
govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of
the provisions of any title, chapter, or section hereof. (Ord. 646 §6, 1981)
1.01.070: REFERENCE TO SPECIFIC ORDINANCES:
The provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect matters or record
which refer to, or are otherwise connected with ordinances which are therein
specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are included within
the code, but such reference shall be construed to apply to the corresponding
provisions contained within this code. (Ord. 646 §7, 1981)
1.01.080: REPEAL OF EXISTING ORDINANCES:
So far as the provisions of this code are the same in effect as those of
previously existing ordinances, they shall be construed as continuations
thereof; but subject to the above limitations and the provisions of the next
section, all ordinances, and resolutions of the city of Jerome, Idaho,
heretofore in force (except such as are of a private, local, or temporary
nature, including franchises, grants, dedications, and special levies for local
assessments), are hereby repealed. Notwithstanding the foregoing, chapter 28 of
the previous Jerome city code, entitled "Zoning", and appendix B of said code
entitled "Subdivision Of Land", and all ordinances amending or supplementing
them are retained, and are not repealed. (Ord. 646 §8, 1981)
1.01.090: EFFECT OF CODE ON PAST ACTIONS AND OBLIGATIONS:
Neither the adoption of this code nor the repeal or amendments hereby or any
ordinance or part or portion of any ordinance of the city shall in any manner
affect the prosecution for violations of ordinances, which violations were
committed prior to the effective date hereof, nor be construed as a waiver of
any license, fee, or penalty at said effective date due and unpaid under such
ordinances, nor be construed as affecting any of the provisions of such
ordinances relating to the collection of any such license, fee, or penalty, or
the penal provisions applicable to any violation thereof, nor to affect the
validity of any bond or cash deposit in lieu required to be posted, filed, or
deposited pursuant to any ordinance and all rights and obligations thereunder
appertaining shall continue in full force and effect. (Ord. 646 §9, 1981)
1.01.100: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This code shall become effective on the date the ordinance adopting this code
as the "Jerome municipal code" shall become effective. (Ord. 646 §10, 1981)
1.01.110: CONSTITUTIONALITY:
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is for any
reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect
the validity of the remaining portions of this code. The council hereby
declares that it would have passed this code, and each section, subsection,
sentence, clause, and phrase thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or
more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases had been declared
invalid or unconstitutional, and if for any reason this code should be declared
invalid or unconstitutional, then the original ordinance or ordinances shall be
in full force and effect. (Ord. 646 §11, 1981)
CHAPTER 1.04
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1.04.010: Short Title
1.04.020: Definitions
1.04.030: Title Of Office
1.04.040: Joint Authority
1.04.050: Grammatical Interpretation
1.04.060: Computation Of Time
1.04.070: Provisions Considered As Continuations Of Existing Ordinances
1.04.080: Repeal Shall Not Revive Any Ordinances
1.04.090: Catchlines Of Sections
1.04.010: SHORT TITLE:
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute
and be designated the CODE OF THE CITY OF JEROME, IDAHO, 1981 and may be so
cited. This code may also be cited as the "Jerome city code 1981". (Prior code
§1-1)
1.04.020: DEFINITIONS:
In the construction of this code and of all ordinances of the city, the
following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be
inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council or the context
clearly requires otherwise:
   CITY: Shall be construed as if followed by the words "of Jerome".
   CODE: The code of the city of Jerome, Idaho, 1981.
   COUNCIL: The city council of Jerome.
   COUNTY: The county of Jerome.
   DAY: The period of time between any twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and the
twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight following.
   DAYTIME: The period of time between sunrise and sunset.
   HOLIDAYS: Every day declared to be a holiday by section 73-108, Idaho Code,
as amended, and as from time to time hereafter amended by appropriate act of
the state legislature.
   IN THE CITY: Means and includes all territory over which the city now has or
shall hereafter acquire jurisdiction for the exercise of its police powers or
other regulatory powers.
   MAY: Is permissive.
   MONTH: A calendar month, unless otherwise expressed.
   NIGHTTIME: The period of time between sunset and sunrise.
   OATH: Includes an affirmation.
   OFFICIAL TIME: Mountain Standard Time or Daylight Saving Time, as may be in
current use in the city.
   OR; AND: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or", if the sense
requires it.
   OWNER: When applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the
entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land.
   PERSON: Includes any person, firm, association, organization, partnership,
business trust, corporation or company.
   PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and
evidences of debt.
   PRECEDING AND FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
   PROCESS: Includes a writ or summons issued in the course of judicial
proceedings of either a civil or criminal nature.
   PROPERTY: Includes real and personal property.
   REAL PROPERTY: Is coextensive with lands, tenements, hereditaments,
possessory rights and claims.
   SHALL: Is mandatory.
   SIGNATURE OR SUBSCRIPTION BY MARK: Includes a mark when the signer or
subscriber cannot write, such signer's or subscriber's name being written near
the mark by a witness who writes his own name near the signer's or subscriber's
name.
   STATE OR THIS STATE: The state of Idaho.
   TENANT OR OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land, shall include any person
holding a written or an oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of
such building or land, either alone or with others.
   WEEK: Consists of seven (7) consecutive days.
   WRITING: Includes any form of recorded message capable of comprehension by
ordinary visual means. Whenever any notice, report, statement or record is
required or authorized by this code, it shall be made in writing in the English
language, unless it is expressly provided otherwise.
   YEAR: A calendar year, except where otherwise provided. (Prior code §§1-2,
1-2.1)
1.04.030: TITLE OF OFFICE:
Officers, departments, boards, commissions and employees referred to in this
code shall mean officers, departments, boards, commissions and employees of the
city, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. (Prior code §1-2)
1.04.040: JOINT AUTHORITY:
All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers
shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or
officers, unless otherwise specifically stated. (Prior code §1-2)
1.04.050: GRAMMATICAL INTERPRETATION:
The following grammatical rules shall apply in the provisions of this code
unless it is apparent from the context that a different construction is
intended:
A.   Gender: The masculine gender includes the feminine and the neuter.
B.   Tenses: The present tense includes the past and future tenses, and the
future includes the present.
C.   Number: The singular number includes the plural, and the plural, the
singular. (Prior code §1-2)
1.04.060: COMPUTATION OF TIME:
The time in which any act provided by law is to be done is computed by
excluding the first day and including the last, unless the last day is a
holiday and then it is also excluded. (Prior code §1-2)
1.04.070: PROVISIONS CONSIDERED AS CONTINUATIONS OF EXISTING ORDINANCES:
The provisions appearing in this code, so far as they are the same as those of
ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this code, shall be
considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. (Prior code §1-
3)
1.04.080: REPEAL SHALL NOT REVIVE ANY ORDINANCES:
A.   The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before
or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect.
B.   The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty
incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding
pending at the time of the repeal, for any offense committed under the
ordinance repealed. (Prior code §1-4)
1.04.090: CATCHLINES OF SECTIONS:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code underlined are intended as
mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed
or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor,
unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such
sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (Prior code §1-5)
CHAPTER 1.08
GENERAL PENALTY 1
SECTION:
1.08.010: Violation; Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. IC §50-302.
   
1.08.010: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Whenever in this code or any other ordinance of the city, any act is prohibited
or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or the doing of any act is
required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a
misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of
any such provision of this code or any other ordinance of the city shall be
punishable by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) or
imprisonment for a term not to exceed six (6) months, or by both such fine and
imprisonment. (Ord. 627(A), 1980: prior code §1-7)

1.12.010: DESCRIBED:
The corporate seal of the city shall be circular in form with inner and outer
circles. The outer circle shall be one and five-eighths inches (15/8") in
diameter, and the inner circle one inch (1") in diameter. It shall bear upon
the space between the two (2) circles, the words "CITY OF JEROME, IDAHO", and
upon the space within the inner circle the word "SEAL". (Prior code §1-8)
1.12.020: ADOPTED:
The seal described in section
1.12.010 of this chapter is adopted as the seal of the city. (Prior code §1-9)
CHAPTER 1.16
ORDINANCES 1
SECTION:
1.16.010: Written Presentation To Council
1.16.020: Manner Of Passing
1.16.030: Mayoral Endorsement As To Passage
1.16.040: Mayoral Veto; Manner Of Overriding
1.16.050: Certificate Of Passage Over Veto
1.16.060: Passage Without Mayor's Signature
1.16.070: Certificate Of Passage Upon Mayor's Failure To Sign Or Veto
1.16.080: When Ordinance Deemed Passed
1.16.090: Effective Date
1.16.100: Recordation And Preservation
 
Notes
1 1. IC ch. 50-9.
   
1.16.010: WRITTEN PRESENTATION TO COUNCIL:
All ordinances shall be written or printed and presented to the city council by
a member at a regular or special meeting. (Prior code §2-20)
1.16.020: MANNER OF PASSING:
A.   Every city ordinance shall be read on three (3) different days, two (2)
readings of which may be by title only and one reading of which shall be in
full.
B.   At each reading of an ordinance it shall be open to discussion and
amendment and may be referred to a committee and shall be passed to the next
reading, unless by a vote of the council some other disposition is made of it.
C.   On final passage the yeas and nays shall be called and recorded and a
concurrence of a majority of all the members elected to the council shall be
required for its passage; provided, however, that one-half (1/2) plus one of
the members of the full council may dispense with the three (3) readings and
pass the ordinance at any meeting. (Ord. 627(B), 1980: prior code §2-21)
1.16.030: MAYORAL ENDORSEMENT AS TO PASSAGE:
When any city ordinance is passed it shall be signed by the clerk, and the date
of its passage, by the council, shall be added thereto, and within three (3)
days thereafter it shall be presented to the mayor, or in case of his absence
from the city, to the president of the council for his consideration. If he
approves the same he shall attach his signature thereto, together with the date
of such approval. (Prior code §2-22)
1.16.040: MAYORAL VETO; MANNER OF OVERRIDING:
Should the mayor not approve an ordinance, he shall return the same to the
council with his objections to the same in writing on or before the date of the
next regular meeting after the same was presented to him. When an ordinance is
so returned by the mayor, the council shall proceed to reconsider the same. If,
on such reconsideration, one-half (1/2) plus one of the council elected vote in
the affirmative, the ordinance shall become law notwithstanding the mayor's
veto. (Ord. 627(C), 1980: prior code §2-23)
1.16.050: CERTIFICATE OF PASSAGE OVER VETO:
When an ordinance has been passed over the mayor's veto, as provided in section
1.16.040 of this chapter, the city clerk shall annex a certificate to the
ordinance stating that the same was vetoed by the mayor, giving the date of
such veto, and that on its reconsideration by the council it received the
required one-half (1/2) plus one vote of the members elected to the council,
together with the date of such action. (Ord. 627(D), 1980: prior code §2-24)
1.16.060: PASSAGE WITHOUT MAYOR'S SIGNATURE:
Should the mayor refuse or neglect to sign any city ordinance and return the
same with his objections in writing, on or before the date of the next regular
meeting after the same was submitted to him, it shall become a law without his
signature. (Prior code §2-25)
1.16.070: CERTIFICATE OF PASSAGE UPON MAYOR'S FAILURE TO SIGN OR VETO:
When any ordinance has become a law without the signature of the mayor, as
provided in section
1.16.050 of this chapter, the city clerk shall annex to such ordinance a
certificate to the effect that the mayor has failed to sign or veto the same,
and it has therefore become a law without his signature. (Prior code §2-26)
1.16.080: WHEN ORDINANCE DEEMED PASSED:
An ordinance of the city shall be considered passed on the date of its approval
by the mayor, and in case of his vetoing an ordinance, on the date of the
passage of such ordinance over his veto, and in the case of the failure of the
mayor to sign or veto an ordinance, on the date of the next regular meeting
after such ordinance was presented to him. (Prior code §2-27)
1.16.090: EFFECTIVE DATE:
All city ordinances, unless otherwise provided in such ordinance, shall take
effect and be in force from and after their passage, approval and publication.
Publication shall be made by being inserted in one issue of some newspaper
published in the city. If no paper be published within the city, then in some
paper having general circulation in the city. (Prior code §2-28)
1.16.100: RECORDATION AND PRESERVATION:
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to safely preserve the original
ordinances of the city and when passed and approved to record the same in a
book provided for that purpose, such book to be designated as, "ORDINANCE BOOK
NO           , CITY OF JEROME". The city clerk shall attach a certificate to
each ordinance, so recorded, to the effect that the same is a true and correct
copy of the original ordinance as passed. (Prior code §2-29)
CHAPTER 1.17
CONSENT CALENDAR
SECTION:
1.17.010: Content Of Consent Calendar
1.17.020: Introduction Of Consent Calendar
1.17.030: Limitation Of Debate
1.17.040: Objection And Removal From Consent Calendar
1.17.050: Approval Of Motion
1.17.060: Minutes
1.17.010: CONTENT OF CONSENT CALENDAR:
The following items are declared to be part of the consent calendar: claims,
minutes of prior meetings, reading of building permits, requests for vacation
by any city officer or employee, reports of officers. In addition, the mayor
may place any other item on the consent calendar from time to time when the
mayor determines that any such item of business requires action by the city
council but is of a routine and noncontroversial nature. (Ord. 647, 1982)
1.17.020: INTRODUCTION OF CONSENT CALENDAR:
The consent calendar shall be introduced by a motion to approve the consent
calendar, and shall be considered by the council as a single item. (Ord. 647,
1982)
1.17.030: LIMITATION OF DEBATE:
There shall be no debate or discussion by any member of the council regarding
any item on the consent calendar beyond asking a question for simple
clarification. (Ord. 647, 1982)
1.17.040: OBJECTION AND REMOVAL FROM CONSENT CALENDAR:
A.   On objection by any member of the city council to inclusion of any item on
the consent calendar, that item shall be removed from the consent calendar
forthwith. Such an objection may be recorded at any time prior to the taking of
a vote on the motion to approve the consent calendar.
B.   All such items shall be considered individually in the order in which they
were objected to, immediately following consideration of the motion to approve
the consent calendar. (Ord. 647, 1982)
1.17.050: APPROVAL OF MOTION:
Approval of the motion to approve the consent calendar shall be fully
equivalent to approval, adoption, or enactment of each motion, resolution,
ordinance, or other item of business contained thereon, exactly as if each had
been acted upon individually, as fully as if set forth at length. Approval of
the motion must be by roll call vote. (Ord. 647, 1982)
1.17.060: MINUTES:
The city clerk shall record in the council minutes each item passed under the
consent calendar individually and in full. (Ord. 647, 1982)
CHAPTER 1.18
PROCEDURE AT MEETINGS
SECTION:
1.18.010: Scope Of Rules
1.18.020: Special Meetings And Call Thereof
1.18.030: Presiding Officer
1.18.040: Call Of Roll Of Members
1.18.050: Order Of Business
1.18.060: Limitation On Remarks
1.18.070: Permission To Speak Required
1.18.080: Absence Of Council Members
1.18.090: Resolutions And Ordinances To Be In Writing
1.18.100: Motions To Reconsider
1.18.110: Motions To Lay Matters On The Table
1.18.120: Motion For Adjournment
1.18.130: Roll Call Vote
1.18.140: Questions Of Order
1.18.150: Alteration Of Rules
1.18.160: Submission Of Reports
1.18.170: Compulsion Of Attendance
1.18.180: Adoption Of Robert's Rules Of Order
1.18.010: SCOPE OF RULES:
The rules or order of procedure prescribed in this chapter shall govern
deliberations and meetings of the council. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.020: SPECIAL MEETINGS AND CALL THEREOF:
Special meetings of the council may be held at the call of the mayor by serving
notice on each member of the council in writing stating the object of the
meeting as provided in section 50-604 of the Idaho Code. One-half (1/2) plus
one of the members of the full council shall have the power to call special
meetings of the city council by serving notice in writing to all members of the
council, stating the object of the meeting as provided by section 50-706 of the
Idaho Code. Notice of special meetings shall be conspicuously placed in the
records of the city council, and shall be posted in such public places in the
city as may be best selected to give the public notice of the holding of such a
meeting. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.030: PRESIDING OFFICER:
The presiding officer of the council shall be the mayor, or in his absence, the
president of the council. In the absence of both the mayor and president of the
council, the city clerk shall call the council to order and call the roll. If
there is a quorum present, the council shall elect, by majority vote, a
chairman to act until the arrival of the mayor or president of the council. The
presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at all regular and
special meetings. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.040: CALL OF ROLL OF MEMBERS:
Before proceeding with the business of the council, the city clerk shall call
the roll of the members and the names of those present shall be entered in the
minutes. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.050: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The order of business of the council shall be as follows:
A.   Call to order
B.   Pledge Of Allegiance
C.   Invocation
D.   Public hearings
E.   Consent calendar
F.   Citizen correspondence, issues and reports
G.   Proclamations
H.   Resolutions
I.   Ordinances - old business
J.   Ordinances - new business
K.   Contracts/capital acquisitions
L.   City council discussion and possible action items
M.   Council reports
N.   City administrator reports
O.   Department head reports
P.   Executive session
Q.   Adjournment. (Ord. 1145, 2015)
1.18.060: LIMITATION ON REMARKS:
No member shall speak more than twice on the same subject at any one meeting
without permission of the presiding officer. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.070: PERMISSION TO SPEAK REQUIRED:
No person, not a member of the council, shall be allowed to address the council
while in session without permission of the presiding officer. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.080: ABSENCE OF COUNCIL MEMBERS:
Any council member whose duty it is to attend regular and special meetings of
the council who shall be absent without the excuse of the presiding officer,
may be fined in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) per meeting at the
discretion of the council. A majority of the members present, even in the
absence of a quorum, may compel the attendance of absent members and approve
the levy of such a fine. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.090: RESOLUTIONS AND ORDINANCES TO BE IN WRITING:
All resolutions and ordinances of the city shall be in writing. (Ord. 648,
1982)
1.18.100: MOTIONS TO RECONSIDER:
Motions to reconsider must be by a member who voted with the prevailing side
and at the same or next succeeding meeting of the council. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.110: MOTIONS TO LAY MATTERS ON THE TABLE:
Motions to lay matters on the table shall be first in order, and on all
questions, the last amendment, the most distant day, and the largest sum shall
be put first. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.120: MOTION FOR ADJOURNMENT:
A motion for adjournment shall always be in order. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.130: ROLL CALL VOTE:
Whenever it shall be required by one or more members, the yeas and nays shall
be recorded; any member may call for the recording of the yeas and nays. The
passage of an ordinance or resolution to enter into a contract shall be by roll
call of the council with the yea or nay of each being recorded. (Ord. 648,
1982)
1.18.140: QUESTIONS OF ORDER:
All questions of order shall be decided by the presiding officer of the council
with the right of appeal to the council by any member, which appeal shall be
decided by a majority of those present. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.150: ALTERATION OF RULES:
The rules of the council may be altered, amended, or temporarily suspended by a
vote of one-half (1/2) plus one of the members present. (Ord. 648, 1982)
1.18.160: SUBMISSION OF REPORTS:
The chairman of each committee established by the council, or a council member
acting in the place thereof, shall submit or make all reports to the council
when so requested by the presiding officer or any member of the council. (Ord.
648, 1982)
1.18.170: COMPULSION OF ATTENDANCE:
The city clerk, city treasurer, city attorney, chief of police, fire chief,
building inspector, any other employee or officer of the city, shall, when
requested, attend all meetings of the city council, and shall remain in the
council room for such length of time as the council shall direct. (Ord. 648,
1982)
1.18.180: ADOPTION OF ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER:
"Robert's Rules Of Order", newly revised, a copy of which is on file at the
office of the city clerk, is hereby adopted as the parliamentary procedure for
the city council. (Ord. 648, 1982)
CHAPTER 1.20
INITIATIVES AND REFERENDUMS
SECTION:
1.20.010: Purpose
1.20.020: General Provisions
1.20.030: Referendum Petition Filing Time Limit
1.20.040: Special Election Date Set Upon Petition Certification
1.20.050: Statutory Requirements
1.20.010: PURPOSE:
The citizens of Jerome, Idaho shall have the right to enact ordinances by
initiative and repeal ordinances by referendum, in accordance with the
provisions of the ordinance codified in this chapter. (Ord. 601 §1, 1979)
1.20.020: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
A.   An initiative to enact an ordinance or a referendum to repeal an ordinance
shall be commenced by filing a petition with the city clerk.
B.   The petition shall contain a full text of the proposed ordinance or
describe by ordinance number, or reference to the appropriate section of the
city code, the ordinance sought to be repealed, and shall be accompanied by the
signature of legal city voters in an amount not less than a number equal to
twenty percent (20%) of the total number of voters registered to vote at the
last city general election.
C.   Each petition shall contain, adjacent to each signature, the typed or
printed name and address of each signer thereof. (Ord. 601 §2, 1979)
1.20.030: REFERENDUM PETITION FILING TIME LIMIT:
Referendum petitions complying with the ordinance codified in this chapter
shall be filed with the city clerk not less than sixty (60) days following the
final adoption of the ordinance subject to the referendum petition. (Ord. 601
§3, 1979)
1.20.040: SPECIAL ELECTION DATE SET UPON PETITION CERTIFICATION:
A special election for initiative or referendum shall be set within ninety (90)
days of certification of the petition by the city clerk, provided that such a
special election shall be combined with any municipal election set within the
time period. The initiative or referendum question shall be determined by a
majority vote of the lawful ballots cast. Voter qualifications and registration
requirements shall be the same as those in effect for general municipal
elections. (Ord. 601 §4, 1979)
1.20.050: STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS:
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, referendum and initiative
petitions shall conform with all requirements for signature, verification of
valid petitions, printing of petitions and time limits, except as expressly
modified to meet the requirements for initiative and referendum, expressed in
sections 34-1701 through 34-1705, Idaho Code. (Ord. 601 §5, 1979)

OFFICIAL NEWSPAPER 1

1.24.010: Official Newspaper Designated
 
Notes

1.24.010: OFFICIAL NEWSPAPER DESIGNATED:
The "Times News", a legal newspaper of general circulation, printed and

city. (Ord. 1048 §1, 2008)
CHAPTER 1.28
CITY BOUNDARIES 1
SECTION:
1.28.010: Defined And Described
1.28.020: Identification References
1.28.030: Adoption And Recordation Of Map
 
Notes
1 1. IC §63-2215.
   
1.28.010: DEFINED AND DESCRIBED:
The boundaries of the city are defined and described as follows:
A.   Beginning at the southeast corner of Block A-176 of Jerome Townsite;
running thence north along the east boundary of Blocks A-176 and A-182 extended
northerly to the southeast corner of Lot 4 in Block 8, Bremer Subdivision to
Jerome Townsite; thence north along the east boundary of said Lot 4 to a point
which intersects with the southwest corner of the northeast quarter of the
northeast quarter of Section 19, Township 8 South, Range 17 East, Boise
Meridian, or the southwest corner of Heiss Subdivision No. 1, Jerome Townsite;
thence east along the south boundary of said Heiss Subdivision No. 1 to the
southeast corner thereof; thence north along the east boundary of said Heiss
Subdivision No. 1 to the northeast corner thereof; thence west along the north
boundary of said Heiss Subdivision No. 1 to its intersection with the east
boundary of Bremer Subdivision, Jerome Townsite; thence north along the east
boundary of said Bremer Subdivision and its extension to the southeast corner
of Block A-197; thence north along the east boundaries of Blocks A-197 and A-
202 to the northeast corner of Block A-202; thence west along the north
boundary of Block A-202 to the northwest corner thereof; thence north along the
east line of Fillmore Street to the south boundary of Bryan Henry Subdivision
No. 1, Jerome Townsite; thence east along the south boundary of said Bryan
Henry Subdivision No. 1 to the southeast corner thereof; thence north along the
east boundary of said Bryan Henry Subdivision No. 1 and the east boundary of
Block A-218; continuing thence north along the east boundary of the northwest
quarter of the northeast quarter of Section 18, Township 8 South, Range 17
East, Boise Meridian, a distance of 945 feet, to a point which is the northeast
corner of the Mountain View Subdivision, City of Jerome; running thence west
along the north boundary of said Mountain View Subdivision a distance of 356.66
feet; thence running north and parallel to the east boundary of said northwest
quarter of the northeast quarter a distance of 50 feet; thence running westerly
and parallel to the north boundary of said northwest quarter of the northeast
quarter a distance of 236.05 feet, more or less, to the west boundary of
Fillmore Street of the City of Jerome projected; running thence southerly along
said west boundary of Fillmore Street extended, a distance of 305 feet; thence
running westerly and parallel with the north boundary of said northwest quarter
of the northeast quarter a distance of 40 feet to a point of tangency of a
20°0' curve to the left (I=37°0'); thence along the arc of said curve to the
left a distance of 185.93 ft. the long chord of which bears S 71°39' W a
distance of 182.73 feet to a point of tangency of a 34°0' curve to the right

1.28.020: IDENTIFICATION REFERENCES:
The lots, blocks, acreage tracts, streets and avenues referred to in subsection
1.28.010A of this chapter refer to the designated lots, blocks, acreage tracts,
streets and avenues in Jerome Townsite and to the subdivisions and additions
thereof, as shown by the official plats thereof on file and of record in the
recorder's office of the county; the various subdivision and additions referred
to refer to the respective official plats thereof on file in the county
recorder's office; and the original plat of Jerome Townsite and such plats of
such subdivisions and additions are adopted and made a part of this section for
the necessary identification of the lots, blocks, acreage tracts, streets,
avenues, additions and subdivisions referred to in such subsection and that
ordinances 268 and 284 of the city, on file in the office of the city clerk,
are referred to and made a part hereof for the necessary identification of
certain streets and avenues names to which were changed by such ordinances.
(Prior code §1-14)
1.28.030: ADOPTION AND RECORDATION OF MAP:
The map and plat attached hereto showing the corporate limits of the city, on
file in the office of the city clerk, as altered and changed by section
1.28.010 of this chapter is made a part of this code, and shall be recorded,
along with a copy of this chapter, certified by the clerk, as provided by law.
(Prior code §1-15)
CHAPTER 1.32
ELECTIONS 1
SECTION:
1.32.010: Precincts Established
1.32.020: Election Officers; Appointment And Qualifications
1.32.030: Election Officers; Term Of Office
1.32.040: Election Officers; Representation Of All Political Parties
1.32.050: Election Officers; Notice Of Appointment
1.32.060: Election Officers; Filling Vacancies
1.32.070: Election Officers; Compensation
1.32.080: Polling Hours
 
Notes
1 1. IC §50-401 et seq.
1.32.010: PRECINCTS ESTABLISHED:
There are established two (2) election precincts, numbered first and second,
the first precinct being the election precinct for those voters of the city
residing north of the center line of Main Street and the second precinct being
for the residents of the remainder of the city. The city council shall
designate a suitable polling place in each precinct and cause the same to be
provided with voting compartments, supplies, official stamps, ballot boxes and
such other supplies as county commissioners are required to provide for state
elections. (Prior code §2-30)
1.32.020: ELECTION OFFICERS; APPOINTMENT AND QUALIFICATIONS:
The city council shall, at its first regular meeting in October, prior to each
biennial election, appoint five (5) capable and discreet persons, possessing
the qualifications of electors, for each polling place, as election officers.
Three (3) of such persons shall be designated as judges of election and two (2)
of such persons shall be designated as clerks of election. (Prior code §2-31)
1.32.030: ELECTION OFFICERS; TERM OF OFFICE:
Judges and clerks of election shall hold office for the period of two (2) years
and shall be the officials of all elections, both general and special, during
that period. (Prior code §2-32)
1.32.040: ELECTION OFFICERS; REPRESENTATION OF ALL POLITICAL PARTIES:
The selection of judges and clerks of election must, as nearly as practical,
represent all political parties of the city. (Prior code §2-33)
1.32.050: ELECTION OFFICERS; NOTICE OF APPOINTMENT:
The city clerk shall give the appointed judges and clerks of election notice of
their appointment and shall request each appointee to give notice of his
acceptance or declination of his appointment to the city clerk within ten (10)
days thereafter. (Prior code §2-34)
1.32.060: ELECTION OFFICERS; FILLING VACANCIES:
Any vacancies arising in the office of judges and clerks of elections shall be
filled by the city clerk. (Ord. 627(E), 1980: prior code §2-35)
1.32.070: ELECTION OFFICERS; COMPENSATION:
The compensation of judges and clerks of the election shall be determined by
the city council at the time of their appointment. (Ord. 627(F), 1980: prior
code §2-36)
1.32.080: POLLING HOURS:
At all general and special city elections, the polls shall be open between
twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. Provided, however,
that should a general election of the United States of America, state of Idaho,
or county of Jerome take place on the same date as a special or general city
election, polls shall be open between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. (Ord. 838 §1, 1997)
TITLE 2
ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL
CHAPTER 2.04
CITY COUNCIL 1
SECTION:
2.04.010: Number And Election Of Councilmen
2.04.020: Time And Place Of Meetings
2.04.030: Reports Of City Officers To Council
 
Notes
1 1. IC ch. 50-7.
2.04.010: NUMBER AND ELECTION OF COUNCILMEN:
There shall be four (4) councilmen who shall be elected at the time and in the
manner as provided by the laws of the state. (Prior code §2-1)
2.04.020: TIME AND PLACE OF MEETINGS:
Regular meetings of the council of the city shall be held at the Jerome city
council chambers on the first and third Tuesdays in each month at five thirty
o'clock (5:30) P.M.; provided, however, that should said regular meeting days
fall on a holiday, as defined elsewhere in this code, then such regular meeting
shall take place on the next business day following the holiday at five thirty
o'clock (5:30) P.M. in the Jerome city council chambers. (Ord. 1038 §2, 2007:
Ord. 743 §1, 1992: Ord. 678, 1984: prior code §2-2)
2.04.030: REPORTS OF CITY OFFICERS TO COUNCIL:
In all cases, not otherwise provided by laws of the state, the provisions of
this code and other ordinances of the city, all officers, elective and
appointive, shall make a written report to the city council of their activities
at the first regular meeting of the council in each month. Any of the above
officers charged with the collection of monies shall include with such report
an accounting and turnover of all monies collected. (Prior code §2-6)
CHAPTER 2.06
PERSONNEL POLICY
SECTION:
2.06.010: Appointive Officers
2.06.020: Term Of Office And Removal
2.06.030: Employees
2.06.035: Employee Discipline
2.06.040: Employment Not Guaranteed; Exception
2.06.045: City Administrator's Role In Discipline
2.06.050: Employment Actions
2.06.060: Department Head Discipline
2.06.070: City Administrator Discipline
2.06.080: Terms Of Employment
2.06.010: APPOINTIVE OFFICERS:
Appointive officers of the city shall hold office for the duration of their
appointment unless sooner removed, by appointment of the mayor and approval of
a majority of the city council shall be as follows:
A.   Clerk and treasurer/finance director;
B.   City attorney;
C.   City administrator.
These officers shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of a
majority of the members of the city council upon such terms and conditions as
the council shall establish in writing at the time of appointment. (Ord. 1129,
2014)
2.06.020: TERM OF OFFICE AND REMOVAL:
All appointive officers shall hold office for the term for which they were
appointed and qualified; provided, that any appointive officer may at any time
be removed by the action of the mayor with the concurrence of one-half (1/2)
plus one of the full city council or by the unanimous vote of the full city
council. (Ord. 1129, 2014)
2.06.030: EMPLOYEES:
All persons hired by the city shall be considered employees of the city, except
for bona fide independent contractors of the city. Hiring of all employees of
the city, except for department heads, shall be by the department head of the
department to which the employee will be assigned, subject to the approval of
the city administrator. (Ord. 1129, 2014)
2.06.035: EMPLOYEE DISCIPLINE:
Discipline of employees shall be undertaken by the department heads over the
department to which an employee has been assigned. Provided, that no
termination of an employee shall be done without the consent of the city
administrator. (Ord. 1129, 2014)
2.06.040: EMPLOYMENT NOT GUARANTEED; EXCEPTION:
Unless otherwise specified in writing, signed by the mayor and approved by the
city council, or specifically authorized by the city council by motion duly
adopted as reflected in the minutes of a regularly constituted meeting of the
city council, no employee of the city shall be guaranteed employment for any
specific length of time. (Ord. 679 §4, 1984)
2.06.045: CITY ADMINISTRATOR'S ROLE IN DISCIPLINE:
A.   Any other provision of this code to the contrary notwithstanding, the city
administrator may, upon the consent of the mayor and council, investigate
alleged misconduct of city employees. (Ord. 1129, 2014)
2.06.050: EMPLOYMENT ACTIONS:
Employment actions shall be handled as provided by the "City Personnel Policy
Manual". (Ord. 1129, 2014)
2.06.060: DEPARTMENT HEAD DISCIPLINE:
A department head shall be subject to all rules of the city of Jerome regarding
conduct of its other employees. Any job action with respect to a department
head shall be in writing, and delivered to the department head. Any discipline
of a department head, other than the city administrator, shall be by the city
administrator. (Ord. 1129, 2014)
2.06.070: CITY ADMINISTRATOR DISCIPLINE:
Discipline of the city administrator shall be by the mayor, subject to the
approval of a majority of the council, or alternatively, by one-half (1/2) plus
one of the full council. (Ord. 1129, 2014)
2.06.080: TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT:
No appointive officer or employee of the city shall have authority to grant any
employee terms or conditions of employment which have not been officially
adopted by the city by ordinances, resolutions, or written agreements. No city
officer or employee shall have any guaranteed term of employment, conditional
or otherwise, unless done by the city by official action, through ordinance,
resolution or written agreement. (Ord. 1129, 2014: Ord. 679 §13, 1984)
CHAPTER 2.08
EMPLOYEES' BONDS
SECTION:
2.08.010: Bonds Of City Employees
2.08.020: Authority To Require Bond Of Other Employees
2.08.010: BONDS OF CITY EMPLOYEES:
Before entering upon the duties of their respective office, any employee of the
city may be required to enter into, execute and file with the city clerk an
official fidelity bond. Each of such bonds shall be conditioned for the
faithful performance of the duties of each such employee, including therein the
duties of all offices of which such employees may be ex officio incumbent. All
of such bonds shall be subject to the approval of the mayor and council and,
when so approved, shall be filed with the city clerk, except the bond of the
city clerk which shall be filed with the mayor. The premiums of all of such
bonds shall be paid by the city. (Ord. 1130, 2014)
2.08.020: AUTHORITY TO REQUIRE BOND OF OTHER EMPLOYEES:
The mayor and council of the city may, whenever they deem it advisable, require
any employee of the city to furnish bonds in such amounts as may be set by the
mayor and council. (Ord. 1130, 2014)

§1, 1991: Ord. 683 §1, 1985: prior code §2-3)
CHAPTER 2.16
CITY ATTORNEY
SECTION:
2.16.010: Appointment And Term
2.16.020: Duties
2.16.010: APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
The mayor, with the consent of the city council, at the time of taking office,
shall appoint some competent and suitable licensed attorney as city attorney.
The incumbent shall hold office until removed by the mayor with the consent of
the council. (Ord. 1130, 2014)
2.16.020: DUTIES:
The city attorney shall be the legal advisor of the council. He shall commence,
prosecute and defend all suits and actions necessary to be commenced,
prosecuted or defended on behalf of the city, or that be ordered by the
council. When requested he shall attend meetings of the council and give them
his opinion on any matter submitted to him either orally or in writing as may
be required. (Prior code §2-11)
CHAPTER 2.20
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2.20.010: Created; Purpose
2.20.020: Building Inspections; Records
2.20.030: Spectators To Remain At Least One Hundred Feet From Fire
2.20.040: Unauthorized Removal Or Use Of Fire Apparatus
2.20.050: Interference With Fire Department
2.20.060: False Alarms
2.20.070: Inspection Service Fees
2.20.010: CREATED; PURPOSE:
There is organized and created a fire department of the city, for the purpose
of protecting property and the lives of citizens of the city. (Prior code §8-1)
2.20.020: BUILDING INSPECTIONS; RECORDS:
A.   The fire chief, or any member he may so designate, is authorized,
empowered and required to inspect from time to time, but not less frequently
than twice yearly, all buildings and premises where accumulations of
combustible materials or other hazardous conditions are liable to exist, and to
order such changes or removal as in his opinion are necessary for safety from
fire, principally in the business and industrial sections. For the purpose of
inspection, he is empowered to enter any and all buildings and premises at any
reasonable hour. In lieu of practices with the equipment, the department may
inspect buildings to familiarize themselves with interior arrangement and
contents.
B.   Records shall be kept of all inspections including notes and sketches.
These records shall be made a permanent part of the records of the fire
department. (Ord. 1130, 2014: prior code §8-9)
2.20.030: SPECTATORS TO REMAIN AT LEAST ONE HUNDRED FEET FROM FIRE:
All persons must remain at least one hundred feet (100') from the building in
which a fire is in progress or from a place to which firemen are called to
extinguish a fire, excepting the owner or occupants of buildings menaced by
fire. (Ord. 1130, 2014: prior code §8-10)
2.20.040: UNAUTHORIZED REMOVAL OR USE OF FIRE APPARATUS:
It is unlawful for any person to knowingly and wilfully remove any part of the
fire apparatus or any property connected with the fire department, owned by the
city, from the firehouse or grounds, except in case of fire, fire alarm,
practice or for repairs; provided, that the chief of the fire department may
give his consent in writing to move such apparatus, and such consent may be
revoked by the city council, and if such consent is granted by the chief of the
fire department, a copy must be filed in the office of the city clerk. (Ord.
1130, 2014: prior code §8-11)
2.20.050: INTERFERENCE WITH FIRE DEPARTMENT:
It is unlawful for any person to knowingly and wilfully interfere with any
person who may be engaged in fighting fire, within the city, to mutilate hose
or any other property connected with the fire department, to drive over any
hose or to remove any hydrant caps, except when being repaired or under the
authority of the proper officers of the city. A violation of this provision
shall be deemed a misdemeanor and anyone having been found guilty or having
pled guilty to same violation may be subject to six (6) months in county jail
and/or a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) fine. (Ord. 1130, 2014)
2.20.060: FALSE ALARMS:
It is unlawful for any person within the city to knowingly and wilfully give
any false alarms of fire. A violation of this provision shall be deemed a
misdemeanor and anyone having been found guilty or having pled guilty to same
violation may be subject to six (6) months in county jail and/or a one thousand
dollar ($1,000.00) fine. (Ord. 1130, 2014)
2.20.070: INSPECTION SERVICE FEES:
A.   Fees Established For Inspection Service: A reasonable fee shall be charged
for the performance of the following inspection and related services performed
by the fire department:
   1.   Standpipe, range, hood and duct system inspections.
   2.   Natural and LPG gas inspections.
   3.   Fuel tanks and piping above and under ground.
   4.   Daycare and in-home care centers.
   5.   Hazardous materials.
   6.   Fireworks sales and public displays.
   7.   Fire department rescue calls:
      a.   Medical Aid (Outside The City): Events where special assistance from
the fire department are requested from the Jerome County ambulance service
outside the city limits. This request may include:
         (1)   Fire department EMTs.
         (2)   Assistance with patient stabilization and loading for transport.
      b.   Rescue And Vehicle Extrication: These are rescue services which are
requested by the Jerome County ambulance service for patient access and/or
removal from areas in which they are trapped. This service involves advanced
equipment and training which is beyond the general scope of normal firefighting
functions.
   8.   Fire department nonemergency services: This is a request for fire
department services not normally within the general scope of provided services
such as:
      a.   Request from a private individual or company for the fire department
to stand by while they conduct a procedure that may cause a fire or be a safety
hazard to the public.
      b.   Control burns requested by a property owner which they cannot
conduct by themselves.
   9.   Nonfire department hydrant use: The private use of fire equipment which
is used to gain water for private use from a city fire hydrant. Equipment may
include:
      a.   Fire hose.
      b.   Hydrant gate valve.
      c.   Hydrant wrench.
      d.   Other equipment as needed.
   10.   Fire alarm system.
   11.   Issuance of gas licenses and examinations for gas licenses.
B.   Exact Fee: The exact fee for each service rendered as above described may
be prescribed by resolution. (Ord. 1130, 2014: Ord. 826 §§1, 2, 1997)

2.24.010: ESTABLISHED:

REVENUE AND FINANCE
CHAPTER 3.04

SECTION:

3.04.010: GENERALLY:
A.   The First Security Bank of Idaho, N.A., the Bank of Idaho and the Idaho
First National Bank, are designated as official depositories of the city.
B.   Subject to the provisions of title 57, chapter 1, Idaho Code, the public
