CHAPTER 3.08
LOCAL IMPROVEMENT GUARANTEE FUND 1
SECTION:
3.08.010: Created
3.08.020: Purpose
3.08.030: Tax Levy To Provide Money For Fund Generally
3.08.040: When Warrants To Be Paid Out Of Fund; Interest On Unpaid Warrants
3.08.050: City's Right Of Subrogation When Warrants Paid Out Of Fund
3.08.060: Money Derived From Collection Of Delinquent Local Improvement
Assessments To Be Paid Into Fund; Use Of Fund To Redeem Certain Property
3.08.070: Tax Levy To Replenish Fund
3.08.080: Limitation Of Claim Of Persons Holding Local Improvement Bonds Or
Warrants
3.08.090: Termination Of Fund
3.08.100: Effectuation Of Chapter By City Officers
3.08.110: Chapter To Constitute A Contract With Persons Holding Local
Improvement Bonds Or Warrants
 
Notes
1 1. IC §50-1762 et seq.; §50-1723.
3.08.010: CREATED:
There is created in the city, a special fund known and designated as the "local
improvement guarantee fund" of the city. (Prior code §12-1)
3.08.020: PURPOSE:
The local improvement guarantee fund is created for the purpose of
guaranteeing, to the extent of such fund the payment of local improvement
warrants and bonds, and the interest thereon, and the payment of other bonds or
warrants, or both, and interest thereon, which may hereafter be issued against
any local improvement district in the city for the payment of local
improvements therein. (Prior code §12-2)
3.08.030: TAX LEVY TO PROVIDE MONEY FOR FUND GENERALLY:
In order to provide money for the local improvement guarantee fund and for the
use and the purposes of such fund, the mayor and city council shall levy an
annual tax of one mill per year, beginning with the tax due and collectible in
the year 1958, on all of the taxable property in the city; provided, however,
that the city may reduce the amount of levy if the city appropriates from other
proper sources, as may be determined by the city, a sum approximately equal in
amount to the sum which it is estimated will not be collected but would have
been collected except for such reduction of the levy; and provided, further,
that the total sum so levied or appropriated, or both, in any year, shall not
be more than sufficient to pay the outstanding warrants on such fund and to
establish therein a balance, which combined levy and appropriations in any one
year shall not exceed five percent (5%) of the outstanding obligations thereby
guaranteed; and provided, further, that the city shall not levy and tax as
provided in this chapter when the amount of monies in the local improvement
guarantee fund equals ten percent (10%) of the total outstanding obligations to
be guaranteed. The tax levies authorized and directed in this chapter shall be
additional to, and if need be, in excess of any and all statutory and charter
limitations. (Prior code §12-3)
3.08.040: WHEN WARRANTS TO BE PAID OUT OF FUND; INTEREST ON UNPAID WARRANTS:
When any bond, warrant or coupon drawn against any local improvement fund is
presented to the city for payment and there is not sufficient amount in the
local improvement fund against which to draw to pay the same, unless otherwise
requested by the holder, payment therefor shall be made by warrant drawn
against the local improvement guarantee fund. Such warrants when presented to
the city treasurer for payment, if not paid, shall be registered and shall draw
interest at a rate of six percent (6%) per annum. Neither the holder nor the
owner of any bond or warrant issued in any local improvement district shall
have any claim therefor except for the payment from the special assessments
made for the improvement for which such bond or warrant was issued and except
against the local improvement guarantee fund provided for in this chapter. The
city shall not be liable to any holder or owner of such bond or warrant for any
loss to any guarantee fund occurring in the lawful operation thereof by the
city. (Prior code §12-4)
3.08.050: CITY'S RIGHT OF SUBROGATION WHEN WARRANTS PAID OUT OF FUND:
A.   Whenever there shall be paid out of the local improvement guarantee fund
any sum on account of principal or interest of a local improvement bond or
warrant, the city, as trustee for the fund, shall be subrogated to all of the
rights of the holders or owners of the bonds or interest, coupons or warrants
so paid, and the policies thereof, or the assessment underlying the same, shall
become part of the guarantee fund.
B.   There shall be paid into the guarantee fund any surplus remaining in any
local improvement fund after the payment of all outstanding bonds or warrants
so paid, and the policies thereof, or the assessment underlying the same, shall
become part of the guarantee fund.
C.   There shall be paid into the guarantee fund any surplus remaining in any
local improvement fund after the payment of all outstanding bonds or warrants,
payable out of such local improvement fund. Bonds or warrants guaranteed by
such fund shall have no preference except in the order of presentation for
payment. (Prior code §12-5)
3.08.060: MONEY DERIVED FROM COLLECTION OF DELINQUENT LOCAL IMPROVEMENT
ASSESSMENTS TO BE PAID INTO FUND; USE OF FUND TO REDEEM CERTAIN PROPERTY:
A.   All monies derived from the assignment of delinquent certificates,
redemptions, sale of property under foreclosure for delinquent local
improvement assessments or from the rent or sale of property, title to which
has been obtained by the city pursuant to sections 50-3001 to 50-3009 of the
Idaho Code, and the terms of this chapter, and all other laws amendatory
thereof and supplemental thereto, shall be paid into the local improvement
guarantee fund, and all delinquency certificates issued and any such property
acquired shall be held by the city for the benefit of such guarantee fund.
B.   Money from the guarantee fund may be used to redeem property subject to
local improvement assessments from general tax delinquencies underlying bonds
or warrants guaranteed by the fund, or to purchase such property at county tax
sales or otherwise, from the county for the purpose of protecting the guarantee
fund.
C.   After so acquiring title to real property, the city may lease or sell and
convey the same for such price and on such terms as may be determined by the
mayor and city council, and any provisions of law, charter or ordinance to the
contrary notwithstanding, and all proceeds resulting therefrom shall belong to
and be paid into the guarantee fund; provided, however, that in the event the
city purchases such property at tax sale, or otherwise, it shall not be sold
for a lesser sum than the city paid therefor. (Prior code §12-6)
3.08.070: TAX LEVY TO REPLENISH FUND:
Whenever there is not a sufficient amount of cash in the local improvement
guarantee fund at any time to pay any and all warrants, together with interest
thereon, drawn against such fund, the city council may replenish the local
improvement guarantee fund by transferring or appropriating to it, monies from
the general fund of the city, or other available sources as may be determined
by the city council subject, however, to the limitations prescribed in this
chapter. Warrants drawing interest as provided in this chapter may be issued
against the local improvement guarantee fund to meet any financial inability
against it; but, at the time of making its next annual tax levy the city shall
provide for the levy of a sum sufficient with other resources of the guarantee
fund, to pay warrants so issued and outstanding, the tax for this purpose not
to exceed one mill in any one year. (Prior code §12-7)
3.08.080: LIMITATION OF CLAIM OF PERSONS HOLDING LOCAL IMPROVEMENT BONDS OR
WARRANTS:
The holder or owner of any local improvement bond or warrant shall have no
claim thereon against the city, except to the extent of the funds created and
received by assessments against the property within any local improvement
district and to the extent of his pro rata share of the local improvement
guarantee fund, authorized and issued under the provisions of this chapter.
(Prior code §12-8)
3.08.090: TERMINATION OF FUND:
At such time, and not before, when all bonds and coupons of all existing local
improvement districts in the city shall have been paid in full, the mayor and
city council may provide by ordinance that the amount and all property rights
in the local improvement guarantee fund shall revert to the general fund of the
city, and the local improvement guarantee fund shall terminate and be
nonexistent thereafter. (Prior code §12-9)
3.08.100: EFFECTUATION OF CHAPTER BY CITY OFFICERS:
The officers of the city are authorized and directed to take all action
necessary or appropriate to effectuate the provisions of this chapter. (Prior
code §12-10)
3.08.110: CHAPTER TO CONSTITUTE A CONTRACT WITH PERSONS HOLDING LOCAL
IMPROVEMENT BONDS OR WARRANTS:
After warrants or bonds of local improvement district 9 for curbs, gutters and
sidewalks for the city have been issued, this chapter shall constitute a
contract by the city and the holder or holders of such bonds, and shall be and
remain irrepealable until such warrants or bonds or both, and the interest
accruing thereon, shall have been fully paid, satisfied and discharged. (Prior
code §12-11)
CHAPTER 3.12
BAD CHECKS
SECTION:
3.12.010: Fee For Returned Check For Payment For City Services
3.12.010: FEE FOR RETURNED CHECK FOR PAYMENT FOR CITY SERVICES:

TITLE 4
BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES
CHAPTER 4.04
COMMUNITY SPIRIT COMMITTEE
SECTION:
4.04.010: Creation; Purpose
4.04.020: Mission
4.04.030: Membership
4.04.040: Bylaws
4.04.010: CREATION; PURPOSE:
There is hereby created the community spirit committee as follows:
A.   The community along with strong partnerships have made great strides to
bring back community spirit with events like Christmas In The Park, City Wide
Cleanup Day, and continued support of the Joe Mama Car Show.
B.   To further encourage community spirit, the creation of this committee will
allow the city to:
   1.   Pursue opportunities to foster greater community participation and
involvement in Jerome community events.
   2.   Engage other commissions, entities, and businesses through outreach for
partnership opportunities.
   3.   Develop and support community events including, but not limited to, the
following:
      a.   Fourth Of July Celebration.
      b.   Community Block Party.
      c.   Mayor's Good Neighbor Award.
   4.   Continue support of current events. (Ord. 1156, 2016)
4.04.020: MISSION:
The mission of the community spirit committee is to increase citizen
participation and Jerome community spirit by ensuring the continuation of
established community events and creating more accessible, community minded
events. The committee will gather and listen to input from citizens and
businesses. (Ord. 1156, 2016)
4.04.030: MEMBERSHIP:
Members and officers shall be comprised of no greater than seven (7) members to
consist of residents and business owners. These members shall be appointed by
the mayor and will volunteer to serve on the committee for a period of two (2)
years. (Ord. 1156, 2016)
4.04.040: BYLAWS:
The bylaws dated August 22, 2016, are incorporated herein and are hereby
adopted by reference. (Ord. 1156, 2016)
CHAPTER 4.08
CITY DEVELOPER REIMBURSEMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
4.08.010: Establishment
4.08.020: Duties And Purposes
4.08.030: Membership
4.08.040: Vacancies
4.08.050: Removal Of Members
4.08.060: Nonpolitical; No Compensation
4.08.070: Chairman
4.08.080: Tenure
4.08.090: Meetings
4.08.100: Quorum
4.08.110: Rules
4.08.120: Conflict Of Interest
4.08.010: ESTABLISHMENT:
It is hereby established and created a Developer Reimbursement Commission to be
known as the Jerome Developer Reimbursement Commission. (Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.020: DUTIES AND PURPOSES:
The duties and purposes of the Developer Reimbursement Commission shall be as
follows:
A.   Administer the Council approved resolution for the amounts, methods and
procedures for reimbursement of costs to private initial developers who have
installed public works infrastructure improvements by any subsequent developers
or property owners that connect to those systems.
B.   The Office of the City Engineer shall prepare and maintain a system to
track all public works improvements by initial developers subject to
reimbursement.
C.   The commission shall accept requests for reimbursement, to include actual
receipted costs and plans, from the initial developer that has installed public
works infrastructure improvements to be paid back by any subsequent developers
or property owners who utilize same infrastructure improvements.
D.   With the assistance of the Office of the City Engineer, establish the
boundaries of properties that will be required to reimburse the initial
developer that installed the public works infrastructure improvements, and
notify owners of those properties of the requirement to reimburse the initial
developer when and if their properties eventually develop and utilize same
public works infrastructure improvements.
E.   Using cost information from the developer that installed the public works
improvements or other approved methods, determine the proper compensation that
any developer or property owner that connects the public works infrastructure
will be required to pay.
F.   Verify that the reimbursement has been made to the initial developer that
installed the public works infrastructure improvements by any subsequent
developer or property owner that connects to those systems. (Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.030: MEMBERSHIP:
There shall be three (3) voting members of the Developer Reimbursement
Commission to be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by the members of the
City Council. Members on the commission shall be actively engaged in the
profession of community development. Members are more specifically to be
appointed from the following organizations or professions: one member from the
development community; one member that is an engineer, surveyor or architect;
and one member at large. There shall also be two (2) nonvoting ex officio
members of the commission: City Administrator, and City Engineer, appointed by
the Mayor and Council. Members of the commission established under this section
should be residents of the City unless this residency requirement is
specifically waived by the Council. (Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.040: VACANCIES:
Any vacancies occurring in the membership of the Developer Reimbursement
Commission for any reason shall be filled by the Mayor, to be confirmed by the
City Council. (Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.050: REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
Any member of the Developer Reimbursement Commission may be removed by a
majority vote of the City Council. (Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.060: NONPOLITICAL; NO COMPENSATION:
The members of the Developer Reimbursement Commission shall be selected without
regard to their political affiliations and shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.070: CHAIRMAN:
The Developer Reimbursement Commission shall elect its Chairman and Vice-
Chairman and fill such offices as it may determine necessary and expedient.
(Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.080: TENURE:
The following tenure of office shall be provided for the members of the
Developer Reimbursement Commission:
A.   The initial commission members shall be appointed for three (3) year
terms.
B.   The ex officio members of the commission shall hold membership
corresponding to their tenures of office or employment in the City of Jerome.
(Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.090: MEETINGS:
All meetings will take place at City Council chambers and shall be open to the
public. (Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.100: QUORUM:
At least two (2) of the appointed voting members of the Developer Reimbursement
Commission shall be necessary to constitute a quorum and conduct any business
at any meeting of the commission. Any decision of the commission will require
at least a quorum of commission members for acceptance of the reimbursement.
(Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.110: RULES:
The Developer Reimbursement Commission shall adopt general rules for the
transactions of its business and shall make a written record of the meetings,
City resolutions, findings and determinations which said written record be kept
as permanent public record. (Ord. 1164, 2017)
4.08.120: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
A member of the commission shall not participate in any proceeding or action
when the member, his employer, or his employee, business partner or associate,
his business or any person related to him by affinity or consanguinity within
the second degree has an interest in the procedure or action. Any action or
potential interest in any proceeding shall be disclosed at or before any
meeting, duly entered and recorded in the minutes, at which the action is being
heard or considered.
The commission shall function under the City resolution determining appropriate
standards and defined criteria for reimbursement standards. (Ord. 1164, 2017)
TITLE 5
BUSINESS TAXES, LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 1
CHAPTER 5.04
GENERAL LICENSING PROVISIONS
(Rep. by Ord. 1007 §1, 2006)
 
Notes
1 1. IC §50-307.
CHAPTER 5.08
FOOD VEHICLES, VENDORS, SOLICITORS, AND TEMPORARY MERCHANTS
SECTION:
5.08.010: Regulations
5.08.010: REGULATIONS:
A.   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to protect the health, safety and
welfare of the City of Jerome and its residents by means of regulating food
vehicles, vendors, solicitors and temporary merchants.
B.   Definitions:
   FOOD VEHICLE: A food establishment that is located upon a vehicle, or which
is pulled by a vehicle, where food or beverage is prepared and served to the
public, including, but not limited to, food trucks, trailers, carts and vans.
   SOLICITOR: Any person, whether a resident of the City or not, who travels by
foot, motor vehicle or any other type of conveyance from place to place within
the City while taking, or attempting to take, in person, orders for sale of
goods, wares, services or merchandise of any nature whatsoever for future
delivery, whether or not advance payments are collected at the time of
solicitation. This definition shall include any person or entity who, for
himself or for another person or entity, hires, leases, uses or occupies any
building, structure, tent, place, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel or motel room,
apartment, lot, or public street or right-of-way within the City for the
purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery.
   SPECIAL EVENT: The temporary use, with a valid permit, of public property,
including streets, parks, and community centers, for the purpose of conducting
certain short term events such as art shows, music concerts, fundraising
events, amusement attractions, community events, circuses, carnival, rodeos,
including, but not limited to, street dances, tournaments, walkathons,
marathons, races, car shows, exhibitions or related activities.
   TEMPORARY MERCHANT: Any person whether owner or otherwise, whether a
resident of the City of Jerome or not, who engages in a temporary business of
selling and/or delivering food, beverages, goods, wares, merchandise or
services within the City limits, and who in furtherance of such purpose hires,
leases, uses or occupies any building, structure or motor vehicle within the
City, for the exhibition and sale of food, beverages, goods, merchandise or
services. Excluded from the term "temporary merchant" are the following
activities:
   1.   Public or private auctions for the disposal by an established business
of its assets or for an individual, for items of personal or household use.
   2.   Any person or entity described in this definition of "temporary
merchant" who sells goods or services exclusively to retail merchants within
the City limits.
   3.   Any religious or charitable entity, including nationally recognized
service clubs, engaging in any one or more of the otherwise prohibited
activities for beneficial, charitable or public benefit purposes.
   4.   Any show, exhibition or fair where goods or services for sale are
exhibited by the person manufacturing the goods or providing the services and
such exhibitor was invited by the person or entity sponsoring the event to
attend. Any person or entity sponsoring such an event shall make the names and
addresses of all exhibitors available to the City upon request.
   5.   Sales pursuant to court order.
   6.   The sale of farm or garden products by persons producing such products.
   7.   Sale of Christmas trees or wreaths in season, provided that any such
person engaged in such a business shall provide their name and address to the
City or a police officer of the City upon request.
   VENDOR: Any person, including an employee or agent of a group of
individuals, partnership, or corporation, who sells or offers to take orders to
sell food, beverages, wares, merchandise or services from a stand, cart, shack,
motor vehicle or any other type of conveyance or from his or her person,
including but not limited to, snow shacks. This definition shall include the
words "hauler", "huckster" and "peddler".
C.   Zoning Requirements: No temporary business license shall be granted to a
public or private location, building or structure in any residential zoning
district.
D.   Application: Any person seeking a license as a food vehicle, vendor,
solicitor, or temporary merchant within the City shall file with the City Clerk
a written, sworn application, signed by the applicant if an individual, by all
partners if a partnership, by all members if a limited liability company, by
the president and secretary of a corporation and by other similar authorized
officer or official of any other entity showing:
   1.   The name or names of the person or persons having the management or
supervision of the applicant's business during the time that it is proposed it
will be carried on in the City. Every address or location at which such
business will be carried on; permanent address or addresses of each person
signing the application, the capacity in which the person signing the
application will act; the name of the corporation or other entity on whose
account the business will be conducted; and, if a partnership, limited
liability company, corporation or other entity, the state in which the entity
was organized.
   2.   Idaho State Sales Tax license number.
   3.   A site plan showing the location of the temporary business, outdoor
seating arrangement and other information as required by the City Clerk.
   4.   The length of time during which it is proposed the business will be
conducted, together with signed lease, license or other permission from the
owner of the real property at which the business will be conducted evidencing
authority to operate at the location.
   5.   A description of the nature of the business and the goods, merchandise,
wares or services which will be dispensed or solicited.
   6.   A statement of whether or not the person or persons signing the
application have been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or felony and the
date, place and nature of every such conviction.
   7.   A valid, government issued ID or driver's license for every person
signing the application or who will conduct the business of the applicant
whether as a food vehicle, vendor, solicitor or temporary merchant.
   8.   If the applicant proposes to sell any food or beverage for human
consumption, a current certificate from the South Central Idaho Health District
authorizing such activity as being in compliance with law shall be required
prior to the issuance of this license, unless otherwise exempt by the South
Central Idaho Health District.
   9.   A waste disposal plan outlining how waste and grease will be disposed.
The Wastewater Department shall review and approve such plan.
   10.   Certification that the temporary business has passed all necessary
inspection from any local, State or Federal agency, including, but not limited
to, South Central Health District, Jerome City Fire Department and Jerome City
building official.
   11.   If the application is determined to be complete and accurate, the City
Clerk shall forward the application and supporting materials to the various
City departments for review and recommendation for approval or denial prior to
the issuance of a temporary merchant license to each applicant upon the payment
of the fee hereafter required.
E.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person, or any business
entity including, but not limited to, a corporation, limited liability company,
partnership, or any other business entity, or any contractor, agent or employee
of the same to act as a food vehicle, vendor, solicitor, or temporary merchant
within the City limits of Jerome, Idaho, without obtaining a license to do so.
F.   License Fee: A license fee shall be payable to the City Clerk in the
initial amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a food vehicle, vendor,
solicitor or temporary merchant. Each license shall be for a period of six (6)
months. Licenses may be renewed for additional six (6) month terms. The renewal
fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
G.   Bond Required: Every food vehicle, vendor, solicitor, or temporary
merchant shall, prior to commencement of the conduct of business, post a bond
with the City Clerk in the form of a surety bond, upon a surety license to
conduct business in the State of Idaho, deemed appropriate by the City Clerk,
or a cashier's check made payable to the City of Jerome, in the amount of five
hundred dollars ($500.00). The bond will be to ensure that garbage, paper,
litter or other debris associated with the conduct of the business does not
remain upon public or private property, including public rights-of-way within
the City. After expiration of a license, the City Clerk shall, upon application
of the licensee, return the bond or cashier's check within six (6) months of an
application for return being filed with the City Clerk, demonstrating that the
terms of the bond had been complied with. The bond shall be forfeited to the
City of Jerome upon the affidavit of the City Clerk or a police officer of the
City of Jerome to the effect that the food vehicle, vendor, solicitor or
temporary merchant has not complied with the provisions of this section.
H.   Exhibition Of License: Any license issued under this section shall be
conspicuously posted at any place of business at which the food vehicle, vendor
or temporary merchant is conducting business, or, if a solicitor, a copy of the
license shall be kept by every solicitor to be displayed upon the request of
any property owner being solicited or by a police officer of the City of
Jerome.
I.   Use Of Private Property Restricted: No owner or lessee of real property,
within the City of Jerome, nor any agent thereof, shall sublet, lease, or
otherwise license such real property to be used by a food vehicle, vendor,
temporary merchant or solicitor, unless such use is specifically excluded from
the duty of application and license under this section or unless the food
vehicle, vendor, temporary merchant or solicitor has obtained the license
required herein.
J.   Rules And Regulations For Food Vehicles, Vendors And Temporary Merchants:
   1.   Shall maintain a clean appearance, free of rust and decay.
   2.   Shall be located a minimum distance of five feet (5') from the edge of
any driveway or public sidewalk, utility boxes and vaults, handicapped ramp,
building entrance, exits, or emergency access/exit ways, or emergency call box
and shall not locate within any area of the lot that impedes, endangers, or
interferes with pedestrian or vehicular traffic.
   3.   Shall be located a minimum distance of ten feet (10') in all directions
of a fire hydrant.
   4.   Food vehicles shall provide proof of mobility on a semi-annual basis.
Physically driving the food vehicle to City offices when renewing a temporary
merchant license shall constitute proof of mobility.
   5.   Drive-throughs shall be prohibited.
   6.   Temporary connections to potable water and other utilities are
prohibited.
   7.   Shall be responsible for the proper disposal of waste and trash
associated with the operation. City trash receptacles shall not be used for
this purpose. Shall keep all areas within ten feet (10') of the business and
any associated seating area clean of grease, trash, paper, cups or cans
associated with the vending operation.
   8.   No liquid waste or grease may be disposed of in tree pits, storm drains
or onto the sidewalks, streets, or other public space. Under no circumstances
shall grease be released or disposed of in the City's sanitary sewer system.
   9.   With the exception of allowable outdoor seating areas, all equipment
required for the operation shall be contained within, attached to or within ten
feet (10') of the retail sales. Outdoor seating areas shall be placed in a safe
manner and to not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic.
   10.   Canopies, carports, sheds, and other temporary structures associated
with a food vehicle, vendor, and temporary merchant shall be subject to
inspection, review and approval by the City Building and Fire Departments.
   11.   Shall be equipped with approved hand-held fire extinguishers. One 10-
pound ABC fire extinguisher is a minimum requirement. If grease laden vapors
are produced, a two and one-half (21/2) gallon Class K fire extinguisher shall
also be required. Additionally, food establishments and food vehicles producing
grease laden vapors shall have a UL 300 listed, Class I hood installed along
with an approved automatic fire suppression system. All Class I hoods shall be
serviced no less than every six (6) months by qualified, licensed inspector.
The fire suppression system shall be inspected and tested annually by a
licensed fire protection system inspector.
   12.   Shall be subject to the temporary sign regulations outlined in section
17.32.038 of this Code. Unsecured menu boards are prohibited. Signs and/or
lettering on the unit shall be produced using professional workmanship without
hand lettering or with a sloppy or garish paint job.
   13.   Issuance of a temporary business license shall not entitle the
licensee to conduct business on any street, sidewalk or other location within
any park, owned or maintained by the City, unless they are part of a special
event and have permission from the event sponsor.
   14.   Issuance of a temporary business license shall entitle the licensee to
conduct business on any privately owned property, excluding residential zones,
provided they satisfy the criteria noted herein and have obtained written
authorization from the property owner.
K.   Revocation: Any license issued under this section may be revoked by the
City Council, after notice and hearing duly given, for any of the following
reasons:
   1.   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in any
application;
   2.   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the
selling or solicitation of any goods, wares, services or merchandise;
   3.   Any other violation of this section;
   4.   Conduct of business by a food vehicle, vendor, temporary merchant, or
solicitor in any other manner in violation of law.
The City Council shall give written notice to the food vehicle, vendor,
temporary merchant, or solicitor of the grounds upon which revocation of
license will be sought and the time, date and place of a hearing before the
City Council where the person or entity holding the license may appear and show
cause, if any they have, why the license should not be revoked.
L.   Enforcement And Penalty:
   1.   Civil Liability: At the direction of the City Council, the City
Attorney shall institute a civil suit in the name of the City of Jerome to
enforce compliance with any of the provisions of this section by suit for
injunction, declaratory relief or other suitable legal theory. The City shall
be entitled to recover attorney fees and costs if it prevails in such civil
action, and such requirement shall be noted on all licenses issued hereunder.
   2.   Misdemeanor: Any person who violates any provisions of this section
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be subject
to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or imprisonment for up to
a period of not more than six (6) months. Each day a violation of this section
occurs shall be deemed a separate misdemeanor. (Ord. 1161, 2017)
CHAPTER 5.10
SKATING RINKS
SECTION:
5.10.010: License Fee
5.10.010: LICENSE FEE:
The person owning or conducting a skating rink within the city shall pay a
license fee of forty dollars ($40.00) per annum, or twelve dollars fifty cents
($12.50) per quarter, payable in advance. (Prior code §11-12)
CHAPTER 5.12
ADVERTISING AND BILLPOSTING
(Rep. by Ord. 894 §1, 2000)
CHAPTER 5.16
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES; LIQUOR 1
SECTION:
5.16.010: Definitions
5.16.020: License; Required
5.16.060: License; Contents; Signature Of Licensee Required
5.16.070: License; Exclusive Use
5.16.080: License; Expiration; Posting Requirement
5.16.090: License; Transferability
5.16.100: License; Location Of Licensed Premises
5.16.110: License; Requirements Of Licensees
5.16.120: License; Qualifications For Obtaining License
5.16.130: License; Revocation And Cancellation
5.16.140: License; Designated For Specific Premises
5.16.150: Licensed Premises; Proper Conduct Required
5.16.160: Licensed Premises; Right Of Entry Of Officers
5.16.170: Hours Of Sale
5.16.180: Restrictions On Sales
5.16.190: Minors On Licensed Premises; Misdemeanor
5.16.200: Public Parks; Consumption Prohibited
 
Notes
1 1. IC title 23; IC §23-916.
5.16.010: DEFINITIONS:
A.   All words and phrases used in this chapter, the definition of which is not
given in this section shall be given the ordinary and commonly understood and
accepted meaning.
B.   For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall
have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
   BARTENDER: Any person, whether agent, servant, employee, licensee, or in any
other capacity, who pours, mixes, prepares, serves or delivers any liquor by
the drink upon any licensed premises.
   INTERDICTED PERSON: A person to whom the sale of liquor is prohibited under
the laws of the state.
   LICENSE: A license issued by the city council.
   LICENSEE: The person to whom a license is issued under the provisions of
this chapter.
   LIQUOR: All kinds of liquor sold by and in a state liquor store of the
state.
   PREMISES: The room in which the sale of liquor by the drink at retail is
authorized under the provisions of this chapter. (Prior code §4-1)
5.16.020: LICENSE; REQUIRED:
The city council at regular or special session shall issue licenses to
qualified applicants, as provided in this chapter whereby the licensee shall be
authorized and permitted to sell liquor by the drink at retail and, upon the
issuance of such license, the licensee therein named shall be authorized to
sell liquor at retail by the drink, but only in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter, and it shall be unlawful to sell liquor by the drink without
having first obtained such license. (Prior code §4-2)
5.16.060: LICENSE; CONTENTS; SIGNATURE OF LICENSEE REQUIRED:
Every license issued under this chapter shall set forth the name of the person
to whom issued, the location by street and number, or other definite
designation, of the premises. If issued to a partnership, the names of the
persons constituting the partnership shall be set forth. If issued to a
corporation or association, the names of the principal officers and the
governing board shall be set forth. Such license shall be signed by the
licensee. (Prior code §4-6)
5.16.070: LICENSE; EXCLUSIVE USE:
Every license issued under the provisions of this chapter is separate and
distinct and no person except the licensee therein named or his or its assignee
shall exercise any of the privileges granted thereunder and all licenses are
applicable only to the premises in respect to which issued. (Prior code §4-7)
5.16.080: LICENSE; EXPIRATION; POSTING REQUIREMENT:
All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire at one o'clock (1:00)
A.M. on August 1, of the year following the issuance of the license. No person
shall be granted more than one license in any one year. Every licensee shall at
all times keep posted, in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises, the
license issued by the city. (Ord. 1199, 4-6-2021: Ord. 627(R), 1980: prior code
§4-8)
5.16.090: LICENSE; TRANSFERABILITY:
A.   Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be transferred
to another qualified person in conformance with the requirements contained
elsewhere in this code. Application for the transfer of any such license shall
be made to the mayor and council and upon receipt of such application the mayor
and council shall make the same investigations and determinations with respect
to the transferee as required elsewhere in this code.
B.   No charge shall be made for the transfer of such license, but, in the
event the city incurs any expense in the course of its investigation of the
proposed transferee, such proposed transferee shall pay the cost incurred in
such investigation. (Ord. 672 §2, 1983: prior code §4-9)
5.16.100: LICENSE; LOCATION OF LICENSED PREMISES:
No license shall be issued for any premises in any neighborhood which is
predominantly residential or within three hundred feet (300') of any public
school, church, or any other place of worship, measured in a straight line to
the nearest entrance to the licensed premises; provided, that this limitation
shall not apply to any duly licensed premises that at the time of licensing did
not come within the restricted area but subsequent to licensing came therein.
(Prior code §4-10)
5.16.110: LICENSE; REQUIREMENTS OF LICENSEES:
Any person seeking a license pursuant to this chapter shall meet all the
requirements for a license as set forth in section 23-910 of the Idaho Code.
Additionally, any applicant for a license under this chapter shall demonstrate
adequately to the city council that if they, at a prior time, held a license
similar to the one authorized by this chapter in any other city, county or
state, that during the period of holding such license, their business was run
in an orderly fashion. The city further reserves the right to make its own
independent evaluation and determination of whether or not the qualifications
for license are met by the applicant, and that any determination by the state,
county or other jurisdiction shall not be binding upon the city. The city
council may, in its discretion, require a licensee to segregate areas within a
licensed premises wherein no alcoholic beverage of any sort may be served,
brought in or possessed. (Ord. 627(S), 1980: prior code §4-11)
5.16.120: LICENSE; QUALIFICATIONS FOR OBTAINING LICENSE:
No person less than nineteen (19) years of age may make application for a
license pursuant to this chapter. Knowing or intentional misrepresentation of
any portion of the application for license under this chapter shall be a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 627(T), 1980: prior code §4-12)
5.16.130: LICENSE; REVOCATION AND CANCELLATION:
The city council may at any time, in compliance with the standards and
procedures as set forth in section 23-933, 23-933A and 23-933B, of the Idaho
Code, and other requirements of this code, revoke, suspend or permanently
cancel any license granted to an applicant under the provisions of this
chapter. A violation of any other section or portion of this code shall be
further grounds for cancellation, suspension or revocation of a license granted
by this chapter, in addition to those grounds set forth in the sections of the
Idaho Code above cited. (Ord. 672 §3, 1983: Ord. 627(U), 1980: prior code §4-
13)
5.16.140: LICENSE; DESIGNATED FOR SPECIFIC PREMISES:
Retailer's licenses, issued pursuant to this chapter shall be granted only for
a certain room or building designated in the license, and the place of business
shall not be changed or moved without the consent of the city council. (Prior
code §4-19)
5.16.150: LICENSED PREMISES; PROPER CONDUCT REQUIRED:
Every licensee, licensed under the terms of this chapter, shall at all times
conduct the licensed premises in a quiet and orderly manner and shall not
permit or allow any boisterous or disorderly conduct in such premises. (Prior
code §4-20)
5.16.160: LICENSED PREMISES; RIGHT OF ENTRY OF OFFICERS:
Any duly authorized police officer of the city shall have the right at any time
to make an examination of the premises of any licensee as to whether the laws
of the state and the provisions of this code and other ordinances of this city
are being complied with. (Prior code §4-21)
5.16.170: HOURS OF SALE:
No liquor shall be sold, offered for sale, or given away upon any licensed
premises during the following hours:
A.   Memorial Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day from one o'clock (1:00)
A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. the following day.
B.   On any other day between one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00)
A.M.
C.   On any day of a general or primary election until after the time when the
polls are closed. (Ord. 1022 §1, 2006: Ord. 902 §1, 2000: prior code §4-22)
5.16.180: RESTRICTIONS ON SALES:
No licensee or his or its employees, agents, servants or bartenders shall sell,
deliver or give away or cause to be sold, delivered or given away any liquor
to:
A.   Any person under the age of twenty one (21) years;
B.   Any person actually, apparently or obviously intoxicated. (Ord. 902 §2,
2000: Ord. 627(V), 1980: prior code §4-23)
5.16.190: MINORS ON LICENSED PREMISES; MISDEMEANOR:
No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall be admitted to premises
licensed under the provisions of this chapter, unless that person is a bona
fide, lawful employee of the business and it shall be a misdemeanor for any
such person to be admitted to or gain admittance to such premises. (Ord. 902
§3, 2000: Ord. 627(W), 1980: prior code §4-24)
5.16.200: PUBLIC PARKS; CONSUMPTION PROHIBITED:
A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to consume, possess, or allow to be
consumed or possessed, any alcoholic beverages within the confines of any
public park within the city limits without prior approval from the city
council.
B.   1. For purposes of this section "alcoholic beverage(s)" shall mean beer,
wine or alcohol as those terms are defined in Idaho Code sections 23-15 and 23-
1001 as those sections now exist or may hereafter be amended.
   2.   The term "city park" shall refer to any public park owned by the city
located within the city limits of the city and shall include, but not be
limited to, those parks commonly referred to as North park, South park, Seasons
park, Camozzi park and Sheppard's park.
   3.   The term "Jerome recreation district park" shall refer to any public
park owned by the Jerome recreation district located within the city limits of
the city and shall include, but not be limited to, Rotary park and Gayle
Forsythe park.
C.   Any person or organization desiring to consume alcoholic beverages within
a city park may do so only from a licensed vendor in valid possession of a
catering permit issued pursuant to the laws of the state of Idaho and the city,
and upon application and permit granted by the city council as follows:
   1.   The application shall contain the following information:
      a.   The name of applicant;
      b.   Place of proposed consumption of alcoholic beverages;
      c.   Day of consumption of alcoholic beverages;
      d.   Hours between which alcoholic beverages will be consumed;
      e.   Name of responsible party for procurement of the alcoholic beverages
to be consumed;
      f.   Written statement that the applicant will permit no one under the
age of twenty one (21) years to consume alcoholic beverages in connection with
the application and that all containers and other refuse will be properly
discarded and the park left clean after the activity.
Every application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable twenty five dollar
($25.00) fee. The full application shall be submitted to the city clerk and
acted on by the council at the next regular council meeting following the
application submittal. The council may reject an application, approve the same,
or impose reasonable conditions on an application including, but not limited
to, the number of persons involved, hours of consumption, crowd control
measures, and the posting of bond for security and other reasons.
D.   Any violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor punished by
fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) or six (6) months'
incarceration in the county jail, or both. (Ord. 981 §1, 2005: Ord. 721 §§1–4,
1990)
CHAPTER 5.20
ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES; BEER 1
SECTION:
5.20.010: Purpose And Interpretation
5.20.020: Definitions
5.20.030: License; Required; State License Prerequisite To Sale
5.20.050: License; Qualifications Of Applicant
5.20.060: License; Issuance To Specific Qualified Location
5.20.070: License; Transferability
5.20.080: License; Expiration
5.20.090: License; Revocation
5.20.100: License; Procedure For Revocation
5.20.110: Regulation Of Sales
5.20.120: Sale, Gift Or Delivery To Minors
5.20.130: Violation; Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. IC §23-1001 et seq.
5.20.010: PURPOSE AND INTERPRETATION:
This chapter shall be deemed an exercise of the police powers of the city, for
the protection of the public health, peace and morals and all of its provisions
shall be liberally construed for the attainment of that purpose. (Prior code
§4-25)
5.20.020: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
   BEER: Shall conform to the definition of the term as it is defined in Idaho
Code sections 23-1001(a) and 23-1002 as those sections now exist or as they may
hereinafter be amended.
   RETAILER: Any person engaged in the sale or distribution of beer to the
consumer. (Ord. 1098, 2012: prior code §4-26)
5.20.030: LICENSE; REQUIRED; STATE LICENSE PREREQUISITE TO SALE:
It shall be unlawful for any retailer to sell or distribute beer within the
city without first having obtained a license as a retailer from the city
council under the provisions of this chapter, and who, before engaging in the
sale or distribution of beer to the consumer, has not first obtained a license
as a retailer under the laws of the state from the commission of the department
of law enforcement of the state. (Prior code §4-27)
5.20.050: LICENSE; QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANT:
The city council may reject any application for a license pursuant to this
chapter, but in no event shall any license for the retail sale or distribution
of beer within the city be granted to the following persons:
A.   Any person not then a bona fide resident of the state and county;
B.   Any person convicted for the violation of any law regulating, governing or
prohibiting the sale of alcoholic beverages or intoxicating liquor during the
last five (5) years;
C.   Any person less than twenty one (21) years of age;
D.   Any person having been previously convicted of a felony or any other crime
involving moral turpitude;
E.   Any person whose room, building or place, for which application for
license is made, has a portion thereof set aside, partitioned or enclosed, made
available or used for the entertainment or amusement of the patrons or
customers of such person, not also open to the public during business hours.
(Ord. 1098, 2012: Ord. 627(Y), 1980: prior code §4-29)
5.20.060: LICENSE; ISSUANCE TO SPECIFIC QUALIFIED LOCATION:
A retailer's license shall be granted only for a certain room, building, or
place designated in the license, which room, building, or place and every
portion thereof shall be well lighted and the view thereof, or any portion
thereof, not obstructed by any curtain, blind, or partition, and the place of
business shall not be changed or moved without the consent of the city council
in regular session. (Prior code §4-30)
5.20.070: LICENSE; TRANSFERABILITY:
A.   Any license issued pursuant to this chapter may be sold, transferred or
assigned to any person having all the qualifications of the original licensee
in compliance with the procedural and substantiative requirements contained
elsewhere in this code. Application to transfer any license issued pursuant to
this chapter shall be made to the mayor and council. Upon receipt of such an
application the mayor and council shall make the same investigation and
determinations with respect to the transferee as are required in the case of
the issuance of the original license, and if the mayor and council shall
determine that all of the conditions required of an original licensee under the
terms of this article have been met by the proposed transferee, then the
license shall be transferred and endorsed over to the proposed transferee by
the licensee for the remainder of the period for which such license has been
issued, and the mayor and council shall endorse their approval of and consent
to such transfer upon such original license and thereafter such transferee
shall have all the rights of the original licensee under the license.
B.   No charge shall be made for the transfer of such license, but, in the
event the city incurs any expense in the course of its investigation of the
proposed transferee, such proposed transferee shall pay the costs incurred in
such investigation.
C.   In case of the receivership, assignment, bankruptcy, or incompetency of
the licensee, the business of the licensee may be carried on under the license
by the duly appointed, qualified and acting receiver, assignee, trustee in
bankruptcy, guardian, executor, or administrator of the licensee; provided,
that such receiver, assignee, trustee, guardian, executor or administrator
shall file with the city clerk a certified copy of his appointment and secure
the written consent of the city council. (Ord. 672 §4, 1983: prior code §4-31)
5.20.080: LICENSE; EXPIRATION:
All licenses issued under this chapter shall terminate at one o'clock (1:00)
A.M. on August 1 of the year following issuance of the license. (Ord. 1199, 4-
6-2021: Ord. 672 §5, 1983: Ord. 627(Z), 1980: prior code §4-32)
5.20.090: LICENSE; REVOCATION:
The license of any person who was eligible for a license under the provisions
of section
5.20.050 of this chapter at the time of the issuance thereof, and during the
period for which such license was issued becomes ineligible therefor under any
provisions of such section, shall be subject to revocation or cancellation
under the provisions of section
5.20.100 of this chapter. (Prior code §4-33)
5.20.100: LICENSE; PROCEDURE FOR REVOCATION:
The right shall be and at all times remain vested in the city council to
revoke, cancel, or suspend the license of any person licensed under this
chapter for any violation of this chapter or violation of any provision of the
Idaho Code title 23. (Ord. 672 §6, 1983: Ord. 627(AA), 1980: prior code §4-34)
5.20.110: REGULATION OF SALES:
A.   Every person to whom a license shall be granted under the terms and
provisions of this chapter:
   1.   Shall at all times conduct a quiet and orderly place of business;
   2.   Shall keep the room, building or site designated in the license, and
all portions thereof open at all times for the inspection of any peace officer
of the city, county, state or United States Of America, and shall give to such
officers or any of them, the right at any and all times to make an inspection
of the licensed premises or any portion thereof, to ascertain whether the
licensee is conforming to the provisions of this chapter, or the laws of the
state or the United States Of America, applicable thereto, and to check the
alcoholic content of any beer being kept for the purpose of sale or
distribution on the premises;
   3.   Shall not conduct on the licensed premises any games, device or table
in violation of the gambling laws of the state;
   4.   Shall not set aside, partition or enclose any portion of the licensed
premises, made available or to the use for the entertainment or amusement of
the patrons or customers of the licensee, not also open to the general public
during business hours;
   5.   Shall not sell any beer to any person under the age of twenty one (21)
years;
   6.   Shall not permit any person under the age of nineteen (19) years to
frequent, loiter in or about, or to patronize any beer dispensary, or to
frequent, loiter in or be employed in such beer dispensary;
   7.   Shall at all times keep posted in a conspicuous place on the licensed
premises all permits or licenses, and shall keep the same so posted for the
full period of which licenses are issued;
   8.   Shall not sell or distribute beer within the city limits between the
hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
B.   The grounds enumerated in this chapter shall constitute bases for the
revocation, suspension, or cancellation of a license issued under this chapter,
in addition to any other grounds appearing elsewhere in this chapter or in the
laws of the state. (Ord. 1098, 2012: Ord. 627(BB), 1980: prior code §4-35)
5.20.120: SALE, GIFT OR DELIVERY TO MINORS:
A.   It shall be unlawful for any person within the city of Jerome to sell,
furnish, deliver or give away beer to any person under the age of twenty one
(21) years.
B.   It is unlawful for any person under the age of nineteen (19) years to
enter or be present in any business establishment which is licensed to sell
beer for consumption on the premises, and it is unlawful for any person to
permit a person under nineteen (19) years of age to enter or be present in the
business establishment licensed to sell beer. Provided, however, that it shall
not be unlawful for a person under nineteen (19) years of age to enter or be
present in a business establishment which is licensed to sell beer for
consumption on the premises, but whose primary business purpose is the sale of
prepared food. (Ord. 1098, 2012: Ord. 627(CC), 1980: prior code §4-36)
5.20.130: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor, punishable by up to
three hundred dollars ($300.00) and/or six (6) months in jail. (Ord. 1098,
2012)
CHAPTER 5.25
RETAIL SALE OF LIQUOR, WINE AND BEER 1
SECTION:
5.25.010: Scope
5.25.020: License Categories
5.25.030: License; Fixing Of Fees
5.25.040: License; Application
5.25.050: License; Application For Renewal
5.25.060: Application; Time For Decision
5.25.070: Application; Evaluation
5.25.080: Application; Decision Of Council
5.25.090: Appeal; Procedure
5.25.100: Appeal; Requirements
 
Notes
1 1. IC §§23-1318, 23-1315.
5.25.010: SCOPE:
This chapter shall apply to any original application, renewal or transfer of a
city license for the retail sale of liquor, wine or beer within the city
limits. (Ord. 672 §7(A), 1983)
5.25.020: LICENSE CATEGORIES:
Licenses shall be issued in the following categories:
A.   Sale of draught, bottles or cans of beer for consumption on premises;
B.   Bottled or canned beer for consumption off premises;
C.   Sale of wine for consumption on premises;
D.   Sale of wine for consumption off premises;
E.   Sale of liquor by the drink on premises. (Ord. 672 §7(B), 1983)
5.25.030: LICENSE; FIXING OF FEES:
The city council shall from time to time by resolution fix a fee for the
original issuance or renewal for each category of license above specified and
shall further fix by resolution a fee for the transfer of any beer, wine or
liquor license. (Ord. 672 §7(C), 1983)
5.25.040: LICENSE; APPLICATION:
Any person or entity seeking an original license under this chapter or seeking
the transfer of such a license must complete an application on a form to be
prescribed by the city council. The application shall be in substantially the
form required by Idaho Code sections 23-1010, 23-905 and 23-1303. Any person
seeking a transfer of a license under this chapter must also complete an
application as though he were the original applicant. (Ord. 672 §7(D), 1983)
5.25.050: LICENSE; APPLICATION FOR RENEWAL:
Any application for renewal of a license issued under this chapter shall be
made by written request for renewal and a statement that all information
provided on the original application of the licensee remains the same. If any
changes have occurred, a full written description of such changes shall
accompany the request for renewal. (Ord. 672 §7(E), 1983)
5.25.060: APPLICATION; TIME FOR DECISION:
Every application for a license or transfer or renewal of the same under this
chapter shall be acted upon by the city council within thirty (30) days of the
submission of a complete application to the clerk of the city. (Ord. 672 §7(F),
1983)
5.25.070: APPLICATION; EVALUATION:
The city council shall evaluate each application made under this chapter.
Standards for evaluation shall be those expressed by any portion of this code
and any relevant portion of the Idaho state code, particularly those portions
in title 23 of the Idaho Code which in any way touch or concern the licensing
and subsequent conduct of establishments for the retail sale of liquor, wine or
beer. (Ord. 672 §7(G), 1983)
5.25.080: APPLICATION; DECISION OF COUNCIL:
The decision of the city council on any application made under this chapter
shall be in writing, and shall specify in addition to what other information
the city may deem proper, and when a denial of the application has been made,
the following:
A.   The statutes, ordinances and standards used in evaluating the application;
B.   The reasons for denial;
C.   The actions, if any, the applicant could take to obtain the license,
transfer or renewal thereof. (Ord. 672 §7(H), 1983)
5.25.090: APPEAL; PROCEDURE:
Any person aggrieved by official decision of the city council under this
chapter may appeal the decision to the city council by filing within fifteen
(15) days of the receipt of written decision of the city council a notice in
writing signed by the aggrieved person and stating in detail the reasons for
which the aggrieved person disputes the original decision of the council.
Thereupon, the written notice shall be filed with the city clerk. Within thirty
(30) days of the receipt of such notice, the city council shall set the matter
for hearing, and advise the aggrieved person of his right to be present at the
hearing. (Ord. 672 §7(I), 1983)
5.25.100: APPEAL; REQUIREMENTS:
A.   Presentation of Evidence: Presentation of evidence on appeal before the
city council under this chapter shall be as follows:
   1.   Petitioner, together with any witnesses supporting his position;
   2.   All persons opposing application or petition;
   3.   Any employee or officer on behalf of the city;
   4.   Rebuttal evidence by petitioner;
   5.   Summation of evidence by petitioner followed by information by no more
than one opponent to the petition;
   6.   Opposing parties shall have the right to cross examine any witness.
B.   Contents Of Evidence: Evidence presented on appeal may consist of
testimonial evidence or any writing, document, exhibit or physical evidence
relevant to the proceeding. All rulings as to relevance shall be made by the
presiding officer at the hearing as hereinafter defined.
C.   Presiding Officer And Duties: The presiding officer at any hearing held
pursuant to this chapter shall be the mayor or in his absence the person
lawfully succeeding to the duties of an absent mayor. All matters presented at
the hearing shall be addressed to the presiding officer. All rules as to
admissibility of evidence shall be made to the presiding officer with the sole
ground of inadmissibility being relevant to the proceedings. Relevance for
purposes of this chapter shall be defined as any matter which tends to prove or
disprove, or immaterial or germane to, any issue lawfully presented to the city
council for its consideration under this chapter.
D.   Witnesses: Any witness presented to the hearing shall first be sworn to
tell the truth upon oath by the city clerk or a deputy city clerk duly
authorized to administer oaths.
E.   Recording: All hearings conducted pursuant to this chapter shall be
recorded by electronic means so as to constitute a transcribable verbatim
record of the proceeding. The record shall be kept by the city clerk
indefinitely. Any person seeking a transcribable record of the proceedings may
receive the same upon request at his expense.
F.   Burden Of Proof: The burden of establishing any matter which is the
substance of petition under this chapter shall at all times be upon the
petitioner. (Ord. 672 §7(J), 1983)
CHAPTER 5.28
TAXICABS
SECTION:
5.28.010: "Taxicab" Defined
5.28.020: License; Required
5.28.030: License; Application; Contents
5.28.040: License; Application; Issuance
5.28.050: License; Fee
5.28.060: License; Revocation And Cancellation
5.28.070: Liability Insurance Requirements
5.28.080: Stands; Designated
5.28.090: Stands; Exclusive Use
5.28.100: Unlawful Acts
5.28.010: "TAXICAB" DEFINED:
The term "taxicab" as used in this chapter means and includes any vehicle held
for public hire using the streets and alleys of the city, carrying passengers
to destinations designated by such passengers without following any fixed
routes and charging therefor upon a time or distance basis. (Prior code §25-1)
5.28.020: LICENSE; REQUIRED:
No person shall carry on, engage in, or pursue the business of operating a
taxicab within the city, without first obtaining a license therefor as provided
in this chapter. (Prior code §25-2)
5.28.030: LICENSE; APPLICATION; CONTENTS:
A.   No person shall engage in the business of operating a taxicab before
applying to the city clerk for the license therefor to engage in and carry on
such a business. Such application shall be verified by the applicant upon forms
to be furnished and provided by the city and shall contain the following:
   1.   The name and address of the applicant; the place of residence of the
applicant;
   2.   The period during which the applicant has resided within the state;
   3.   The intended place of business of the person seeking the license;
   4.   The number of cabs to be operated; the vehicle serial numbers and make
and year of manufacture of each vehicle sought to be operated as a cab;
   5.   If the applicant is a corporation the names and addresses of the
president and secretary thereof, and the date of incorporation shall be given
in addition thereto.
B.   Each application shall be accompanied by the amount of the license fee as
provided elsewhere in this chapter. (Ord. 627(KK), 1980: prior code §25-3)
5.28.040: LICENSE; APPLICATION; ISSUANCE:
Each application for a license under this chapter shall be presented to the
city council and the clerk of the city shall not issue any license therefor
until the same shall have been approved and authorized by the city council. The
license shall be in such a form as may from time to time be determined by the
city council and shall state the date of issuance, the name of the owner and
such other information as may from time to time be required by the city
council. (Ord. 627(JJ), 1980: prior code §25-4)
5.28.050: LICENSE; FEE:
The license fee for each licensee shall be the sum of twenty five dollars
($25.00) per year. Such license shall expire on December 31 following the date
of issuance and must be renewed by January 1 for each following year; provided,
however, that if any license is issued after July 1 in any year, the fee for
such year shall be one-half (1/2) the amount above provided. (Prior code §25-5)
5.28.060: LICENSE; REVOCATION AND CANCELLATION:
The city council shall have the right to revoke and cancel the licenses of any
person licensed pursuant to this chapter for any violation of this chapter, and
upon verified complaint filed with the city council, the city council shall
cause any licensed person to appear before the council and be heard upon such
complaint. A copy of such complaint shall be served with a notice specifying
the date and hour of the hearing, which shall be not less than five (5) days,
nor more than twenty (20) days following the service of such notice. Such
hearing shall be before the city council at its room in the city hall unless a
different place be fixed for such hearing. After such hearing upon the taking
of evidence on behalf of the city and the alleged offender it shall appear to
the city council that cause exists for the cancellation or revocation of such
license. The same may be cancelled and revoked without other or further process
of law, and upon such cancellation or revocation no refund of any unexpired
portion of the license fee shall be made to the licensee. Following such
revocation it shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for such person to thereafter
operate a taxicab in the city until a new license shall have been issued, and
it shall be discretionary with the city council whether or not any person whose
license has been revoked shall be again licensed hereunder. (Prior code §25-6)
5.28.070: LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
A.   Before a license shall be issued to any taxicab under the provisions of
this chapter, the owner shall obtain and file with the city clerk either the
original or a certified copy of a policy of insurance executed by an insurance
agency authorized to do business in this state, insuring the public and any
passenger using such taxicab against any loss or damage that may result to any
person from the operation of such taxicab to the following amounts:
   1.   Property damage, not less than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) per
occurrence;
   2.   Public liability, not less than one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00) for one person; and
   3.   Not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per
occurrence.
B.   Such policy of insurance with certified copies thereof shall be kept on
file in the office of the city clerk, and as such policies are permitted to
lapse for any reason whatsoever, or are cancelled by the insurance company, the
rights theretofore granted shall be forthwith terminated and shall not again
reissue until the owner has obtained and filed with the city clerk an effective
policy of insurance as required. Such policy of insurance shall be available
for public inspection and any person who may have any claim for damages against
any licensed taxicab driver shall be entitled to any information pertaining to
such insurance as disclosed by the files in the office of the city clerk. (Ord.
627(LL), 1980: prior code §25-7)
5.28.080: STANDS; DESIGNATED:
The city council shall designate places on the streets of the city where
taxistands may be located and where taxicabs may be parked, and it shall be the
duty of the chief of police to see that such designated places are properly
marked and it shall be unlawful for any taxicab to park in any other place
except to load or unload passengers. (Prior code §25-8)
5.28.090: STANDS; EXCLUSIVE USE:
Any space designated for the use of taxicabs shall not be used by any other
person for parking any other vehicle, and any person who shall park a vehicle
in a designated taxi space shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code §25-9)
5.28.100: UNLAWFUL ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any operator, owner or employee of an owner or
operator to:
A.   Sell, give away or furnish intoxicating liquors to any other person;
B.   Permit such taxicab to be driven by any person who is not a skilled and
efficient chauffeur thoroughly familiar with the laws of the road of the city
and of the state;
C.   Drive or permit such taxicab to be driven by anyone not holding a valid
chauffeur's license issued by the state;
D.   Employ as an operator or driver any person who has been convicted of
either reckless driving or driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor;
E.   Drive or permit any taxicab to be driven by any person under the influence
of intoxicating liquors;
F.   Operate any taxicab without having insurance coverage as provided in this
chapter;
G.   Use or permit any taxicab to be used for any unlawful or immoral purposes.
(Prior code §25-10)
CHAPTER 5.30
SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES
SECTION:
5.30.010: Intent And Purpose
5.30.020: Application Of Provisions
5.30.030: Definitions
5.30.040: Location And Zoning Restrictions
5.30.043: Intensification Of Nonconforming Use
5.30.050: Business License Required
5.30.051: Application For License
5.30.052: Issuance Of License
5.30.055: Regulation Of Business
5.30.058: Exemption To Business License Requirement
5.30.010: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
A.   Intent: In adopting this chapter, the city of Jerome recognizes that
sexually oriented businesses have some inherently serious and objectionable
operational characteristics, particularly when located near residential
neighborhoods and other sensitive properties and enterprises, or when readily
accessible to minors and other vulnerable adults. Sexually oriented businesses
can have deleterious impact on property values and the quality of life in
surrounding areas.
B.   Purpose: It is the purpose and object of this chapter that the city
establish reasonable and uniform regulations governing the time, place and
manner of operation of sexually oriented businesses and their employees in the
city. The primary purpose of these regulations is to preserve the integrity and
character of residential neighborhoods and other sensitive properties and
enterprises, as well as to protect minor children and other vulnerable adults
from objectionable, operational characteristics of sexually oriented
businesses. This chapter shall be construed to protect the governmental
interests recognized by this chapter in a manner consistent with constitutional
protections provided by the United States and Idaho constitutions.
C.   Intention Not To Create Nuisance: This section is not intended and should
not be construed to create a contemporary community standard nor to allow the
sale, loan, distribution, dissemination, presentation, or exhibition of
material or live conduct which is obscene or which is in violation of any other
law, nor to permit the creation or maintenance of any public, private or moral
nuisance. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.020: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
This chapter imposes regulatory standards and license requirements on certain
business activities, which are characterized as sexually oriented businesses,
and certain employees of those businesses characterized as sexually oriented
business employees. Except where the context or specific provisions require,
this chapter does not supersede or nullify any other related ordinances,
including, but not limited to, those codified in
chapter 9.50 of this code. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.030: DEFINITIONS:
   ADULT BOOKSTORE OR ADULT VIDEO STORE: A commercial establishment that sells
or rents adult material; however, any establishment meeting all the following
criteria shall not be considered an adult video or book store:
   A.   The adult material is accessible only by patrons over twenty one (21)
years of age only after access has been granted or provided by an employee of
the establishment to said patron.
   B.   The individual items of adult material offered for sale and/or rental
comprise less than ten percent (10%) of the individual items publicly displayed
at the establishment as stock in trade in the following categories: videos,
books, magazines, periodicals, other printed matter, slides, other visual
representations, recordings, and other audio matter.
   C.   The establishment does not use the following terms in advertisements or
other promotional activities relating to the adult materials: "XXX", "XX", "X",
or any series of the letter "X" whether or not interspersed with other letters,
figures, or characters; "erotic" or deviations of that word; "adult
entertainment" or similar phrases; "sex" or "sexual acts" or similar phrases;
"nude" or "nudies" or similar phrases; or any other letters, words, or phrases
that promote the purchase or rental of adult material.
   ADULT BOOTH: A separate enclosure within a structure featuring adult
entertainment or adult material. The term adult booth does not include a
restroom or a foyer through which any person can enter or exit the
establishment.
   ADULT BUSINESS: An adult motion picture theater, adult bookstore or adult
video store.
   ADULT ENTERTAINMENT: Any modeling, posing, exhibition, display, or exposure,
of any type, whether through book, pictures, film, displays, live performance,
dance, or modeling, that has as its dominant theme, or is distinguished or
characterized by an emphasis on, any one or more of the following: a) any
actual or simulated specified sexual activities, b) specified anatomical areas,
c) the removal of articles of clothing, or d) appearing nude or seminude.
   ADULT MATERIAL: One or more of the following materials that have as their
primary or dominant theme matter depicting, illustrating, describing or
relating to adult entertainment, regardless of whether it is new or used: a)
books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter; b) photographs, films,
motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, or other visual representations; c)
recordings or other audio matter. The term adult material shall also include
instruments, novelties, devices or paraphernalia that are designed for use in
connection with adult entertainment.
   ADULT MOTION PICTURE THEATER: A commercial establishment which:
   A.   Excludes minors from the showing of two (2) consecutive exhibitions;
repeated showings of any single presentation shall not be considered a
consecutive exhibition; or
   B.   As its principal business, shows, for any form of consideration, films,
motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, or similar photographic reproductions
which are primarily characterized by the depiction or description of "specified
sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas".
   ADULT THEATER: A theater, concert hall, auditorium, or similar commercial
establishment which:
   A.   Holds itself out as such a business; or
   B.   Excludes minors from the showing of two (2) consecutive exhibitions;
repeated performance of the same presentation shall not be considered a
consecutive exhibition; or
   C.   As its principal business, features persons who appear in live
performances in a state of nudity or which are characterized by the exposure of
specified anatomical areas or by specified sexual activities.
   EMPLOY: Hiring an individual to work for pecuniary or any other form of
compensation, whether such person is hired on the payroll of the employer, as
an independent contractor, as an agent, or in any other form of employment
relationship.
   ESCORT: Any person who, for pecuniary compensation, dates, socializes,
visits, consorts with or accompanies or offers to date, consort, socialize,
visit or accompany another or others to or about social affairs, entertainment
or places of amusement, or within any place of public or private resort or any
business or commercial establishment or any private quarters. "Escort" shall
not be construed to include persons who provide business or personal services
such as licensed private nurses, aides for the elderly or handicapped, social
secretaries or similar service personnel whose relationship with their patron
is characterized by a bona fide contractual relationship having a duration of
more than twelve (12) hours and who provide a service not principally
characterized as dating or socializing. "Escort" shall also not be construed to
include persons providing services such as singing telegrams, birthday
greetings or similar activities characterized by appearances in a public place,
contracted for by a party other than the person for whom the service is being
performed and of a duration not longer than one hour.
   ESCORT SERVICE: An individual or entity who, for pecuniary compensation,
furnishes or offers to furnish escorts, or provides or offers to introduce
patrons to escorts.
   ESCORT SERVICE RUNNER: Any third person, not an escort, who, for pecuniary
compensation, acts in the capacity of an agent or broker for an escort service,
escort or patron by contacting or meeting with escort services, escorts or
patrons at any location within the city, whether or not such third person is
employed by such escort service, escort, patron, or by another business, or is
an independent contractor or self-employed.
   NUDE AND SEMINUDE DANCING AGENCY: Any person, agency, firm, corporation,
partnership, or any other entity or individual which furnishes, books or
otherwise engages or offers to furnish, book or otherwise engage the service of
a professional dancer licensed pursuant to this chapter for performance or
appearance at a business licensed for nude entertainment, seminude dancing
bars, or adult theaters.
   NUDE ENTERTAINMENT BUSINESS: A business, including adult theater, where
employees perform or appear in the presence of patrons of the business in a
state of nudity or seminudity. A business shall also be presumed to be a nude
entertainment business if the business holds itself out as such a business.
   NUDITY OR STATE OF NUDITY: The showing of the human male or female genitals,
pubic area or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering; the showing of
the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part of the
nipple; the exposure of any device, costume or covering which gives the
appearance of or simulates the genitals, pubic hair, natal cleft, perineum anal
region or pubic hair region; or the exposure of any device worn as a cover over
the nipples and/or areola of the female breast, which device simulates and
gives the realistic appearance of nipples and/or areola.
   OUTCALL SERVICES: Services of a type performed by a sexually oriented
business employee outside of the premises of the licensed sexually oriented
business, including, but not limited to, escorts, models, dancers and other
similar employees.
   PATRON: Any person who contracts with or employs any escort services or
escort or the customer of any business licensed pursuant to this chapter.
   PECUNIARY COMPENSATION: Any commission, fee, salary, tip, gratuity, hire,
profit, reward, or any other form of consideration.
   PERSON: Any person, unincorporated association, corporation, partnership or
other legal entity.
   PROTECTED ZONING DISTRICTS: Shall include areas zoned as R-1, R-2, R-3, NS,
CBD, as defined in chapter 17.12 of this code.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Includes all outdoor places owned by or open to the general
public, and all buildings and enclosed places owned by or open to the general
public, including such places of entertainment, taverns, restaurants, clubs,
theaters, dance halls, banquet halls, party rooms or halls limited to specific
members, restricted to adults or to patrons invited to attend, whether or not
an admission charge is required.
   SEMINUDE: A state of dress in which opaque clothing covers no more than the
nipple and areola of the female breast, and the male or female genitals, pubic
region and anus shall be fully covered by an opaque covering no narrower than
four inches (4") wide in the front and five inches (5") wide in the back which
shall not taper to less than one inch (1") wide at the narrowest point.
   SEMINUDE DANCING BARS: Any business which permits dancing, modeling, or
other performance or appearance however characterized, in a state of
seminudity.
   SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESS: Nude entertainment businesses, sexually oriented
outcall services, adult businesses, "seminude dancing bars" and seminude
dancing agencies, or any business providing or purporting to provide "adult
entertainment" as defined by this chapter.
   SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESS EMPLOYEES: Those employees who work on the
premises of the sexually oriented business in activities related to the
sexually oriented portion of the business. This includes all managing
