employees, dancers, escorts, models, and other similar employees whether or not
hired as employees, agents or as independent contractors.
Employees shall not include individuals whose work is unrelated to the sexually
oriented portion of the business, such as janitors, bookkeepers and similar
employees. Sexually oriented business employees shall not include cooks,
serving persons, bartenders and similar employees, except where they may be
managers or supervisors of the business. All persons making outcall meetings
under this chapter, including escorts, models, guards, escort runners, drivers,
chauffeurs and other similar employees, shall be considered sexually oriented
business employees.
   SPECIFIED ANATOMICAL AREAS: The human male or female pubic area or anus with
less than a full opaque covering, or the human female breast from the beginning
of the areola, papilla or nipple to the end thereof with less than full opaque
covering.
   SPECIFIED SEXUAL ACTIVITIES:
   A.   Acts of:
      1.   Masturbation,
      2.   Human sexual intercourse,
      3.   Sexual copulation between a person and a beast,
      4.   Fellatio,
      5.   Cunnilingus,
      6.   Bestiality,
      7.   Pederasty,
      8.   Buggery, or
      9.   Any anal copulation between a human male and another human male,
human female, or beast;
   B.   Manipulating, caressing or fondling by any person of:
      1.   The genitals of a human,
      2.   The pubic area of a human,
      3.   The uncovered female nipple and areola;
   C.   Flagellation or torture by or upon a person clad in undergarments, a
mask or bizarre costume, or the condition of being fettered, bound or otherwise
physically restrained on the part of the one so clothed.
   WALKING DISTANCE: One mile, or any such distance that can be traversed at a
normal walking pace within a period of thirty (30) minutes or less.
   ZONING DISTRICTS: Shall include areas zoned as R-1, R-2, R-3, NS, CBD, AB,
M-1, residential overlay zone, RT, and any overlay district as defined in
chapter 17.12 of this code. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.040: LOCATION AND ZONING RESTRICTIONS:
A.   Prohibited Business Locations: It shall be unlawful for any sexually
oriented business to do business at any location within an area zoned R-1, R-2,
R-3, NS, CBD, or RT. Sexually oriented businesses licensed as adult businesses,
nude entertainment businesses, or seminude dancing bars pursuant to this
chapter shall only be allowed in areas zoned for their use.
B.   Special Use Permit: Any sexually oriented business may be located in an
area of the city zoned AB or M-1, but only with a special use permit approved
and issued pursuant to title 17 of this code.
C.   Separation: In recognition of Idaho Code section 67-6533, the following
distance separations shall be required:
   1.   No sexually oriented business shall be allowed within one thousand feet
(1,000') of another existing adult entertainment establishment.
   2.   No sexually oriented business shall be located within two thousand five
hundred feet (2,500') of any of the following:
      a.   Any public or private school;
      b.   Any public library, park, or recreation facility;
      c.   Any licensed daycare, childcare, after school program facility,
whether public or privately operated;
      d.   Any hospital, or any facility used for the treatment or care of the
aging, the physically disabled, the mentally ill, or those addicted to or
dependent on alcohol or other drugs;
      e.   Any correctional or detention facility used by any agency of
government to house those charged with or convicted of any crime;
      f.   Any public or private business that sells alcoholic liquor, beer,
wine, or any spirits;
      g.   Any government owned building or facility open to the general
public;
      h.   Any existing movie theater; or
      i.   Any place generally known to be frequented by minors.
   3.   No sexually oriented business shall be located within five hundred feet
(500') of any existing open space zoning district or zoning district, as
defined herein, within the city of Jerome, Idaho, or the area of city impact.
D.   Prohibitions: Notwithstanding any other provision of this code, it shall
be unlawful for any person, business, association, or enterprise to host,
provide, present, display, sponsor, or promote at any location within the city
limits, any live, adult entertainment, where such entertainment is located
within walking distance of any of the following:
   1.   Any public or private school;
   2.   Any public library, park, or recreation facility;
   3.   Any licensed daycare, childcare, after school program facility, whether
public or privately operated;
   4.   Any hospital, or any facility used for the treatment or care of the
aging, the physically disabled, the mentally ill, or those addicted to or
dependent on alcohol or other drugs;
   5.   Any correctional or detention facility used by any agency of government
to house those charged with or convicted of any crime;
   6.   Any public or private business that sells alcoholic liquor, beer, wine,
or any spirits;
   7.   Any government owned building or facility open to the general public;
or
   8.   Any public place generally known to be frequented by minors.
E.   Evidence Required: The applicant shall provide evidence certified by a
professional land surveyor licensed in the state of Idaho that the proposed
sexually oriented business conforms to the separation requirements of
subsections C and D of this section.
F.   Exterior Display:
   1.   Except as provided in this chapter, all sexually oriented businesses
shall comply with the zoning regulations of title 17 of this code, including,
but not limited to,
chapter 17.32 of this code.
   2.   Any business providing adult entertainment or adult material shall have
in place at each entrance to such business a legible door sign (as defined
herein) stating "Persons under 19 years of age not permitted". The sign shall
be no less than 0.5 square foot and no greater than one square foot in area.
   3.   Sexually oriented business shall have no more than one business or
advertising sign, which sign shall only be permitted on the front facade. Such
sign shall have a surface area of no larger than five percent (5%) of the front
building facade of the first floor elevation (first 10 feet) of the premises
occupied by the licensee, or twenty (20) square feet, whichever is less.
   4.   Any sign or advertisement for any sexually oriented businesses shall
not be posted on any property not designated by the sexually oriented business
license issued under this chapter.
   5.   Signs may be illuminated, but such illumination shall not be by way of
exposed neon, exterior lighting such as spot or flood lights, or any flashing
or animated lights, whether interior to the sign, exterior to the sign, or as a
border to the sign.
   6.   Such advertisements may not contain any graphic words, phrases, or
images describing or showing any specified sexual activities or specified
anatomical areas.
   7.   No sexually oriented business shall, in any manner, advertise, or
permit the observation of any live entertainment, or other adult materials,
depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified
anatomical areas by display, decoration, sign, show window, or other opening
viewable from any public street, alley, sidewalk or other right of way. Such
businesses shall ensure that any window, entrances or other exterior opening be
completely covered so as to be opaque. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.043: INTENSIFICATION OF NONCONFORMING USE:
A.   If a sexually oriented business is or becomes a nonconforming use,
intensification of the use shall be prohibited as follows, and no permit,
approval or other authorization related to such intensification of use shall be
granted:
   1.   For an adult bookstore or adult video store, an increase in the retail
floor or shelf space from which minors are excluded;
   2.   For a nude entertainment business, an adult theater or an adult motion
picture theater, an increase in the occupant load set by the fire department
for the related space or an increase in the number of stages or viewing
screens; and
   3.   For seminude dancing bars, an increase in the occupant load set by the
fire department for the related space or an increase in the number of stages.
B.   A valid, existing sexually oriented business shall not be deemed
nonconforming for purposes of this section as the result of a subsequent
location of a use specified in section
5.30.040 of this chapter. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.050: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to operate a sexually oriented business, as
specified below, without first obtaining a sexually oriented business license.
The business license shall specify the type of business for which it is
obtained. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.051: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
A.   No person less than nineteen (19) years of age may make application for a
license pursuant to this chapter. Knowing or intentional misrepresentation of
any portion of the application for license, or any subsequent report, the
applicant, or applicants, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction thereof, shall be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days or
fined by not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or both.
B.   Prior to the issuance of a sexually oriented business license, the
applicant shall file with the city clerk an application, in writing, signed by
the applicant and containing information and statements relative to the
applicant and the premises (in existence or to be constructed in accordance
with plans and specifications approved by the city) where the sexually oriented
business is to be conducted. The application shall be verified by the affidavit
of the applicant before a person authorized to administer oaths. In addition to
setting forth the qualifications required by other provisions of this chapter,
the applicant must show:
   1.   A detailed description of the premises for which a license is sought,
its location and street address.
   2.   The names and addresses of all persons who will have any financial
interest in any business to be carried on, in or upon the licensed premises,
whether such interest results from open loans, mortgages, conditional sales
contracts, trusts or any other basis other than open trade accounts incurred in
the ordinary course of business, and the amounts of such interest.
   3.   If the premises to be licensed are not owned by the applicant, then a
certified copy of the lease by which he will occupy the premises showing that
the owner consents to existence of a sexually oriented business on such
premises.
   4.   The name and address of the applicant which shall include all members
of a partnership or association, or the officers and members of the governing
board and the principal stockholders of a corporation.
   5.   Proof that the applicant has applied for and been issued a special use
permit from the city to locate the sexually oriented business on the property.
   6.   If, during the period of any license issued hereunder, any change shall
take place in any of the requirements of this section, the licensee shall
forthwith make a verified report of such change to the city clerk.
   7.   Each application shall be accompanied by the required license fee which
shall be returned to the applicant if for any reason the city refuses to issue
the license. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.052: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
A.   The city council shall duly consider and evaluate all new applications and
renewal applications for a license to conduct a sexually oriented business, and
after so evaluating shall determine to grant or deny each application in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
B.   Prior to said determination, new applications shall be submitted to the
Jerome city chief of police for review, and his/her assessment of each
application shall be considered by the city council prior to its decision.
C.   If the city council so orders, the city clerk shall issue a license to the
applicant, which license shall at all times be prominently displayed in the
place of business of the licensee and shall be issued only for the particular
premises therein described.
D.   All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire at one o'clock
(1:00) A.M. on January 1, of the year following the issuance of the license. No
person, partnership, association, enterprise or corporation, shall be granted
more than one license in any one year. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.055: REGULATION OF BUSINESS:
A.   Every person to whom a license shall be granted under the terms and
provisions of this chapter:
   1.   Shall at all times conduct a quiet and orderly place of business;
   2.   Shall keep the room, building or site designated in the license, and
all portions thereof open at all times for the inspection of any peace officer
of the city, county, state or United States of America, and shall give to such
officers or any of them, the right at any and all times to make an inspection
of the licensed premises or any portion thereof, to ascertain whether the
licensee is conforming to the provisions of this chapter, or the laws of the
state or the United States of America, applicable thereto;
   3.   Shall not conduct, allow, sponsor, or promote prostitution, as defined
in Idaho Code sections 18-5601–18-5614;
   4.   Shall not conduct on the licensed premises any games, device or table
in violation of Idaho Code sections 18-3801–18-3810;
   5.   Shall not have any adult booths, or set aside, partition or enclose any
portion of the licensed premises, made available or to the use for the
entertainment or amusement of the patrons or customers of the licensee, not
also open to the general public during business hours;
   6.   Shall not admit any person under the age of nineteen (19) years to any
premises licensed under the provisions of this chapter, a violation of which
shall be a misdemeanor;
   7.   Shall not permit any person under the age of nineteen (19) years to
frequent, loiter in or about, or to patronize any sexually oriented business,
or to frequent, loiter in or be employed in such business;
   8.   Shall, at the licensee's expense, ensure that any person considered for
employment as a sexually oriented business employee is given a physical
examination by a medical doctor currently licensed by the state of Idaho before
employment and that such employee(s) is tested for the presence of sexually
transmitted diseases; and that every sexually oriented business employee, as
defined in this chapter, is similarly examined and tested by a licensed medical
doctor no less than once every six (6) months;
   9.   Shall at all times keep posted in a conspicuous place on the licensed
premises all permits or licenses, and shall keep the same so posted for the
full period of which licenses are issued;
   10.   Shall not authorize, permit, or allow the sale, purchase, possession,
or consumption of any alcoholic beverage or controlled substance in or on the
premises;
   11.   Shall not allow any person actually, apparently or obviously
intoxicated to enter, remain present, or loiter in or on the premises;
   12.   Shall not permit any live, nude or seminude entertainment, nor present
any other adult entertainment within the city limits between the hours of one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) A.M., nor during any period
beginning two (2) hours before and ending two (2) hours after regular public
school hours, regardless of whether school is in session.
B.   The grounds enumerated in this chapter shall constitute bases for the
revocation, suspension, or cancellation of a license issued under this chapter,
in addition to any other grounds appearing elsewhere in this code or in the
laws of the state. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)
5.30.058: EXEMPTION TO BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIREMENT:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any medical doctor or other
healthcare provider licensed by the state to provide bona fide healthcare
diagnosis and treatment. (Ord. 1005 §1, 2006)

6.04.010: KEEPING SWINE IN CITY PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to keep swine within the city, either on his own
premises or on the premises of another. (Prior code §5-1)
6.04.020: ANIMALS AT LARGE OR GRAZING NEAR RESIDENCE OF ANOTHER:
It is unlawful for any person to allow, suffer or permit any cattle, hog,
horse, mule, sheep, turkey, geese, chicken or goat owned by him or under his
control to run at large at any time, in the streets and alleys or public parks
in the city or to stake out such animal in front of or within fifty feet (50')
of the residence of another person for the purpose of grazing such animal.
(Prior code §5-2)
6.04.030: HITCHING ANIMALS TO TREES:
It is unlawful for any person at any time to hitch or to tie any animal to any
tree on any of the streets or alleys within the city. (Prior code §5-3)

6.08.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, and the definition of the term "kennel"
presently found in section 17.08.330 of this code, the following words and
phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section
as follows:
   AT LARGE: Off the premises of the owner and not under the control of the
owner or a member of his immediate family or other authorized agent or employee
either by leash, cord, chain, electronic device or other means. Other means
shall not include voice or verbal commands issued by the dog's handler and/or
owner.
   CONFINED: A dog is "confined" if such dog is securely confined indoors or
confined in a "secure enclosure", as defined in this section.
   DOG: Any member of the animal species Canis familiaris.
   OWNER: Any person owning, keeping, harboring, possessing, exercising control
over, transporting, or selling a dog, whether on a permanent or temporary
basis.
   SECURE ENCLOSURE: One that: a) has secure sides at least eight feet (8')
high, or if all sides are not eight feet (8') high, one that has a secure top;
b) the sides are embedded or buried in the ground not less than one foot (1')
or if not embedded, the enclosure has a bottom permanently attached to the
sides; and c) is constructed of such material and secured in such a manner that
the dog cannot exit the enclosure on its own.
   SECURE TEMPORARY ENCLOSURE: For purposes of this chapter, is a secure
enclosure used for purposes of transporting a dog and which includes a top and
bottom permanently attached to the sides except for a "door" for removal of the
dog. Such enclosure must be of such material, and such door closed and secured
in such a manner, that the dog cannot exit the enclosure on its own.
   SERVICE ANIMAL: A service animal is any dog that is individually trained to
do work or perform tasks for the benefit of an individual with a disability,
including a physical, sensory, psychiatric, intellectual, or other mental
disability. Other species of animals, whether wild or domestic, trained or
untrained, are not considered service animals. A service animal in training is
not a service animal. Any service animal that is found running at large,
barking or howling, or that otherwise disturbs the peace of any person or
neighborhood shall not be considered a service animal, but shall be considered
a dog and shall be dealt with accordingly. A Vicious Dog, as defined by this
code, shall not be considered a service animal.
   VICIOUS DOG: A dog that has bitten, clawed or otherwise harmed, or
constitutes a physical threat, or a dog whose temperament or habits endanger or
menace any person or other animal without provocation by such person or animal.
This term shall not include a dog that bites, attacks or menaces a person or
other animal that has tormented or injured the dog. (Ord. 1197 §1, 2020: Ord.
1016 §1, 2006: Ord. 970 §1, 2005: Ord. 966 §1, 2005: Ord. 885 §1, 2000: prior
code §5-4)
6.08.020: RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED; PENALTY:
A.   It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper of any dog or service animal,
whether or not the same has been licensed, to permit such dog or service
animal, at any time, to run at large within the city.
B.   Any person violating this section shall be served with a uniform citation
signed by an animal control officer, police officer or citizen who has actually
witnessed the occurrence of such violation. Any such violation shall be
punishable pursuant to section
6.08.170 of this chapter.
C.   All dogs or service animals on city rights of way must be on a leash,
cord, chain, electronic device or other means. Other means shall not include
voice or verbal commands issued by the dog's handler and/or owner.
D.   If two (2) or more dogs, belonging to the same "owner", as defined in
section
6.08.010 of this chapter, are found to be running at large in violation of this
section, each dog running at large shall constitute a separate offense, subject
to the enhanced penalties of section
6.08.170 of this chapter. Any service animal running at large shall be
considered a dog and not a service animal. (Ord. 1197 §2, 2020: Ord. 1016 §2,
2006: Ord. 970 §2, 2005: Ord. 841 §1, 1997: Ord. 757 §1, 1993: Ord. 607, 1978:
prior code §5-5)
6.08.030: VICIOUS AND DANGEROUS DOGS:
A.   It shall be a violation of this section for any person to own, keep,
harbor, possess, exercise control over, transport or sell any dog or service
animal whose behavior comes within the definition of a vicious dog, as that
term is defined by section
6.08.010, Jerome Municipal Code. Violations of this section shall be punishable
pursuant to section
6.08.170 of this chapter.
B.   Any dog or service animal whose behavior falls within the definition of a
vicious dog as defined by section
6.08.010, whether found running at large or not, may be impounded for a period
not to exceed fourteen (14) days, the exact length of which time shall be
determined by the chief of police. Any such dog or service animal, found at
large, which cannot be safely taken up or impounded, may be killed by any
police officer or animal control officer of the city.
C.   In any case where a person has been charged or cited with the offense of
owning or having custody of a vicious or dangerous dog or other animal pursuant
to the provisions of this chapter, the city attorney may file a motion
requesting the dog, service animal or other animal be impounded if not already
impounded and may move for the destruction of the animal prior to a final
adjudication of the criminal charges. The animal shall remain confined at the
animal shelter or pound pending a final decision on the motion. The court may
order the destruction of the animal upon making a finding that the animal is
vicious as defined in this chapter, and that it poses a danger to the public if
allowed to be released from confinement.
D.   Any person keeping or owning a dog or service animal taken up or impounded
under this section shall pay to the clerk of the city or any animal control
employee on behalf of the city a sum to be fixed by resolution of the city
council from time to time for confinement after the day the dog or service
animal is taken up. (Ord. 1197 §3, 2020: Ord. 1016 §3, 2006: Ord. 966 §2, 2005:
Ord. 841 §2, 1997: Ord. 757 §2, 1993: Ord. 607, 1978: prior code §5-6)
6.08.035: LIMITATION ON THE NUMBER OF DOGS:
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person or group of
persons, whether related or unrelated, who occupy as their residence the same
parcel or group of parcels, to collectively or individually own, keep, harbor,
possess, exercise control over, transport, or sell more than three (3) dogs at
a time, whether on a permanent or temporary basis. For purposes of this section
service animals as defined herein, owned by a person with a bona-fide
disability and used by said person to perform specific tasks for which the
service animal is trained, shall not count as a dog.
Puppies are an exception to the limitation expressed in this section during the
first six (6) months of the life of the puppy provided said puppies are the
offspring of a dog residing on the same premises as the puppies.
Violations of this section shall be punished pursuant to section
6.08.170 of this chapter. (Ord. 1197 §4, 2020: Ord. 1016 §5, 2006)
6.08.040: LICENSING AND REGISTRATION; GENERALLY:
A.   All dogs, including service animals, harbored or maintained in the city
shall be licensed and registered by their owner. Licenses shall be issued by
the police department, animal shelter or other authorized agent upon payment of
a fee to be set by resolution of the city council. Upon a showing by the
applicant for a dog license that the owner is disabled and the dog is specially
trained to perform specific tasks for the owner, the authorized agent issuing
the license shall indicate in the records of the City of Jerome that the dog is
a service animal.
B.   Every person applying for a dog license shall provide the owner's name,
address, together with the dog's name, breed, color and sex, and shall further
indicate whether the dog has been spayed or neutered. Proof of rabies
vaccination inoculation shall also be provided. (Ord. 1197 §5, 2020: Ord. 885
§3, 2000: Ord. 841 §3, 1997: Ord. 757 §3, 1993: Ord. 607, 1978: prior code §5-
7)
6.08.050: TAG; ISSUANCE AND DURATION:
Upon payment of the license fee, the city shall issue to the owner a license
certificate and a metallic tag for each dog licensed. The licenses shall be
issued in four (4) categories as follows:
A.   A one year license for neutered or spayed animals;
B.   A three (3) year license for neutered or spayed animals;
C.   A one year license for unneutered or unspayed animals;
D.   A three (3) year license for unneutered or unspayed animals. (Ord. 885 §4,
2000: Ord. 841 §4, 1997: Ord. 757 §4, 1993: prior code §5-8)
6.08.060: TAG; ISSUANCE OF DUPLICATE; NONTRANSFERABLE:
Every owner of a dog shall be required to provide each dog with a collar to
which the license tag must be affixed, and shall see that the collar and tag
are constantly worn. In case a dog tag is lost or destroyed, a duplicate will
be issued by the city upon presentation of a receipt showing the payment of the
license fee for the current year and an additional payment of fifty cents
($0.50) for a duplicate. Dog tags shall not be transferable from one dog to
another and no refunds shall be made for any dog license due to death of the
dog or the owner of the animal moving from the city before the expiration of
the license period. (Ord. 885 §5, 2000: Ord. 841 §5, 1997: prior code §5-9)
6.08.070: IMPOUNDMENT; GENERALLY:
A.   There is established a city pound for the impounding and care of stray
dogs, which pound shall be under the jurisdiction of the police department for
the purpose of impounding, keeping and disposing of any dog impounded according
to the provisions of this code.
B.   It is unlawful for any person to hinder or molest any person who may be
lawfully engaged in seizing, keeping or removing any dog in conformity with the
provisions of this chapter.
C.   It shall be the duty of every police officer and animal control officer,
or other designated official to apprehend any dog found running at large within
the city limits and to impound such dog in the city pound or other suitable
place. The city shall cause a registry to be made regarding the breed, color
and sex of any dog impounded and whether or not the animal is licensed. If the
animal is licensed, the name and address of the owner and the number of the
license tag shall be entered. (Ord. 885 §6, 2000: prior code §5-10)
6.08.080: IMPOUNDMENT; OWNER NOTIFICATION; REDEMPTION PROCEDURE AND FEES:
Not later than one day after the impounding of any dog, the owner thereof, if
known, shall be notified by written notice posted for five (5) days at the main
entrance of the Jerome city hall describing the dog and the place and time of
taking. The owner of any dog so impounded may, within five (5) days of the
posting of such notice, reclaim such dog upon payment of the license fees, if
any are unpaid, and of all costs and charges incurred for impounding and
maintenance of the dog. The fees for impounding for dogs shall be fixed from
time to time by resolution of the city council. (Ord. 1091, 2011)
6.08.090: IMPOUNDMENT; DISPOSITION OF UNREDEEMED, UNLICENSED OR INFECTED DOGS:
All dogs impounded under this chapter shall be impounded for a period of at
least five (5) days. If at the expiration of five (5) days from the date of the
posting of notice such dog shall not have been redeemed, it may be destroyed.
Any unlicensed dog required by law to be licensed or any dog which appears to
be suffering from rabies, or mange or other infection or dangerous disease
shall not be released but may be forthwith destroyed by humane means. (Ord.
1021 §1, 2006: Ord. 885 §8, 2000: prior code §5-12)
6.08.095: REDEMPTION WHILE PLACING OF DOGS FROM THE CITY ANIMAL SHELTER, AND
RETRIEVAL OF UNLICENSED DOGS:
The owner of a dog that has been impounded and is not currently licensed, shall
have the dog returned to the owner upon payment of all outstanding shelter
charges and the payment of amounts for rabies immunization and licensing. The
amount of the deposit shall be fixed by a resolution of the mayor and council
of the city. (Ord. 885 §9, 2000)
6.08.100: RABIES CONTROL; MUZZLING REQUIREMENT; IMPOUNDMENT OF UNMUZZLED DOGS:
(Rep. by Ord. 885 §11, 2000)
6.08.110: RABIES CONTROL; DUTY OF OWNER OF SUSPECTED RABID DOG OR DOG BELIEVED
TO HAVE BEEN BITTEN BY RABID DOG:
A.   If a dog is believed to have rabies or has been bitten by a dog suspected
of having rabies, such dog shall be confined by a leash or chain on the owner's
premises and shall be placed under the observation of a veterinarian at the
expense of the owner for a period of two (2) weeks. The owner shall notify the
poundmaster of the fact that his dog has been exposed to rabies and at his
discretion the poundmaster is empowered to have such dog removed from the
owner's premises to a veterinary hospital and there placed under observation
for a period of two (2) weeks at the expense of the owner.
B.   It shall be unlawful for any person knowing or suspecting a dog has rabies
to allow such dog to be taken off his premises or beyond the city without the
written permission of the poundmaster or chief of police. Every owner, or other
person, upon ascertaining a dog is rabid shall immediately notify the
poundmaster or a policeman who shall either remove the dog to the pound or
summarily destroy it.
C.   Any person who owns or keeps a dog six (6) months or older shall cause the
dog to be vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian. Evidence of
vaccination shall consist of a "rabies vaccination and license certificate"
signed by the veterinarian administering the vaccination. A tag must be
attached at all times. A license certificate and license tag for one animal is
not valid for any other animal.
D.   Any nonresident who brings a dog six (6) months of age or older into the
city of Jerome with the intent to reside within the city permanently or
temporarily for a minimum of six (6) months shall obtain the license
certificate and license tag for the dog.
E.   Vaccination is excused only if the owner or keeper can prove that the dog
has been vaccinated against rabies within the past six (6) months by a
veterinarian licensed to practice in any state or if a licensed veterinarian
certifies in writing that a vaccination would be injurious to the animal's
health. In the latter case, the animal shall be kept in an enclosed building or
kennel until the veterinarian can safely vaccinate the animal. (Ord. 970 §3,
2005: prior code §5-14)
6.08.120: EXPIRATION OF DOG LICENSES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor or keep any dog within the city
from and after March 1 of any year, unless such dog is licensed under the
provisions of this chapter for that year. Any violation of this section shall
constitute a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by fine not to exceed an
amount set by the mayor and city council by resolution. (Ord. 841 §7, 1997:
prior code §5-15)
6.08.130: UNLEASHED DOGS ON SCHOOL GROUNDS:
(Rep. by Ord. 885 §11, 2000)
6.08.140: CONFINEMENT OF FEMALE DOGS IN HEAT:
(Rep. by Ord. 885 §11, 2000)
6.08.150: BARKING, HOWLING DOGS:
It is unlawful for any person to own or keep a dog which by loud, continued
and/or frequent barking, or howling shall annoy or disturb any person or
neighborhood. This chapter shall not apply to a dog confined in a dog pound or
veterinary hospital. (Ord. 627(OO), 1980: prior code §5-18)
6.08.160: RIGHT OF ENTRY OF POLICE OR ANIMAL ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
Any police officer or animal enforcement officer duly authorized by the city to
act as such, is authorized to enter the premises of any person when in pursuit
of a dog running at large within the meaning of this chapter. It is unlawful
for any person to refuse access to property to such an officer lawfully engaged
in pursuit of a dog pursuant to this section. (Ord. 627(PP), 1980: prior code
§5-19)
6.08.165: ADOPTION:
Dogs that have not been retrieved by their owners within five (5) days of their
original confinement may be subject to adoption. To qualify for adoption,
animals must be:
A.   In good health;
B.   Not vicious;
C.   Immunized against rabies;
D.   Licensed if the adoptive owner plans on residing in the city of Jerome;
E.   Spayed or neutered.
One adoption fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), which fee may be adjusted from time
to time by resolution of the city council, shall be paid for each animal
adopted. The fee shall pay for spaying or neutering, appropriate vaccinations,
worming, a collar, and a license if the animal is to be kept in the city. (Ord.
1123, 2014)
6.08.170: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
A.   Violations of provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction,
constitute a violation punishable as follows:
   1.   Except as otherwise provided, any person who violates any provision of
Section
6.08.030 shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be
subject to a fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00) plus court
costs and/or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days or by
a combination of such fine and imprisonment.
   2.   Except as otherwise provided, any person who violates any provision of
this chapter, other than a violation of Section
6.08.030, shall, upon conviction, be guilty of an infraction and shall be
subject to a fine in the amount of $72.00, including court costs.
   3.   A second violation of any provision of this chapter, other than a
violation of Section
6.08.030, in a period of twenty four (24) consecutive months shall, upon
conviction, be a misdemeanor subject to a fine of not less than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) and not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus court
costs and/or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days, or
both.
   4.   A third or subsequent violation of any provision of this chapter, other
than a violation of Section
6.08.030, in a period of thirty six (36) consecutive months shall, upon
conviction, be a misdemeanor subject to a fine of not less than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) and not exceeding six hundred dollars ($600.00) plus court
costs and imprisonment for not less than one day and not exceeding ninety (90)
days. (Ord. 1197 §6, 2020: Ord. 1016 §6, 2006: Ord. 966 §3, 2005: Ord. 885 §12,
2000: Ord. 841 §9, 1997: Ord. 627(QQ), 1980: prior code §5-20)
6.08.180: EUTHANASIA FEES:
A.   The owner of any dog given to the city animal control officer to be
destroyed by euthanasia shall be assessed a fee for such services in accordance
with resolution of the mayor and council prior to those services being
performed. (Ord. 841 §10, 1997)
CHAPTER 6.12
PERMIT REQUIRED FOR CERTAIN ANIMALS
SECTION:
6.12.010: Permit; Required
6.12.020: Permit; Application
6.12.030: Permit; Fees
6.12.040: Permit; Grounds For Denial
6.12.050: Exclusions
6.12.060: Violation; Penalty
6.12.010: PERMIT; REQUIRED:
No person, without a valid permit issued pursuant to this chapter, shall own,
possess or maintain under his control within the city limits, any live animal
falling within any of the following groups:
A.   Poisonous reptiles;
B.   Any snake of the constrictor genus exceeding five feet (5') in length;
C.   Any carnivorous mammal, except for domestic dogs and cats. (Ord. 651 §1,
1982)
6.12.020: PERMIT; APPLICATION:
Any person desiring to own, possess or maintain control over one or more of the
animals described in section
 6.12.010 of this chapter shall first make application to the clerk of the city
which application shall clearly state:
A.   The name, address and occupation of the applicant;
B.   Specific description of the animal(s) to be kept;
C.   The location at which the animal(s) will be kept;
D.   The purpose for which the animal(s) will be kept;
E.   The duration for which the animal(s) will be kept;
F.   The type of enclosure or confinement which will be provided for the
protection of the public. (Ord. 651 §2, 1982)
6.12.030: PERMIT; FEES:
A permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per animal shall accompany each
application. An animal renewal fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per animal shall be
paid to the city clerk on January 10 of each year following the issuance of the
original permit. (Ord. 651 §2, 1982)
6.12.040: PERMIT; GROUNDS FOR DENIAL:
The city clerk may deny any application made pursuant to this chapter, or
revoke a permit once issued, for any of the following reasons:
A.   Failure to provide all information required by the application, or to
maintain the animal(s) in accordance with the information contained in the
application;
B.   Inadequate provision for the protection of the public;
C.   Keeping of the animal(s) in violation of any other ordinance of this city
or Jerome County, or a law of the state or the United States of America;
D.   Failure to pay the original or renewal permit fee. (Ord. 651 §3, 1982)
6.12.050: EXCLUSIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to any bona fide educational or scientific
institution keeping said animal(s) for purposes in keeping with educational or
scientific pursuits. (Ord. 651 §4, 1982)
6.12.060: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating the terms of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 651 §5, 1982)

CHAPTER 8.04
