CHAPTER 10.08
BICYCLES
SECTION:
10.08.010: License; Required
10.08.020: License; Not To Be Issued To Other Than Owner Or Person In
Possession
10.08.030: License; Records
10.08.040: License; Plates To Be Attached To Bicycle
10.08.050: License; Fees
10.08.060: License; Permanent Attachment; Stamping Number On Frame
10.08.070: License; Impoundment Pending Investigation Of Proper Licensing
10.08.080: License; Stamping Of Replacement Parts
10.08.090: Transfer Of Ownership And Registration; Fee
10.08.100: Serial Number Attached To Bicycle
10.08.110: Lights Required
10.08.120: Number Of Persons On Machine
10.08.130: Hanging Onto Vehicles
10.08.140: Riding On Sidewalks
10.08.150: Parking In Parking Racks Provided By City
10.08.160: Racing Prohibited; Exception
10.08.170: Obedience To Traffic Laws
10.08.180: Operation Unlawful When
10.08.190: Bicycle Safety Course Requirements; Persons Under The Age Of
Fourteen Years
10.08.200: Bicycle Safety Pledge
10.08.210: Compliance With Stop Signs
10.08.220: Violation Of Sections 10.08.180 Through 10.08.210; Penalty
10.08.010: LICENSE; REQUIRED:
A bicycle owned by anyone other than a dealer in the same wholesale or retail,
must be registered with the city clerk, and be licensed. The chief of police
shall, upon receipt of a proper application therefor, issue a bicycle license
which shall upon issuance be effective for the life of the bicycle. The life of
the bicycle shall be deemed to be the life of the frame which must have the
serial number stamped or attached thereon. Licenses must be applied for within
ten (10) days of the purchase of a bicycle, and if not licensed within ten (10)
days thereafter, the bicycle shall not be used or ridden within the city. Any
bicycle not so licensed is subject to being impounded until proper license is
issued therefor. (Ord. 627(XX), 1980: prior code §15-95)
10.08.020: LICENSE; NOT TO BE ISSUED TO OTHER THAN OWNER OR PERSON IN
POSSESSION:
No license shall be issued for any bicycle when the issuing officer knows, or
has reasonable grounds to believe, that the applicant is not the owner of, or
entitled to the possession of such bicycle. (Prior code §15-96)
10.08.030: LICENSE; RECORDS:
The chief of police shall maintain a record of the number of each license, the
date issued, the name and address of the person to whom it was issued, the make
of the bicycle, the color of the frame thereof, the person of concern from whom
it was purchased, the number on the frame of the bicycle for which such license
shall be issued. All fees collected for such license shall be transmitted to
the city treasurer and deposited in the general fund of the city. (Ord. 627
(YY), 1980: prior code §15-97)
10.08.040: LICENSE; PLATES TO BE ATTACHED TO BICYCLE:
At time of registration, a number plate or metallic sticker shall be assigned
to the bicycle registered; such plate or metallic sticker must be attached to
the bicycle in such a position as to be plainly visible and must at all times
be displayed during the life of the bicycle. (Ord. 690, 1986: prior code §15-
98)
10.08.050: LICENSE; FEES:
Each bicycle owner shall, at the time of applying for a license, pay a fee of
one dollar ($1.00), for each bicycle registered and to which a number plate is
issued. (Prior code §15-99)
10.08.060: LICENSE; PERMANENT ATTACHMENT; STAMPING NUMBER ON FRAME:
The owner, parent or legal guardian of the owner, shall take the bicycle to the
city clerk where the license shall be sealed, riveted, or otherwise permanently
attached thereto. At time of licensing a member of the police department
designated shall stamp or inscribe with an electric pencil or other suitable
tool a number identical to the license number on the frame. (Ord. 627(JJJ),
1980: prior code §15-100)
10.08.070: LICENSE; IMPOUNDMENT PENDING INVESTIGATION OF PROPER LICENSING:
The chief of police shall have the power to order any bicycle impounded which
has a number, other than the license number issued to the bicycle, inscribed or
stamped on any part, while the department conducts an investigation to
determine the ownership of the part. (Ord. 627(KKK), 1980: prior code §15-101)
10.08.080: LICENSE; STAMPING OF REPLACEMENT PARTS:
Any person who purchases a new part to replace a worn or defective part, if
such part is required to be restored, on a bicycle shall have the police
department inscribe or stamp on the replacement part the number issued to the
bicycle on which such part is attached, and shall present proof of ownership of
such replaced part. (Prior code §15-102)
10.08.090: TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP AND REGISTRATION; FEE:
In case of a sale or transfer of a bicycle from one individual to another, the
registration of such bicycle, together with number plate originally assigned
thereto, shall be transferred to the new purchaser or transferee, and the
number plate originally assigned to such bicycle must remain attached thereto.
Each transferee of a bicycle shall within ten (10) days after obtaining title
to such bicycle, notify the police judge of such transfer and shall present
proof of ownership of such bicycle. The police judge shall, upon proof of
ownership, issue a transfer of registration, showing the new owner of such
bicycle. A fee of fifty cents ($0.50) shall be paid to the city for each
transfer of ownership. (Prior code §15-103)
10.08.100: SERIAL NUMBER ATTACHED TO BICYCLE:
No bicycle shall be sold or registered unless it shall have imposed, cut or
impressed on some portion thereof the serial or manufacturer's number. Any
person in possession of a bicycle from which the serial or manufacturers number
is gone, removed or defaced shall apply to the chief of police, who, if he is
satisfied that the bicycle is not stolen, shall issue a number to be stamped on
the bicycle and registered as the serial number therefor. Thereafter, the chief
of police may register the bicycle and issue numbered plates therefor. (Ord.
627(MMM), 1980: prior code §15-105)
10.08.110: LIGHTS REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle upon the streets, alleys or
public places of the city during the nighttime without having the bicycle
equipped with a headlight attached to the front thereof and a reflector at
least one and one-half inches (11/2") in diameter attached to the rear thereof.
The headlight shall have a capacity sufficient to be easily seen a distance of
at least three hundred feet (300') and shall be lighted at all times the
bicycle is ridden upon the streets, alleys or public places of the city during
the nighttime. (Prior code §15-106)
10.08.120: NUMBER OF PERSONS ON MACHINE:
It is unlawful for two (2) or more persons to ride on a bicycle at the same
time, unless such bicycle is manufactured with double sets of saddles, steering
handles and cranks or levers and pedals. (Prior code §15-107)
10.08.130: HANGING ONTO VEHICLES:
It is unlawful for any person riding on a bicycle to take hold of or hang on to
another vehicle for the purpose of being drawn along by such other vehicle. It
is unlawful for any person to permit the rider or operator of a bicycle to take
hold of, or hang on to any vehicle operated by any such person for the purpose
of drawing or towing such bicycle. (Prior code §15-108)
10.08.140: RIDING ON SIDEWALKS:
It is unlawful for any person to ride any bicycle upon any public sidewalk
within the city. (Prior code §15-109)
10.08.150: PARKING IN PARKING RACKS PROVIDED BY CITY:
It is unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any bicycle upon the
streets, alley or sidewalks of the city, except in parking racks to be provided
by the city. (Prior code §15-110)
10.08.160: RACING PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION:
It is unlawful for any person or persons to run or engage in, or cause to be
run or engaged in any bicycle race within the city; provided, however, that
road races may be run and engaged in under supervision and direction of the
chief of police, who is hereby given authority to designate the streets that
may be traversed and used in such road races. (Prior code §15-111)
10.08.170: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC LAWS:
Every person riding a bicycle upon a highway, street or alley within the city
shall be subject to all the rules and regulations applicable to the driver of
any other vehicle, except such rules and regulations which by their very nature
can have no application. (Prior code §15-112)
10.08.180: OPERATION UNLAWFUL WHEN:
It is unlawful for any person to operate a bicycle, or permit another person to
operate a bicycle, within the city limits of Jerome, Idaho, while such person
operating the bicycle is under the age of fourteen (14) years, and without
having completed an authorized bicycle safety course as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 689 §1, 1986)
10.08.190: BICYCLE SAFETY COURSE REQUIREMENTS; PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF
FOURTEEN YEARS:
Every individual under the age of fourteen (14) years shall, prior to operating
a bicycle within the city limits of Jerome, Idaho, take and complete a bicycle
safety course authorized by the city. Each bicycle safety course shall be
administered by a member of the Jerome City policy department, or their
designee, and shall follow the format of the bicycle safety course authorized
by the National Child Safety Council, Jackson, Michigan. The course of
instruction shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
A.   Traffic sign designations and the duties of bicycle operators with respect
thereto;
B.   Duties of bicycle operators with respect to statutes of the state and the
motor vehicle codes;
C.   Prudent safety precautions with respect to bicycle operators and operators
of motor vehicles;
D.   Traffic signaling for bicycle operators;
E.   Required bicycle safety equipment and maintenance and function of bicycle
parts;
F.   Such other safety instructions as may be appropriate. (Ord. 689 §2, 1986)
10.08.200: BICYCLE SAFETY PLEDGE:
Every person successfully completing the required course of instruction shall
be issued a bicycle safety pledge with the name of the person contained
thereon. The card shall be certified by the officer administering the safety
course to the effect that "this bicycle driver has taken the National Child
Safety Council bicycle safety test. In doing so, the driver has met the bicycle
safety test. In doing so, the driver has met the necessary requirements for
safe driving and has agreed to obey the bicycle safety rules listed on the
reverse side of this card." The reverse side of the card shall contain the
following information:
I will... ride single file; keep to the right; look out for cars; never carry a
rider; obey all traffic laws; slow down at all crossings; avoid stunt driving
or showing off; give pedestrians the right-of-way; and keep my bicycle in good
driving condition.
The pledge shall be signed by the individual completing the course. (Ord. 689
§3, 1986)
10.08.210: COMPLIANCE WITH STOP SIGNS:
Every person operating a bicycle within the city shall come to a full and
complete stop at all stop signs on streets within the city and not proceed
until ascertaining that it is safe to do so. (Ord. 689 §4, 1986)
10.08.220: VIOLATION OF SECTIONS 10.08.180 THROUGH 10.08.210; PENALTY:
Every violation of sections
10.08.180 through
10.08.210 of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed thirty
five dollars ($35.00). (Ord. 689 §5, 1986)

CHAPTER 10.16
SPEED LIMITS
SECTION:
10.16.005: Designated; Generally
10.16.010: Designated; Portions Of Streets Adjacent To Public Schools
10.16.020: Section 10.16.010 Effective When
10.16.030: Signing; Public Works Director Duties
10.16.040: Violation Of Section 10.16.010; Infraction
10.16.005: DESIGNATED; GENERALLY:
A.   A maximum speed limit of twenty (20) miles per hour for motor vehicles
traveling upon the following streets or portions of streets within the city of
Jerome, Idaho, is hereby established:
   North Fillmore Street from 4th Avenue Drive to 6th Avenue East
   North Lincoln Avenue from 1010 North Lincoln to Mountain View Drive
   South Lincoln from 423 South Lincoln to 610 South Lincoln
   North Tiger Drive from East Main Street to 4th Avenue Drive
   10th Avenue East from North Fillmore Street to North Tiger Drive
B.   A maximum speed limit of thirty five (35) miles per hour for motor
vehicles traveling upon the following streets or portions of streets within the
city of Jerome, Idaho, is hereby established:
   North Lincoln from Mountain View Drive to 16th Avenue
   South Lincoln from G Street to 2825 South Lincoln
   East Main Street from Cleveland Street to Tiger Drive
   West Main Street from Birch Street to Iron Wood Drive
   East Nez Perce from South Lincoln to South Tiger Drive
   West Nez Perce from South Lincoln to Victory Lane
   South Tiger Drive from East Main Street to East Yakima
   Victory Lane from West Nez Perce Avenue to West Yakima
   100 West Road North from West Main Street to 100 North Road West
C.   A maximum speed limit of forty five (45) miles per hour for motor vehicles
traveling upon the following streets or portions of streets within the city of
Jerome, Idaho, is hereby established:
   South Lincoln from 2825 South Lincoln to East Montana
   West Main Street from Iron Wood Avenue to the boundaries of Interstate 84
D.   All other streets or portions of streets within the corporate boundaries
of the city of Jerome, Idaho, not otherwise described in subsections A through
C of this section shall have a maximum speed limit of twenty five (25) miles
per hour. (Ord. 1090, 2011)
10.16.010: DESIGNATED; PORTIONS OF STREETS ADJACENT TO PUBLIC SCHOOLS:
It is unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle at more than twenty
(20) miles per hour between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and four
o'clock (4:00) P.M. on the following portions of streets within the city
limits:
A.   North Lincoln Street between the midpoint of the 200 block and the
midpoint of the 500 block;
B.   North Fillmore Street, from its intersection with Fourth Avenue to its
intersection with Eighth Avenue. (Ord. 693 §1, 1986)
10.16.020: SECTION 10.16.010 EFFECTIVE WHEN:
The speed limits provided by this chapter shall be effective only on such days
public schools are in session. When the public schools are not in session, the
previous posted speed of twenty five (25) miles per hour shall constitute the
speed limit on the above described portions of streets. (Ord. 693 §2, 1986)
10.16.030: SIGNING; PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR DUTIES:
The reduced speed limit, and portions of streets to which the speed limit
applies, shall be designated by appropriate signing, under the direction of the
public works director, consistent with the standards and regulations of the
state. (Ord. 693 §3, 1986)
10.16.040: VIOLATION OF SECTION 10.16.010; INFRACTION:
A violation of the prohibition of section
10.16.010 of this chapter shall be an infraction within the meaning of Idaho
Code 49-3401(3). (Ord. 693 §4, 1986)
CHAPTER 10.20
TRUCKS
SECTION:
10.20.010: Definitions
10.20.020: Parking Unlawful When
10.20.030: Owner Responsibilities
10.20.040: Violation
10.20.010: DEFINITIONS:
   For purposes of this chapter, the words “truck”, “semitrailer” and “truck-
tractor” shall be as defined in Idaho Code 49-121 as said sections now exist
and as they may hereafter be amended.
(Ord. 1232, 9-17-2024: Ord. 1162, 2017)
10.20.020: PARKING UNLAWFUL WHEN:
   It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stand, or to allow to be
parked or stood, on any street or alley within the City of Jerome,. Any truck,
semi-trailer, semi-tractor, or semi-tractor/trailer falling in any of the
categories following:
   A.   Any truck with a gross vehicle weight in excess of 8,000 pounds;
   B.   Any truck or semi-trailer, whether considered separately or when
connected, which exceeds more than twenty-two feet (22') in length;
   C.   Any semi-trailer;
   D.   Any truck-tractor, whether stood or stopped.
   Exception: while in the actual process of loading or unloading a truck and
semi-trailer may park.
(Ord. 1323, 9-17-2024: Ord. 1162, 2017)
10.20.030: OWNER RESPONSIBILITIES:
   The registered owner of the truck, semi-trailer, semi-tractor, or semi-
tractor/trailer shall be presumed to be in control of the equipment found to be
in violation of this chapter, and subject to the penalty therefor. Provided,
however, that no such presumption shall apply where the owner demonstrates the
equipment illegally parked was placed there without the consent, express or
implied, of the owner. Any business that willfully allows the registered owner
and/or themselves parks or stands any truck, semi-trailer, semi-tractor, or
semi-tractor/trailer shall be in violation of this chapter and subject to the
penalty therefor.
(Ord. 1323, 9-17-2024: Ord. 1162, 2017)
10.20.040: VIOLATION:
   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this chapter shall be
deemed guilty of an infraction and shall pay a fine of one-hundred dollars
($100.00). Any person found guilty of a subsequent violation within a twelve
(12) month period, shall be subject to a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00).
Any person found guilty of a third violation in any twelve (12) month period
shall be subject to a fine of three hundred dollars ($300.00). Any violations
of this code by a business shall be found guilty and pay the fines as stated
above regardless of the registered truck owner.
(Ord. 1323, 9-17-2024: Ord. 1162, 2017)
CHAPTER 10.24
MOTOR VEHICLES AND SOUND PRODUCTION DEVICES
(Rep. by Ord. 1012 §1, 2006)
CHAPTER 10.28
OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES ON PUBLIC PROPERTY
SECTION:
10.28.010: Definitions
10.28.020: Prohibited Areas Of Operation
10.28.030: Violations; Penalties
10.28.040: Vehicles In Excess Of Twenty Two Feet
10.28.010: DEFINITIONS:
Unless a different meaning is apparent from the context or is specified
elsewhere in this code, the following definitions shall be used:
   HIGHWAY: A way or place of whatever nature, publicly maintained and open to
the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. "Highway" includes
streets and roads.
   MOTOR VEHICLES: A motor vehicle as defined by Idaho Code section 49-123(g)
as it now exists or may hereafter be amended.
   UNIMPROVED PRIVATE PROPERTY: Under this chapter means any parcel of land
under common ownership which contains no buildings or which is not surfaced
with cement, concrete, asphaltic concrete or other similar material, or which
does not have a hard surface made up of a mixture of rock, sand or gravel bound
together with a chemical or mineral substance other than natural soil. (Ord.
769 §1, 1994)
10.28.020: PROHIBITED AREAS OF OPERATION:
A.   No person shall operate a motor vehicle, other than a publicly owned motor
vehicle, upon any public sidewalk, walkway, parkway or in any public park or
recreational area or upon any other publicly owned property, except highways,
within the city.
This shall not be construed to prohibit the operation of a motor vehicle having
a valid Idaho vehicle registration by any person possessing a valid Idaho
operator's license upon the public highways in the city.
B.   No person shall operate a motor vehicle, other than a publicly owned motor
vehicle, upon any unimproved private property within the city. (Ord. 769 §2,
1994)
10.28.030: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 769 §3, 1994)
10.28.040: VEHICLES IN EXCESS OF TWENTY TWO FEET:
A.   Prohibited Turns: It shall be unlawful for a motor vehicle or combination
of motor vehicle and attached vehicles, as both terms are presently defined in
Idaho Code section 49-123(2), as the same now exists or as it may hereafter be
amended, in excess of twenty two feet (22') in total length to make any turn at
the intersection of Main and Lincoln Streets within the city of Jerome, Idaho.
B.   Truck Route: Any motor vehicle, or combination of a motor vehicle and
attached vehicles in excess of twenty two feet (22') in total length shall, in
lieu of making a turn at the intersection of Main and Lincoln Streets within
the city of Jerome, Idaho, travel on the city of Jerome truck route, which
truck route is hereby designated as follows:
   1.   Heading southbound on Lincoln Street, turn right onto West Avenue D;
then right onto South Birch Street; and then proceed northbound to West Main
Street.
   2.   Heading northbound on Lincoln Street, turn left onto West Avenue D;
then right onto South Birch Street; and then proceed northbound to West Main
Street.
   3.   Heading eastbound on Main Street, turn right onto South Birch Street;
then left onto West Avenue D; and then proceed eastbound to South Lincoln
Street.
   4.   Heading westbound on Main Street, turn left onto South Birch Street;
then left onto West Avenue D; and then proceed eastbound to South Lincoln
Street.
C.   Residential Zones: It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle or any
combination of a motor vehicle and attached vehicles in excess of twenty two
feet (22') in total length, to park on or travel on any street of any area of
the city of Jerome zoned R-1, R-2, or R-3.
D.   Exemptions: A motor vehicle or a combination of a motor vehicle and
attached vehicles in excess of twenty two feet (22') or more in total length
shall be exempt from the provisions of this section as follows:
   1.   Any motor vehicle or combination of a motor vehicle and attached
vehicles of more than twenty two feet (22') in total length which travels on
Main Street or Lincoln Street in the city of Jerome without making a turn of
any kind at the intersection of Main and Lincoln Streets shall be exempt from
subsection A of this section.
   2.   Any motor vehicle or combination of a motor vehicle and attached
vehicles in excess of twenty two feet (22') in total length which is making a
delivery of goods or services to a residence or owners of a residence in an
area within the city of Jerome zoned R-1, R-2 or R-3 shall be exempt from
subsection C of this section.
   3.   An authorized emergency vehicle as that term is defined at Idaho Code
section 49-123(2)(b) as it now exists or as it may hereafter be amended shall
be exempt from this section.
E.   Penalties: Any person operating or parking a motor vehicle or combination
of a motor vehicle and attached vehicles in excess of twenty two feet (22') in
total length in violation of this section shall be guilty of an infraction
punishable by a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). (Ord. 1057 §§1, 2,
3, 4, 5, 2008)

RESERVED
TITLE 12

CHAPTER 12.04
CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR OF SIDEWALKS 1
SECTION:
12.04.010: Materials And Specifications
12.04.020: Construction; When Required
12.04.030: Construction; Notice To Abutting Owner
12.04.040: Construction; By City Upon Failure Of Abutting Owner; Collection Of
Costs
 
Notes
1 1. IC §50-311 et seq.
1 1. IC §50-316.
12.04.010: MATERIALS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
Sidewalks, curbs, crosswalks and driveways within the city shall be of
concrete, of such dimensions and thickness and constructed according to such
official plans and specifications as from time to time may be adopted by order
of the city council and filed with the city clerk. (Prior code §24-2)
12.04.020: CONSTRUCTION; WHEN REQUIRED:
The mayor and city council may, at any regular meeting, or at any special
meeting called for that purpose, by a vote of three- fourths (3/4) of the
members of the city council or by a vote of a majority of the council upon a
petition of three-fourths (3/4) of the property owners of not less than one
side of a block, by an order entered upon the minutes of such meeting, direct
the construction of sidewalks on any street, block or part of a block, within
the city, assessing the cost thereof to the property in front of which the same
shall be paid, and may direct the owner thereof to lay the same at his own
expense. (Prior code §24-17)
12.04.030: CONSTRUCTION; NOTICE TO ABUTTING OWNER:
Whenever the mayor and city council shall order any sidewalk constructed, as
provided in section
12.04.020 of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the city engineer within
five (5) days after the passage of such order, to serve a written or printed
notice to construct such sidewalks within thirty (30) days upon the owner or
his agent of all of the property in front of which such sidewalk has been
ordered laid. If the owner resides out of the city and his address is known,
such notice shall be sent by registered mail, and if he cannot be found, and
his address is unknown, such notice shall be published at least once a week for
two (2) consecutive weeks in a newspaper published in the city. (Prior code
§24-18)
12.04.040: CONSTRUCTION; BY CITY UPON FAILURE OF ABUTTING OWNER; COLLECTION OF
COSTS:
If, within thirty (30) days after serving of such notice, or after the first
publication, if the address of the owner is not known, or if he cannot be
found, the owner fails and neglects to construct such sidewalk in front of his
property as ordered, such sidewalk may be constructed by the city, under the
direction of the city engineer, who shall keep an account of the construction
of such sidewalk, and the cost thereof, in front of each lot or part of lot,
and after the same has been completed he shall present to the city council a
detailed statement of the cost thereof and the amount assessed against the
property owned by each person in front of whose property such sidewalk shall
have been constructed by the city, and after such account shall have been
approved by the city council, if not paid by the owner within ten (10) days
thereafter, the same shall be and constitute a lien against such property in
favor of the city, and shall be recoverable, together with all costs as
provided by law, for the foreclosure of liens. (Prior code §24-19)
CHAPTER 12.08
GRADES AND CURB LINES
SECTION:
12.08.010: Base Point Established
12.08.020: Grades To Be Measured From Base Point
12.08.030: Adoption Of Grade And Grade Elevation Map
12.08.040: Curb Lines Established Generally
12.08.050: Grades And Curb Lines In Bremer Addition
12.08.060: Sidewalk Slopes
12.08.010: BASE POINT ESTABLISHED:
For the purpose of establishing grades in the streets, avenues, alleys and
block intersections in the city, the following named point shall be taken as a
base, or starting point: The top of west anchor bolt on the southwest pier of
the city water tower as now located, the elevation of such point being 3,776.21
feet above sea level. (Prior code §24-11)
12.08.020: GRADES TO BE MEASURED FROM BASE POINT:
Whenever any point is given by numbers as a grade point, it shall mean the
number of feet and hundredths of a foot above the datum plane as compared with
the elevation of the base established by section
12.08.010 of this chapter, and the grade of any street, avenue, alley or block
intersection of the city, between grade points as established in this chapter,
shall be a plane between such points. (Prior code §24-12)
12.08.030: ADOPTION OF GRADE AND GRADE ELEVATION MAP:
The grades and grade elevations of streets, avenues, sidewalks and alleys
within the city, shown by map of L. C. Kelsey, civil engineer, entitled
"Jerome, Idaho map showing established grades, 1918", on file in the office of
the city clerk, are made the established grades and grade elevations of such
streets, avenues, sidewalks and alleys, and such map is adopted as an
authorized grade and grade elevation map of the city. (Prior code §24-13)
12.08.040: CURB LINES ESTABLISHED GENERALLY:
Curb lines within the territory shown in the map referred to in section
12.08.030 of this chapter shall be the distances from the property lines shown
by such map, except that the curb lines on Avenue A and First Avenue from
Cherry Street to Elm Street and on Lincoln Avenue from the south city limits to
the north city limits shall be sixty feet (60') from curb to curb, being thirty
feet (30') on each side of the centerline of the street. (Prior code §24-14)
12.08.050: GRADES AND CURB LINES IN BREMER ADDITION:
Sidewalks and curbs laid and constructed prior to January 1, 1939, on the
portion of the city included within Bremer Subdivision of Jerome Townsite shall
be deemed laid and constructed to authorized grades and at authorized distances
from the property lines. (Prior code §24-15)
12.08.060: SIDEWALK SLOPES:
The grades given in this chapter shall be the grade of the top of the sidewalks
at their inner edges when the latter are on the block lines or not more than
two feet (2') out therefrom. When the inner edge of the sidewalk is more than
two feet (2') out from the block lines, the elevation of top of the inner edge
of walk shall be determined by subtracting from the established grade at the
block line, an amount equal to the amount of fall from the block line to the
inner edge of sidewalk, which shall be at the rate of one-fourth inch (1/4")
per foot from the block line to the outer edge of curb. (Prior code §24-16)
CHAPTER 12.12
STREET NUMBERING 1
SECTION:
12.12.010: Purpose
12.12.020: Supervision
12.12.030: Initial Point Of Numbering
12.12.040: Manner Of Using Even And Odd Numbers
12.12.050: Block Numbers
12.12.060: Frontage
12.12.070: Numbers To Be Of Uniform Size
12.12.080: Diagonal Streets
12.12.090: Unextended Streets
12.12.100: Owner Required To Affix Number
12.12.110: Violation; Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. IC §50-318.
12.12.010: PURPOSE:
A.   The purpose of this plan for numbering of residences and business houses
within the city is to establish a uniform and orderly system through which the
locating of any residence or business may be expedited.
B.   It is not the purpose of this chapter to change the existing numbers given
to residences or businesses to conform with the footage numbering system
established by this chapter; however, it is the purpose of this chapter that
all residences and businesses within a block shall conform with the one hundred
(100) numbers assigned to the block, as shown on the official plat; and that
there shall not be two (2) residences within the same block with identical
numbering. The official plat in this chapter referred to is a plat prepared by
the city engineer for the purposes of this chapter and is on file in the office
of city clerk, which plat is adopted for such purposes. (Prior code §24-24)
12.12.020: SUPERVISION:
The mayor and city council, or other persons designated by the mayor and city
council, are hereby given the exclusive right to determine the building numbers
as provided for in this chapter. Such numbering shall be placed on the front of
residences and other buildings and mayor and council shall determine what
constitutes the front of any such residence or other building. (Prior code §24-
25)
12.12.030: INITIAL POINT OF NUMBERING:
The initial point of numbering shall be the intersection of the centerlines of
Main Street and Lincoln Avenue. The baselines shall be Main Street and Lincoln
Avenue. (Prior code §24-26)
12.12.040: MANNER OF USING EVEN AND ODD NUMBERS:
On streets running east and west, even numbers shall be on the north side of
the streets and odd numbers shall be on the south side of the streets. On
streets running north and south, odd numbers shall be on the west side of the
streets and even numbers shall be on the east side of the streets. (Prior code
§24-27)
12.12.050: BLOCK NUMBERS:
Each block shall be numbered by hundreds beginning with 100 at Main Street on
streets running east and west, the second block beginning with 200 and so on,
and the same system on Lincoln Avenue running north and south. (Prior code §24-
28)
12.12.060: FRONTAGE:
A.   In numbering houses in the city, one whole number shall be allowed on
every twenty five feet (25') of property wherever practicable. In numbering
business houses, one whole number shall be allowed on every twelve and one-half
feet (121/2') of property wherever practicable. The number given to the house
or the business shall be determined by the actual increment measurement to the
entrance door of the building and the number given shall in all cases be
determined by the mayor and the city council.
B.   On a large commercial building of two (2) or more stories, one basic
number shall be issued for each office within the building.
C.   In residential areas where three- or more plex apartment units are
available, one basic number shall be issued for the apartment unit and each
apartment shall be issued a letter of the alphabet. (Prior code §24-29)
12.12.070: NUMBERS TO BE OF UNIFORM SIZE:
All numbers used in numbering of houses or businesses under this chapter shall
not be less than three inches (3") in height and all figures making such number
shall be uniform in size, style and composition. (Prior code §24-32)
12.12.080: DIAGONAL STREETS:
All buildings and lots on diagonal streets shall be numbered the same as the
north and south streets if the diagonal runs more from north to the south, and
the same of east and west streets if the diagonal runs more from the east to
the west. (Prior code §24-30)
12.12.090: UNEXTENDED STREETS:
All streets not extending through to the baseline shall be assigned the same
relative numbers as if the street extended to the baselines. (Prior code §24-
31)
12.12.100: OWNER REQUIRED TO AFFIX NUMBER:
It shall be the duty of the property owner or person in charge of any house or
place of business having entrance from any street in this city to number the
same in the manner provided by this chapter within ninety (90) days after
notice in writing has been served upon him by the city. (Prior code §24-33)
12.12.110: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any owner, agent or person having control of such dwellings or business houses
in the city who shall fail, neglect or refuse to number or keep and maintain on
such dwelling, house or business a number as herein provided, or shall fail,
neglect or refuse to comply with any such provisions of this chapter, shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction therefor, shall be fined in
any sum not to exceed twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Prior code §24-34)
CHAPTER 12.16
CUTTING AND EXCAVATION
SECTION:
12.16.010: Permit To Excavate Or Cut Public Curbs, Streets, Or Pathways;
Required
12.16.020: Permit Application
12.16.030: Permit Issuance
12.16.040: Fees
12.16.050: Action On Application For Permit; Appeal
12.16.060: Definition Of Public Pathway
12.16.070: Penalty
12.16.010: PERMIT TO EXCAVATE OR CUT PUBLIC CURBS, STREETS, OR PATHWAYS;
REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut or in any way demolish any public
curb, sidewalk, street or pathway, or to perform any excavation within any
public street or right of way without first obtaining a permit therefor from
the city's building official, as defined in the latest edition of the
international building code adopted by the city of Jerome, as it now exists or
as it may hereafter be amended. (Ord. 1062 §2, 2009)
12.16.020: PERMIT APPLICATION:
Applications for any permit required by section
12.16.010 of this chapter shall be made in writing on such forms as prescribed
by the city, and shall include, in addition to whatever other information the
city may require, the location, character, extent and purpose of the work for
which the permit is sought. The application shall be submitted to the building
official. (Ord. 1062 §2, 2009)
12.16.030: PERMIT ISSUANCE:
A.   Every submitted application shall be reviewed by the building official,
who shall determine whether or not to grant the application. In determining
whether or not an application shall be deemed to be within the public interest
and subject to approval, the building official shall consider the following
factors:
   1.   Whether the action proposed by the application would benefit adjacent
real property;
   2.   Whether the work proposed in the application would result in
irreparable damage to a public street, alley or pathway;
   3.   Whether the work proposed would irreparably endanger existing public
water, sewer, or other public improvements;
   4.   Whether the work proposed would unduly hamper or impede the passage of
traffic or persons on a public street, alley or pathway;
   5.   Any other factor which may be presented to the building official, which
may impact upon the general health, safety and well being of the citizens of
Jerome.
B.   Any permit issued by the building official shall, among such other
reasonable conditions as may be imposed by the building official, require the
applicant to backfill, repave, or reinstall any curb, sidewalk or street
disturbed as a result of the work, in keeping with city standards and
specifications, to the satisfaction of the city. The building official shall
inspect all backfill, repaving, or reconstruction as required and give approval
of such activity, in writing, before it shall be deemed accepted by the city.
(Ord. 1062 §2, 2009)
12.16.040: FEES:
Every application under this chapter shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable
fee, the amount of which shall be determined by the council by resolution in
effect at the time the application is submitted. (Ord. 1062 §2, 2009)
12.16.050: ACTION ON APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; APPEAL:
The building official shall issue a permit for every completed, approved
application accompanied by the proper permit fee, within fifteen (15) calendar
days of its submittal to the building official. Should the application be
denied, the applicant may appeal such decision to the council by filing a
notice of appeal in writing setting forth all grounds for the appeal which
written notice of appeal must be filed with the Jerome city clerk within ten
(10) days of the date upon which the written notice of denial of the
application is mailed by the building official to the applicant at the address
provided by the applicant. (Ord. 1062 §2, 2009)
12.16.060: DEFINITION OF PUBLIC PATHWAY:
For purposes of this chapter, the term "public pathway" shall mean any bike
path, hiking path, or any other similar path which is publicly owned and
intended for pedestrian and/or bicycle use by the public. The term shall
include all existing bike paths owned by the Jerome recreation district and
such additional bike paths as may be established by the Jerome recreation
district in the future. (Ord. 1062 §2, 2009)
12.16.070: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. (Ord. 1062 §2, 2009)
CHAPTER 12.20
OBSTRUCTIONS AND FOREIGN MATTER IN STREETS 1

12.20.010: ALLOWING IRRIGATION WATER TO BE RUN UPON STREET:
No person shall run, or permit to be run, into or upon any public street,
boulevard or avenue within the city, any irrigation water used by such person,
and when such water is run into or upon such street, boulevard or avenue as the
result of the wilfulness or negligence of such person, the same shall
constitute a misdemeanor. (Prior code §24-1)
12.20.020: OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS; GENERALLY:
A.   In General: "Obstruction of streets and sidewalks generally" shall mean:
   1.   Obstruction Of Street Or Sidewalk Prohibited: It is unlawful for any
person to place or leave or permit to be placed or left in any street, or
sidewalk, or alley, any wagon, cart, dray, barrow, handcart, sleigh or other
vehicle, or any lumber, wood, timber or any other article or thing whatsoever,
in such a manner as to obstruct or interfere in any manner with the public use
of any street or sidewalk.
   2.   Parking Of Trailer, Motor Home Or Boat Transporter: It is unlawful for
any person to place, leave, or permit to be placed or left in any street any
trailer, motor home or boat transporter for more than seventy two (72)
consecutive hours.
   3.   Exception: Any "speed trailer", "reader board", "display board" or
public safety device used for law enforcement or prevention purposes is
excepted from the prohibited conduct set forth above.
B.   Definitions: For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and
phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
   MOTOR HOME: A vehicular unit designed to provide temporary living quarters,
built into an integral part of or permanently attached to a self-propelled
motor vehicle chassis.
   TRAILER:
   1.   Generally: Every vehicle without motive power designed to carry persons
or property and for being drawn by motor vehicle.
   2.   Fifth Wheel Trailer: A vehicular unit equipped in the same manner as a
travel trailer, but constructed with a raised forward section that allows a
bilevel floor plan. This style is designed to be towed by a vehicle equipped
with a device known as a fifth wheel hitch, which is typically installed in the
bed of a pickup truck.
   3.   Fold Down Camping Trailer: A vehicular portable unit mounted on wheels
and constructed with collapsible partial side walls, which fold for towing by
another vehicle and unfold at the campsite to provide temporary living
quarters, for recreational, camping or travel use.
   4.   Park Trailer: A trailer designed to be towed by a motorized vehicle,
and of such size and weight as not to require special highway movement permit.
It is designed for seasonal or temporary living quarters and may be connected
to utilities necessary for operation of installed fixtures and appliances. It
is hooked on a single permanent chassis and constructed to permit setup by
persons without special skills.
   5.   Pull Trailer: Every vehicle without motive power designed to be drawn
by another vehicle and attached to the towing vehicle by means of a reach or
pull or by being boomed or otherwise secured to the towing vehicle, and
ordinarily used for transporting long or irregularly shaped loads such as
poles, pipes, or structured members capable, generally, of sustaining
themselves as beams between the supporting connections.
   6.   Semitrailer: Every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying
persons or property and for being drawn by motor vehicle and so constructed
that some part of its weight and that of its load rests upon or is carried by
the towing vehicle.
   7.   Travel Trailer: A vehicular unit, mounted on wheels, designed to
provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel or
emergency use and of such size or weight as not to require special highway
movement permits when towed by a motorized vehicle.
   8.   Utility Trailer: Every trailer or semitrailer designed primarily to be
drawn behind a passenger car or pickup truck for domestic and utility purposes.
Utility or domestic use shall include a farm trailer while being used to haul
agricultural products or livestock from farm to storage, market, or processing
plant, or returning therefrom.
   9.   Speed Trailer, Reader Board, Display Board Or Other Public Safety
Device: A "utility trailer", cart, or other public safety device owned and/or
used by law enforcement or a public agency which is equipped with a device
capable of measuring and displaying in large digits the speed of oncoming
traffic. Reader boards or display boards are owned by a public agency to make
public service announcements.
   TRANSPORTER: Any vehicle combination designed and used specifically to
transport assembled boats and boat hulls.
C.   Violation; Penalty: Any person who violates a term or provision of this
section should be guilty of an infraction punishable by a fine of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) including court costs and fees. Each and every day the
violation continues shall be a separate and distinct violation. (Ord. 1099,
2012: Ord. 1018 §1, 2006: Ord. 1006 §1, 2006: prior code §24-5)
12.20.030: DEPOSITING RUBBISH ON STREETS:
It is unlawful to throw, cast or lay any ashes, offal, shavings, dirt, filth,
soapsuds, filthy water or rubbish of any kind whatsoever, in any street,
sidewalk, watercourse, ditch, lane, alley or public place, except at such
places as may be designated by city authorities within the city. (Prior code
§24-6)
12.20.040: SPILLING VEHICLE LOADS ON STREETS:
It is unlawful for the driver of a vehicle loaded with ashes, cinders, coal,
sand, gravel, mortar, tin cans, rubbish or similar materials to permit or allow
the load or any part thereof to scatter along the street. (Prior code §24-7)
12.20.050: UTILITY POLES; PROHIBITED ON MAIN STREET; EXCEPTION:
No telegraph, telephone, electric light or other poles shall be placed upon
Main Street, in the city, except by permission of the city council. (Prior code
§24-8)
12.20.060: UTILITY POLES; MOVEMENT TO ALLEYS:
Whenever repairs to, or the reconstruction of, any telegraph, telephone,
electric light or other line, shall amount to a rebuilding of same, such line
shall be removed to the alleys or the middle of the blocks, except if
permission be granted by the city council for its continuance on the streets.
(Prior code §24-9)
12.20.070: UTILITY POLES; LOCATION IN STREETS GENERALLY:
All poles placed on the streets of the city shall be placed at the inner edge
of the curb line. (Prior code §24-10)
CHAPTER 12.24
STREET SPRINKLING
SECTION:
12.24.010: Local Sprinkling District 1
12.24.010: LOCAL SPRINKLING DISTRICT 1:
A.   Local sprinkling district 1 of the city shall embrace the territory
described in this section for the purpose of sprinkling the streets within the
city within such territory. The territory embraced in such district shall be:
all streets and avenues within the city.
B.   The cost and expense of the sprinkling district shall be taxed and
assessed upon all lots fronting thereon in proportion to the number of feet of
such lots and in proportion to the benefits derived therefrom. (Prior code §24-
4)
CHAPTER 12.28
PARKS
SECTION:
12.28.010: Purpose And Construction Of Chapter
12.28.020: Rules And Regulations; Promulgation Authorized
12.28.030: Rules And Regulations; Posting
12.28.035: Permits For Use Of Public Parks
12.28.037: Hours
12.28.040: Violation; Penalty
12.28.010: PURPOSE AND CONSTRUCTION OF CHAPTER:
This chapter shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the city,
acting in its governmental capacity for the protection of the health, welfare,
morals, safety and cleanliness of the city and all its provisions shall be
liberally construed for the accomplishment of that purpose. (Prior code §18-1)
12.28.020: RULES AND REGULATIONS; PROMULGATION AUTHORIZED:
The mayor and council may, by resolution, adopt rules and regulations governing
the use of the public parks, skate park, swimming pools, public playgrounds,
tennis courts, athletic fields, picnic grounds and other public places, and
other buildings or grounds of any kind or description, to which the public has
general access. (Ord. 1127, 2014)
12.28.030: RULES AND REGULATIONS; POSTING:
A.   After the adoption of any such rules and regulations pursuant to section
 12.28.020 of this chapter, same rules and regulations shall be posted in a
conspicuous place at or near the entrance to any swimming pool, park, skate
park, public playground, tennis court, athletic field, picnic grounds or public
building, a copy of any rules and regulations adopted by governing the use of
such facility.
B.   Such regulations shall be either typewritten or printed in plain English
so that the same may be easily read by persons using any of the facilities of
the grounds or buildings governed by such rules and regulations. (Ord. 1127,
2014)
12.28.035: PERMITS FOR USE OF PUBLIC PARKS:
A.   Applications For Private Use of Public Parks:
   1.   Any person or entity seeking to reserve a public park in the city for
any private use must complete a written application form provided by the City
Clerk, which shall contain the following information:
      a.   The name of the person or entity conducting the activity.
      b.   The event, if any, pursuant to which the activity will be conducted.
      c.   Specific description of any commercial activities to be conducted as
part of the activity.
      d.   The dates upon which the activities will be conducted.
      e.   The exact location within each public park where the commercial
activity will be conducted.
      f.   The expected duration of the activity.
      g.   Any other information required by the City Clerk.
      h.   Each application shall include an attachment for the Applicant to
keep that includes a checklist of items that must be attended to by the
applicant following the close of the activity.
   2.   Each application must be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee
of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
   3.   Deposit. No Permit for Private Use of a City Park involving any two of
the conditions listed herein will be issued until approved by City Council and
until the Applicant has made a security and cleaning deposit in the sum of
$300.00. Deposits are refundable in the sole discretion of the Parks
Supervisor. A refund of the Deposit will be based upon the Applicant’s
compliance with the terms and conditions of its application and its compliance
with post-event checklist included with the Application. Activities involving
two of the following conditions shall pay the Deposit:
      a.   Any event reserving more than one shelter, including the
amphitheater at ICCU Park;
      b.   Any event lasting more than 3 hours; or
      c.   Any event involving commercial sales of goods or services of any
kind.
   4.   Applications involving commercial activity shall be considered by the
city council at its next regular city council meeting following the date of the
submission of the completed application to the city clerk. Applications may be
approved as part of the City Council’s Consent Agenda. Any application denied
shall be entitled to a hearing before the Council prior to final decision on
the denial. Any application may be approved, denied or approved with conditions
found acceptable by the Council.
   5.   Should the council approve the application, the Deposit shall become
due and upon the making of said Deposit and proof of insurance, a permit shall
be issued to the applying entity to conduct the activity which permit shall
provide:
      a.   The date, the name of the person or entity in which the permit is
issued.
      b.   The time, duration, place and date at which the activity may be
conducted.
      c.   The exact nature of the activity which may be conducted.
      d.   The effective date of the Permit, which shall be the date it is
issued by the City.
B.   Insurance. Prior to the issuance of the permit, the Applicant shall
provide proof to the city of the placement of public liability insurance in an
amount not to exceed the single limit coverage of at least five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000.00) of which policy the city has been made an
additional insured. A permit shall further be issued subject to the
understanding by the applicant that by obtaining the permit it agrees to hold
harmless and indemnify the City, from all liability which may arise from, touch
or concern the commercial activity permitted by the City. (Ord. 1127, 2014;
amd. Ord. 1218, 3-21-2023)
12.28.037: HOURS:
A.   Prohibition: No person shall remain within the boundaries of any public
park or public tennis court between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of the following morning.
B.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the terms "public park" and
"public tennis court" shall refer to any park or tennis court owned by the city
or the Jerome recreation district.
C.   Exceptions: The prohibitions of this section shall not apply to:
   1.   Any person traveling through a public park by foot or other lawful
means without stopping or loitering;
   2.   The public tennis court located at the intersection of 1st and Buchanan
in the city;
   3.   Any person who is a part of a group which has been permitted by the
city council, after application on a suitable form, to use the public park or
public tennis court for a specific event, the dates and times for which shall
be specified on the permit. Each application under this section shall be
accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) and shall
include:
      a.   The name of the sponsoring group.
      b.   The event for which the permit is sought.
      c.   The dates and times for which the event is sought.
      d.   Security and noise abatement arrangements.
      e.   Such other provisions as may be reasonably required.
   4.   This section shall not be construed to supersede any other provision of
this code requiring permits for the use of public parks.
D.   Emergencies: Any public park or public tennis court may be closed to the
public during any emergency wherein the public health, safety, or welfare is
clearly threatened by any occurrence. The order of closure may be entered by
the chief of police or mayor.
E.   Penalty: A violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor. (Ord.
1127, 2014)
12.28.040: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of the rules or regulations adopted
by the mayor and council, as provided in this chapter, shall be guilty of an
offense, punishable as follows:
A.   First Offense: A first offense shall be an infraction punishable by a fine
of fifty dollars ($50.00).
B.   Second Offense: A second offense committed within one calendar year shall
be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of three hundred dollars ($300.00) and/or
six (6) months in jail. (Ord. 1127, 2014)
CHAPTER 12.30
TREES
SECTION:
12.30.010: Policy Statement
12.30.020: City Administrator
12.30.030: Tree Committee
12.30.040: Authority And Control Over Trees
12.30.050: Permit Required For Action To Trees; Application
12.30.060: Definitions
12.30.070: Trimming And Pruning Of Trees
12.30.080: Unlawful To Abuse Trees
12.30.090: Hedges And Shrubbery
12.30.100: Penalty
12.30.010: POLICY STATEMENT:
The city hereby declares that it shall be the policy of the city to protect
trees planted and growing within the public rights of way, city parks, and
other real property owned by the city, or over which it has the right to
control trees. (Ord. 847 §1, 1998)
12.30.020: CITY ADMINISTRATOR:
The city administrator shall administer the provisions of this chapter and
shall have all administrative powers in connection therewith which are not
specifically assigned to some other person or body. Administrator shall have
the following authority and duties:
A.   Supervise planting, pruning, spraying, preserving and removing of trees
and other work authorized by this chapter;
B.   Prepare and distribute rules and regulations containing guidelines for the
pruning of trees;
C.   Prepare a tree list consisting of acceptable varieties, size of trees,
property planting and spacing instructions for trees. (Ord. 847 §1, 1998)
12.30.030: TREE COMMITTEE:
There is hereby created a tree committee to consist of five (5) members to be
appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. The members of the
committee shall be eligible and registered voters of the city. The terms of
office for the first members shall be one, two (2) and three (3) years, to be
determined by lot and thereafter the term for each member shall be three (3)
years. Vacancies occurring otherwise than through expiration of terms shall be
filled by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. Members may be removed
after a hearing before the city council by a majority vote of the city council.
Members shall be selected without respect to political affiliation and shall
serve without compensation.
A.   Organization And Meetings: Meetings of the committee shall be held when
duly called by the chairman upon reasonable prior written or oral notice. A
majority of the members of the committee shall be necessary to constitute a
quorum at any meeting. All meetings shall be open to the public. Written rules
consistent with this chapter and the laws of the state for the transaction of
business of the committee shall be adopted and a written record of meetings
kept.
B.   Duties Of Committee: The duties of the tree committee shall include, but
are not limited to, the following:
   1.   Provide advice to the mayor and city council as to appropriate
practices for the preservation, protection and management of trees subject to
this chapter.
   2.   Assist the city administrator in taking an inventory of all existing
trees on all city properties.
   3.   Assist the city administrator in providing information to the public
through educational campaigns, published material and other opportunities.
   4.   Assist the city administrator in implementing Arbor Day celebrations
and activities.
   5.   Encourage and solicit donation and other funding for city tree
projects.
   6.   Identify and implement suitable landscaping projects for city property.
   7.   Assist the city administrator to plan and review applicable budgets and
to make recommendations to the mayor and city council. (Ord. 847 §1, 1998)
12.30.040: AUTHORITY AND CONTROL OVER TREES:
The mayor and the city council have complete authority over all trees on or
within real property owned or controlled by the city. (Ord. 847 §1, 1998)
12.30.050: PERMIT REQUIRED FOR ACTION TO TREES; APPLICATION:
A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, remove, trim, cut or in any
way damage any tree or within real property owned or controlled by the city
without first procuring a permit to do so from the city administrator,
provided, that no permit shall first be required in situations where public
inconvenience would result from the delay entailed in obtaining a permit or
where such delay would place life, limb or property in jeopardy.
B.   Any person desiring a permit to plant, remove, cut or in any way damage a
tree on or within the city properties shall file with the city administrator an
application to do so on forms to be furnished by the city administrator setting
forth therein in detail the work that is contemplated and the location and
address of the same. Upon the filing of such application, the city
administrator shall investigate the contemplated work and if in his judgment it
is desirable and within the parameters of this chapter, shall issue a written
permit therefor; provided that the work authorized in such permit shall be done
under the supervision of the city administrator or his designee. (Ord. 847 §1,
1998)
12.30.060: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter whenever the following words are used, the
intent and meanings shall be interpreted as follows:
   CITY PROPERTY: Real property dedicated, deeded or leased to the city or
otherwise under the physical control of the city, including, but not limited
to, public rights of way and city parks.
   HEDGES AND SHRUBBERY: Any plant of more than two feet (2') but less than
eight feet (8') in height.
   OWNER: The legal owner or owners of the real property adjacent to a public
street in the city of Jerome, Idaho.
   PARKWAY: That portion of a street between a roadway and a sidewalk.
   PERSON: Any individual, firm, partnership, limited liability company,
association, corporation, group or combination acting as a unit.
   ROADWAY: That portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used by
the public for vehicular travel.
   SIDEWALK: That portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used by
the public for pedestrian travel.
   STREET: The entire width between the boundary lines of a public right of way
dedicated or deeded to the city for use of the public for purposes of vehicular
travel, whether or not maintained by the city and whether or not open for
vehicular traffic.
   TREES: Any plant which at maturity would exceed a height of more than eight
feet (8'). (Ord. 847 §1, 1998)
12.30.070: TRIMMING AND PRUNING OF TREES:
A.   Trees on or within the city property shall at all times be so trimmed and
pruned that there shall be at least seven and one- half feet (71/2') of clear
space between the surface of the sidewalk or parkway, as the case may be, and
the overhanging branches and leaves, and so that there is at least thirteen
feet (13') of clear space between the surface of the roadway and the
overhanging branches and leaves.
B.   The branches or leaves of any tree, which overhang any sidewalk, parkway
or roadway present in such manner as to create a hazard to, or impediment to
the progress or vision of any person traveling on any street, sidewalk or
roadway, or which covers, endangers or impairs the view of any traffic control
device by a person operating a motor vehicle on a roadway, including any
branches or leaves with the restricted areas mentioned in subsection A of this
section, are hereby declared to be a public nuisance, whether or not within the
restricted areas mentioned in subsection A of this section.
C.   Each owner of property abutting on a street shall at all times keep pruned
and trimmed all trees on his property which abut this property so as at all
times to prevent such branches and leaves from protruding within the restricted
area mentioned in subsection A of this section and from constituting a public
nuisance under subsection B of this section. Each owner of property shall also
treat or remove any tree or plant so diseased or insect ridden as to constitute
a hazard to trees or plants in public places.
D.   Any tree which shall endanger or damage the usefulness of any street,
roadway, sidewalk, parkway or public sewer or water line, whether growing on
private property or on a parkway, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance,
and each owner of property abutting on a street shall at all times keep trimmed
and pruned all trees, including the pruning and trimming of branches, leaves
and roots, growing on his property which abut this property so as to prevent
such trees from damaging or endangering the usefulness of any street, sidewalk,
roadway, parkway, or public sewer or water line. (Ord. 847 §1, 1998)
12.30.080: UNLAWFUL TO ABUSE TREES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to abuse, damage or mutilate any tree, in
any parkway, or in any public place, or to attach or place any rope or wire,
other than one used to support a young or broken tree, or any sign, poster,
handbill, advertisement or other thing to or on any tree, growing on any
parkway or public place or to cause or permit any wire charged with electricity
to come in contact with any such tree, or to cause or permit any gaseous,
liquid or solid substance which may be harmful to any such tree to come in
contact with the tree. (Ord. 847 §1, 1998)
12.30.090: HEDGES AND SHRUBBERY:
Any owner, agent, tenant or occupant of any real property shall trim all hedges
and shrubbery adjacent to public sidewalks so that no part of said hedges and/
or shrubbery shall extend over any part of a public sidewalk in the city. (Ord.
847 §1, 1998)
12.30.100: PENALTY:
Any violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine
not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 847 §1,
1998)
CHAPTER 12.32
ROLLER SKATES AND SKATEBOARDS
SECTION:
12.32.010: Definition Of Terms
12.32.020: Prohibited Use
12.32.030: Penalty
12.32.010: DEFINITION OF TERMS:
For purposes of this chapter terms shall be defined as follows:
   CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT: The area within the central business district
zone boundary line as shown on the current city of Jerome planning and zoning
map.
   ROLLER SKATES; ROLLERBLADES: Any footwear or other device which can be
attached to the foot containing wheels in contact with the surface as a means
of transporting the wearer. "Rollerblades" refers to any such footwear or
device with in-line wheels.
   SKATEBOARD: A board or platform of any material containing wheels in contact
with the surface upon which an individual may ride as a means of transporting
that individual. (Ord. 920 §1, 2002)
12.32.020: PROHIBITED USE:
A.   No person may use or operate roller skates, rollerblades or a skateboard
on the public streets or public sidewalks in a central business district.
B.   No person may use or operate roller skates, rollerblades or a skateboard
in a reckless or inattentive manner so as to threaten the safety of that person
or any other person or property. (Ord. 920 §1, 2002)
12.32.030: PENALTY:
A violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor. (Ord. 920 §1, 2002)
