13.30.020: METER AND EQUIPMENT COST:
In addition to the connection fee imposed by section
13.30.010 of this chapter, every new customer connecting to the water system
must pay the city the cost of the water meter and related equipment required
for the connection. (Ord. 803 §2, 1996)
13.30.030: OPTIONAL INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS:
At the option of the city, any person seeking connection to the city water
system may purchase and install a meter and other required equipment to effect
the connection. Upon the connection, the meter and other equipment installed
will become the property of the city. In such event, the city will provide
inspection of the work as it is performed, and all work done will be subject to
the city's approval. The provisions of this section shall apply only to persons
whose property to be served is within a subdivision not approved by the city as
of the date of passage hereof. (Ord. 675 §3, 1984)
13.30.040: EXEMPTION FROM STREET CUT FEE:
Notwithstanding any other ordinance or portion of this code to the contrary,
any person complying with the provisions of this chapter shall not be assessed
a separate street cut fee. (Ord. 675 §4, 1984)
CHAPTER 13.32
IRRIGATION SYSTEM
SECTION:
13.32.010: Irrigation System Under Municipal Control
13.32.020: Water Commissioner Appointment And Duties
13.32.030: Delivery Devices To Be Furnished By City
13.32.040: Assessment And Collection Of Expenses
13.32.050: Fund Established
13.32.060: Unlawful Interference With Ditches And Equipment
13.32.070: Placement Of Earthen Dams Or Injury To Ditches Prohibited
13.32.080: Irrigation Schedule; Penalty For Violation
13.32.010: IRRIGATION SYSTEM UNDER MUNICIPAL CONTROL:
Whereas the city is the holder of legal title to more than a majority of the
shares of the capital stock of North Side Canal Company, Limited, which
represents the water right appurtenant to the lands and lots within the city,
it is declared that the distribution and apportionment of irrigation water to
the inhabitants of the city, the conveyance of irrigation water through the
public streets, avenues and alleys of the city, and the construction,
maintenance and operation of the irrigation works within the city, are subject
to regulation, control and supervision by the mayor and council of the city.
(Prior code §27-7)
13.32.020: WATER COMMISSIONER APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES:
A.   The mayor and council shall at the beginning of each irrigation season
appoint a water commissioner, fix his term of service and his compensation,
which shall be paid out of the "irrigation fund" provided in section
13.32.050 of this chapter. He shall be removable at the pleasure of the mayor
and council.
B.   It shall be the duty of the water commissioner to keep the irrigation
works in good repair and operating condition, and to keep the ditches clean and
free from obstructions.
C.   It shall be his duty to supervise and control, under such general
regulations as the mayor and council may adopt, the distribution and
apportionment of all irrigation water to the inhabitants of the city in
proportion to the amount of land to be irrigated, and he shall have sole
control and regulation of all head gates, weirs, delivery boxes, and other
measuring and delivery devices, and shall see that water is used only in due
turn and rotation, and at the allotted times.
D.   He shall issue certificates to or otherwise inform the water users of the
quantity of water they are to receive, and the times and the duration of the
delivery thereof. (Prior code §27-8)
13.32.030: DELIVERY DEVICES TO BE FURNISHED BY CITY:
Head gates, weirs, delivery boxes or other measuring or delivery devices for
the delivery or measurement to individual users of irrigation water shall be
paid for by the city. Installation of the irrigation measuring or delivery
devices shall be paid for by the city of Jerome, and the city of Jerome shall
be responsible to keep the irrigation measuring or delivery devices in repair.
The duty of the city to keep the measuring and delivery devices in repair shall
not prevent the city from seeking recovery of the costs of repairs from
responsible parties who may intentionally or negligently damage those devices.
In the event a property owner fails to repair head gates, weirs, delivery boxes
or other measuring or delivery devices intentionally or negligently damaged by
the property owner, his family, contractors or invitees, the city shall refuse
to deliver irrigation water to such property owner until the necessary repairs
have been made by the property owner. (Ord. 941 §1, 2003: prior code §27-9)
13.32.040: ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION OF EXPENSES:
A.   The annual cost of the conveyance, distribution and apportionment of
irrigation water, the construction, maintenance and repair of the irrigation
works, and the charges of the North Side Canal Company, Limited, for the
delivery of water from its system, shall be defrayed by assessment against each
lot and parcel of land whereon irrigation water is, may be, or can be used or
delivered out of the irrigation system, in proportion to the amount of water
allotted to such lot and parcel of land.
B.   The mayor and council shall cause to be prepared in the month of July in
each year an assessment roll showing the amount assessed for the purposes
aforesaid in that year against each lot, piece or parcel of real estate served
by the irrigation system and subject to assessment for such purposes, and file
the same in the office of the city clerk.
C.   The city clerk shall publish in one issue of a newspaper printed and
published in the city a notice stating that the assessment roll has been filed
in his office and a time and place at which the mayor and council will hear and
consider protests against any assessment made therein.
D.   The assessment roll, as modified or confirmed by the mayor and council,
shall be certified to the proper county officer for inclusion in and collection
with the general state and county taxes of that year. (Prior code §27-10)
13.32.050: FUND ESTABLISHED:
All collections of the assessments made under section
13.32.040 of this chapter shall be placed in a separate fund, to be known as
the irrigation fund, out of which shall be paid the annual cost of the
conveyance, distribution and apportionment of irrigation water, the
construction, maintenance and repair of the irrigation works, and the charges
of the North Side Canal Company, Limited, and no other charges. (Prior code
§27-11)
13.32.060: UNLAWFUL INTERFERENCE WITH DITCHES AND EQUIPMENT:
It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to change, alter, destroy, disturb,
meddle, tamper or interfere with, any head gate, dam, weir, water box or other
measuring or delivery device, placed, used or regulated by the water
commissioner when such device is being used for the measurement or delivery of
irrigation water, or to meddle, tamper or interfere with the dam or turn
irrigation water so as to disarrange the schedule of distribution of the
municipality and thereby deprive any user or landowner from the uninterrupted
use and benefit of his turn and rotation of such water. (Prior code §27-12)
13.32.070: PLACEMENT OF EARTHEN DAMS OR INJURY TO DITCHES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person:
A.   To place in any ditch earthen dams or checks;
B.   To injure, damage or destroy ditches, laterals, pipes, flumes, culverts or
other devices within the city by which irrigation water is conveyed or
distributed to the inhabitants thereof, or to permit livestock of any kind
owned by him or in his charge to trample down, damage, injure or destroy the
same. (Prior code §27-13)
13.32.080: IRRIGATION SCHEDULE; PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
A.   An irrigation schedule shall be adopted by the city for each irrigation
season. The irrigation schedule shall be adopted by the city administrator in
consultation with employees of the irrigation department. The irrigation
schedule shall designate the days and times where each property owner may use
irrigation water delivered to that property. The irrigation schedule for that
irrigation season shall be put in writing and delivered to each property owner
by personnel of the city prior to the commencement of each irrigation season.
B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to use irrigation water provided
through the city of Jerome irrigation system in any manner not in compliance
with the irrigation schedule for that property.
C.   Any of the provisions of subsection B of this section shall be considered
a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars
($300.00) per occurrence. (Ord. 947 §1, 2003: Ord. 594, 1977)
CHAPTER 13.36
INDUSTRIAL WASTE DISPOSAL
SECTION:
13.36.010: Definitions
13.36.020: Admission Of Industrial Wastes Into Public Sewers; Approval Required
13.36.030: Admission Of Industrial Wastes Into Public Sewers; Pretreatment
13.36.040: Admission Of Industrial Wastes Into Public Sewers; Submission Of
Information
13.36.050: Prohibited Discharges; Sanitary Sewers
13.36.060: Prohibited Discharges; Combined And Storm Sewers
13.36.070: Prohibited Discharges; Enumerated
13.36.080: Special Agreements
13.36.090: Control Of Admissible Wastes; Submission Of Basic Data
13.36.100: Control Of Admissible Wastes; Time Extension For Compliance
13.36.110: Industrial Waste Sewer Service Charges
13.36.120: Flow Measurement And Sampling Facilities
13.36.130: Analyses
13.36.140: Billing Periods
13.36.150: Payment
13.36.160: Delinquency
13.36.170: Discontinuance Of Service
13.36.180: Restoration Of Service
13.36.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings set out below:
   APPROVING AUTHORITY: The public works director of the city; or his duly
authorized deputy, agent, or representative.
   BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (Abbreviated As BOD): The quantity of oxygen,
expressed in parts per million required for the aerobic biological oxidation of
organic solids in waste or sewage under laboratory conditions of five (5) days'
incubation at a temperature of twenty degrees centigrade (20°C). The laboratory
determination shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the
definition of "Standards Methods" of this section.
   CHLORINE REQUIREMENT: The amount of chlorine in pounds required to meet the
chlorine demand and still produce a specified residual chlorine content.
Chlorine residual shall be expressed in parts per million, and shall be
determined in accordance with procedures outlined in the definition of
"Standard Methods" of this section.
   CITY: The city of Jerome, Idaho.
   COMBINED SEWER: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and wastewater.
   COMMERCIAL BUILDING: All buildings or premises used for any purpose other
than a dwelling unit, but not an industrial waste contributor.
   DWELLING UNITS: Buildings and structures that are constructed and used
primarily for residential purposes. Any building or structure which has been
constructed or altered to provide for two (2) or more families or households,
or which has been constructed or altered to accommodate travelers or
transients, shall also be considered a dwelling unit(s).
   GARBAGE: The residue from the preparation and dispensing of food, and from
the handling, storage, and sale of food products and produce.
   GROUND GARBAGE: The residue from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of
food that has been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried
freely in suspension under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension.
   INDUSTRIAL USER: All sewer users which discharge an industrial waste as
defined by the definition of "Industrial Waste" of this section.
   INDUSTRIAL WASTE: Any flow discharged to the sewer wastewater treatment
facilities containing one or more of the following:
   A.   A total of more than thirty (30) pounds of suspended solids in any one
day.
   B.   A total of more than thirty (30) pounds of BOD in any one day.
   C.   A total flow of more than 0.025 million gallons per day in any one day,
or a flow that will average more than 0.025 million gallons per day for a
monthly period.
   PARTS PER MILLION: A weight to weight ratio. The formula PPM times 8.345
times million gallons per day shall be used to compute organic and solids
loading for purposes of the definition of "Industrial Waste" of this section.
   PERSON: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any
individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association,
society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency, or other entity.
   pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion
concentration expressed in moles per liter. It shall be determined by one of
the procedures outlined in the definition of "Standard Methods" of this
section.
   PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the
city. It shall also include sewers within or outside the city boundaries that
serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the city sanitary or
combined sewer system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed
with city funds.
   SANITARY SEWER: A sewer that conveys domestic, commercial, or industrial
wastes, or a combination of the three (3), and into which storm, surface, and
ground waters or unpolluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted.
   SERVICE CHARGE: The assessment levied on all users of the public sewer
system.
   SEWER: A pipe or conduit for conveying wastewater or any other waste
liquids, including storm, surface, and ground water drainage.
   SEWERAGE: The system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection,
transportation, and pumping of wastewater and industrial wastes.
   SHALL; MAY: "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissible.
   STANDARD METHODS: The examination and analytical procedures set forth in the
most recent edition of "Standard Methods For The Examination Of Water, Sewage,
And Industrial Wastes", published jointly by the American Public Health
Association, the American Water Works Association, and the Federation of Sewage
and Industrial Wastes Association.
   STORM SEWER: A sewer that carries storm, surface, and ground water drainage,
but excludes domestic, commercial, and industrial wastes.
   STORMWATER RUNOFF: That portion of the rainfall that is drained into the
sewers.
   SUSPENDED SOLIDS: Solids that either float on the surface of, or are in
suspension in water, domestic, commercial, or industrial waste, and which are
removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of
suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the
definition of "Standard Methods" of this section.
   UNPOLLUTED WATER OR LIQUIDS: Any water or liquid containing none of the
following: free or emulsified grease or oil; acids or alkalies; substances that
may impart taste and odor or color characteristics; toxic or poisonous
substances in suspension, colloidal state or solution; odorous or otherwise
obnoxious gases. It shall contain not more than thirty (30) parts per million
each of suspended solids or biochemical oxygen demand. Analytical
determinations shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the
definition of "Standard Methods" of this section.
   WASTEWATER: The water carried human, animal, or household wastes in a public
or private drain, and may include ground water infiltration, surface drainage,
and industrial wastes.
   WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT: An assemblage of devices, structures, and
equipment for treating domestic, commercial, and industrial waste.
   WASTEWATER TREATMENT WORKS: All facilities for collecting, pumping,
treating, and disposing of domestic, commercial, and industrial waste, and it
includes sewers as well as the waste treatment facilities. (Ord. 722 §6, 1990:
Ord. 620 §2, 1978: Ord. 586 §§101-128, 1976)
13.36.020: ADMISSION OF INDUSTRIAL WASTES INTO PUBLIC SEWERS; APPROVAL
REQUIRED:
Review and acceptance of the approving authority shall be obtained prior to the
discharge into the public sewers of any water or wastes having any one or more
of the following characteristics:
A.   A total of more than thirty (30) pounds of suspended solids in any one
day;
B.   A total of more than thirty (30) pounds of five (5) day BOD in any one
day;
C.   A total flow of 0.025 million gallons in any one day or a flow that will
average more than 0.025 million gallons a day for a monthly period. (Ord. 722
§6, 1990: Ord. 620 §2, 1979: Ord. 586 §201, 1976)
13.36.030: ADMISSION OF INDUSTRIAL WASTES INTO PUBLIC SEWERS; PRETREATMENT:
A.   Where required, in the opinion of the approving authority, to modify or
eliminate wastes that are harmful to the structure, processes or operation of
the wastewater treatment works owned by the city, the user shall provide at his
sole expense, such preliminary treatment or processing facilities as may be
necessary to render waste acceptable for admission to the public sewers.
B.   All wastes containing soil, dirt and/or sand shall be settled a minimum of
two (2) hours in an acceptable basin before discharge to a sewer.
C.   All industrial wastes must be passed through approved self- cleaning 20-
gauge mesh screens unless otherwise allowed by the approving authority.
D.   All waste containing floating solids, greases, waxes, slurries or the like
in small or trace amounts must be passed through a suitable trap before
discharge into the sewerage system. (Ord. 620 §2, 1979: Ord. 586 §202, 1976)
13.36.040: ADMISSION OF INDUSTRIAL WASTES INTO PUBLIC SEWERS; SUBMISSION OF
INFORMATION:
Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to proposed
pretreatment or processing facilities shall be submitted for approval to the
approving authority prior to the start of their construction if the effluent
from such facilities is to be discharged into the public sewers. (Ord. 586
§203, 1976)
13.36.050: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES; SANITARY SEWERS:
No person shall cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface drainage,
subsurface drainage, ground water, roof runoff, cooling water, or unpolluted
water into any sanitary sewer. (Ord. 586 §301, 1976)
13.36.060: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES; COMBINED AND STORM SEWERS:
Stormwater, surface drainage, subsurface drainage, ground water, roof runoff,
cooling water, or unpolluted water may be admitted to such sewers as are
specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers and which have
adequate capacity for their accommodation. No person shall use such sewers
without first having obtained the consent of the approving authority. (Ord. 586
§302, 1976)
13.36.070: PROHIBITED DISCHARGES; ENUMERATED:
Except as provided in this chapter, no person shall discharge into the public
sewers:
A.   Any solids, liquids, or gases which may, by themselves or by interaction
with other substances, cause fire or explosive hazards, or in any other way be
injurious to persons, property, or the operation of the wastewater treatment
works;
B.   Any noxious or malodorous solids, liquids, or gases which either singly,
or by interaction with other substances, are capable of creating a public
nuisance or hazard to life or preventing entry into sewers for their
maintenance or repair;
C.   Any solids, greases, waxes, slurries, or viscous material of such
character or in such quantity that, in the opinion of the approving authority,
may cause an obstruction to the flow in the sewer, or otherwise interfere with
the proper functioning of the wastewater treatment works;
D.   Any toxic substance, chemical elements, or compounds in quantities
sufficient to impair the operation or efficiency of the wastewater treatment
facilities, or that will pass through the wastewater treatment plant and cause
the effluent thereof to exceed Idaho state board of health water requirements
for the receiving stream;
E.   Any liquids having a pH lower than 6.0 or higher than 9.0, or having any
corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazards to structures,
equipment, or personnel of the wastewater treatment works;
F.   Any radioactive isotopes without obtaining a special permit from the
approving authority;
G.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature greater than one hundred forty
degrees Fahrenheit (140°F);
H.   Any garbage that has not been ground or shredded;
I.   Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags,
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure, hair, or any other solid capable
of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with proper
operation of the wastewater treatment works. (Ord. 586 §303, 1976)
13.36.080: SPECIAL AGREEMENTS:
No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting any
special agreement or arrangement between the city and any person whereby an
industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be admitted to the
wastewater treatment works, either before or after pretreatment, provided that
there is no impairment of the functioning of the wastewater treatment works by
reason of the admission of such wastes, and no extra costs are incurred by the
city without recompense by the person. (Ord. 586 §304, 1976)
13.36.090: CONTROL OF ADMISSIBLE WASTES; SUBMISSION OF BASIC DATA:
A.   Within three (3) months after passage of this chapter, each person who
discharges industrial wastes to a public sewer shall prepare and file with the
approving authority a report that shall include pertinent data relating to the
quantity and characteristics of the wastes discharged to the wastewater
treatment works.
B.   Similarly, each person desiring to make a new connection to a public sewer
for the purpose of discharging industrial wastes shall prepare and file with
the approving authority a report that shall include actual or predicted data
relating to the quantity and characteristics of the waste to be discharged.
(Ord. 586 §401, 1976)
13.36.100: CONTROL OF ADMISSIBLE WASTES; TIME EXTENSION FOR COMPLIANCE:
When it can be demonstrated that circumstances exist which would create an
unreasonable burden on the person to comply with the time schedule imposed by
section
13.36.090 of this chapter, a request for extension of time may be presented for
consideration of the approving authority. (Ord. 586 §402, 1976)
13.36.110: INDUSTRIAL WASTE SEWER SERVICE CHARGES:
Each person discharging industrial wastes to a public sanitary sewer with a
daily total loading in excess of thirty (30) pounds per day suspended solids,
thirty (30) pounds per day of five (5) day BOD, or any average total flow in
excess of 0.025 million gallons per day shall, when directed by the city
administrator, or his duly authorized deputy, agent or representative,
construct and maintain approved measurement and sampling facilities for all
waste entering the sanitary sewer. These facilities shall be used to obtain
flow, BOD, and suspended solids data for use as a basis to the industrial waste
service charges on a monthly basis. (Ord. 722 §6, 1990: Ord. 620 §2, 1979: Ord.
586 §403, 1976)
13.36.120: FLOW MEASUREMENT AND SAMPLING FACILITIES:
A.   Installation And Maintenance: If so directed by the approving authority,
all devices, access facilities, and related equipment shall be installed by the
person discharging the waste at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so
as to be in a safe and proper operating condition at all times, and readily
accessible to city forces during his operating day.
B.   Types Of Devices: The flow measurement device can be a Parshall flume,
weir, venturi, nozzle, magnetic flow meter, or any other type of device
providing accurate and continuous flow indication recorded on a chart or
totalizer in million gallons a day. Pump timers or other indirect measurement
devices will not be accepted.
C.   Composite Sampler: If so directed by the approving authority, an automatic
sampler, capable of collecting no less than two (2) quarts of sample in a
twenty four (24) hour period shall be installed and maintained by the person
discharging the waste, at his expense. The sampler must be capable of
maintaining sample at a temperature of less than forty degrees Fahrenheit
(40°F).
D.   Plans; Location Of Sampling Station: The flow measurement and sampling
station shall be located and constructed in a manner acceptable to the city.
Complete plans on all phases of the proposed installation, including all
equipment proposed for use shall be submitted to the city for approval prior to
construction.
E.   Records; Maintenance And Operation: The person discharging the waste shall
keep flow records as required by the city and shall provide qualified personnel
to properly maintain and operate the facilities. (Ord. 586 §404, 1976)
13.36.130: ANALYSES:
The waste samples will be analyzed by city forces. Laboratory procedures used
in the examination of industrial wastes shall be those set forth in "standard
methods". However, alternate methods for certain analyses of industrial wastes
may be used. (Ord. 586 §405, 1976)
13.36.140: BILLING PERIODS:
Industrial waste charges shall be assessed monthly in accordance with this
code. (Ord. 620 §2, 1979: Ord. 586 §501, 1976)
13.36.150: PAYMENT:
Industrial waste sewer service charges shall be payable at the city hall. (Ord.
586 §502, 1976)
13.36.160: DELINQUENCY:
Such sewer service charges levied in accordance with this chapter shall be a
debt due to the city and shall be a lien upon the property. If this debt is not
paid within thirty (30) days after it shall be due and payable, it shall be
deemed delinquent and may be recovered by civil action in the name of the city
against the property owner, the person, or both. (Ord. 586 §601, 1976)
13.36.170: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
A.   In the event of failure to pay sewer service charges after they become
delinquent, or failure to have flow or sampling devices in proper operating
condition for more than one week, the city shall have the right to remove or
close sewer connections, and enter upon the property for accomplishing such
purposes.
B.   The expense of such removal, or closing, as well as the expense of
restoring service, shall likewise be a debt due to the city and a lien upon the
property and may be recovered by civil action in the name of the city against
the property owner, the person, or both. (Ord. 586 §602, 1976)
13.36.180: RESTORATION OF SERVICE:
Sewer service shall not be restored until all charges, including the expense of
removal, closing, and restoration, shall have been paid. (Ord. 586 §603, 1976)
CHAPTER 13.40
PUBLIC SERVICES; GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
13.40.010: Continuous Service Agreement
13.40.020: Level Pay Plan
13.40.030: Prohibition Of Water Service
13.40.040: Penalty Of Twenty Percent Placed On Delinquent Accounts (Rep. by
Ord. 1142, 2015)
13.40.050: Late Fee Of Thirty Dollars Shall Be Placed On Unpaid Accounts
13.40.010: CONTINUOUS SERVICE AGREEMENT:
A.   Notwithstanding other provisions of this code to the contrary,
"landlords", hereby defined as any person or entity owning real property within
the area serviced by the city water and/or sewer systems, which real property
is regularly leased to third parties, hereby referred to as "tenants", may
execute the form approved by the city council, a continuous service agreement.
Continuous service agreement shall be executed by landlords and shall provide,
in addition to whatever other matters the city council deems appropriate, the
following provisions:
   1.   Correct legal name of the landlord.
   2.   Landlord's phone number and address.
   3.   Space for the landlord's signature.
   4.   The correct mailing address of every parcel of real property owned by
the landlord for which the continuous service agreement is sought, together
with apartment numbers, if appropriate.
   5.   The requirement that the landlord provide immediate written notice to
the city of any changes in the landlord's telephone number, mailing address,
ownership of any of the properties desired to be subject to the agreement.
   6.   The landlord will be continuously responsible for payment of all water
and wastewater charges incurred from the date of cessation of service by a
current tenant, whether by notice and termination of service under lawfully
established procedures or by the tenant vacating the premises without notice,
and the date upon which a new tenant contacts the city and lawfully assumes
responsibility for said charges.
   7.   A provision that if any landlord defaults in the performance of a
continuous service agreement that they will be liable to the city, in addition
to all charges attributable to the landlord under the agreement, lawful
interest and attorney fees and costs incurred by the city in the collection of
the charges.
B.   A deposit in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) per residential unit
covered by the continuous service agreement shall be paid by the landlord to
the city at the time the agreement is executed. The deposit shall be applied to
any delinquent charges attributable to a landlord under the continuous service
agreement. (Ord. 724 §§1, 2, 1991)
13.40.020: LEVEL PAY PLAN:
A.   Any person who has had a minimum of one year's history of payment of user
charges incurred by patronizing the city domestic water and/or public sewer
system, without default in payment, may apply to the city for "level pay"
payments of domestic water and/or sewer charges. Applications shall be made on
a form provided by the office of the city clerk.
B.   If the application is in order, and the applicant appears qualified, the
applicant shall execute an agreement, on a form to be provided by the office of
the city clerk, setting forth the obligations of the applicant and the city
with regard to the "level pay" arrangement.
C.   The "level pay" year will commence on the next July 1 occurring after the
date of the agreement. From July 1 through June 30, "level pay" parties shall
pay the average amount of billings for sewer and domestic water services as
determined by the previous twelve (12) months' billing experience. Meters will
continue to be read on the regular schedule and, for informational purposes,
the monthly statement will reflect a debit or credit balance based on current
readings. The statement issued for the last month of the level pay year shall
reflect a final credit or debit balance. Debit balances must be paid in full by
the customer with that statement. Credit balances will be reflected by credit
being granted by the city on that month's statement.
D.   Noncompliance with the "level pay" agreement by any customer executing the
same shall allow the city to immediately institute all proceedings now
established by this code for termination of service and collection of all
charges due and owing. Noncompliance with the "level pay" agreement shall also
result in that person being ineligible for "level pay" program for a minimum of
one year. (Ord. 725 §§1 - 4, 1991)
13.40.030: PROHIBITION OF WATER SERVICE:
A.   No domestic water service shall be provided to any new structure which is
constructed on prime farmland as that term is defined and identified by the
United States department of agriculture, natural resource conversation service,
if the new structure would cause the land upon which it is located and which it
is surrounded by to lose its designation as prime farmland.
B.   The foregoing restriction shall not apply to any land, however designated,
within the city limits, or on any land under the jurisdiction of the city's
newly adopted comprehensive land use plan zoning and subdivision ordinance,
which is being developed in accordance with the comprehensive plan. (Ord. 833
§1, 1997)
13.40.040: PENALTY OF TWENTY PERCENT PLACED ON DELINQUENT ACCOUNTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 1142, 2015)
13.40.050: LATE FEE OF THIRTY DOLLARS SHALL BE PLACED ON UNPAID ACCOUNTS:
A late fee in the amount of thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be required from the
responsible party, as provided elsewhere in this title, for late payment of a
domestic water or wastewater collection and treatment account. "Late" for
purposes of defining "late fee" shall mean payment on unpaid accounts received
after the beginning of regular business hours of the last Tuesday of each
month. The rates and fees established herein may be amended or revised in the
future by a resolution passed by a majority of the full city council. (Ord.
1142, 2015)
TITLE 14
URBAN RENEWAL
CHAPTER 14.04
BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
14.04.010: Established
14.04.020: Terms Of Office
14.04.030: Qualifications
14.04.040: Powers
14.04.010: ESTABLISHED:
A board of commissioners of five (5) members is hereby established pursuant to
Idaho Code 50-2006, to exercise the powers of the Jerome urban renewal agency.
(Ord. 869 §1, 1998)
14.04.020: TERMS OF OFFICE:
Each commissioner shall serve a term of five (5) years, provided that the
initial commissioners shall serve terms as follows:
 
Seat 1 5 years
Seat 2 3 years
Seat 3 3 years
Seat 4 1 year
Seat 5 1 year
 
After the initial term of the office has been completed, all successive terms
of office shall be for a period of five (5) years. (Ord. 869 §2, 1998)
14.04.030: QUALIFICATIONS:
All commissioners shall be qualified electors of the city residing in the city
limits of Jerome. (Ord. 869 §4, 1998)
14.04.040: POWERS:
The board of commissioners shall have the ability to exercise such powers as it
may lawfully exercise under the provisions of Idaho Code 50-2001 et seq. The
board of commissioners shall have power to make reasonable rules of procedure
to govern the conduct of its business. (Ord. 869 §5, 1998)
CHAPTER 14.08
SOUTH LINCOLN URBAN RENEWAL PLAN
SECTION:
14.08.010: Findings
14.08.020: Open Land
14.08.030: Housing And Economic Development
14.08.040: Approval Of Plan
14.08.050: Agreement On The Administration Of The Revenue Allocation
14.08.060: Action Against Plan
14.08.070: Copies Transmitted
14.08.080: Revenue Allocation Area
14.08.090: Council Members As Commissioners
14.08.100: Council As Board
14.08.110: Effective Date
14.08.120: Severability
14.08.130: Summary
14.08.010: FINDINGS:
It is hereby found and determined that:
A.   The project area as defined in the third amended South Lincoln plan is a
deteriorated or a deteriorating area as defined in the law 1  and the act 2
and qualifies as an eligible urban renewal area under the law and act,
including under the act a deteriorated area consisting of open land.
B.   The rehabilitation, conservation, and redevelopment of the project area
pursuant to the third amended South Lincoln plan is necessary in the interest
of public health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the city of Jerome.
C.   There continues to be a need for the agency to function in the city of
Jerome.
D.   The third amended South Lincoln plan conforms to the comprehensive plan of
the city of Jerome.
E.   Specifically the city council finds that sufficient park and recreational
facilities exist within close proximity of the project area. Certain
improvements outlined in the third amended South Lincoln plan will enhance
accessibility to those park and recreational facilities, specifically the
installation of traffic signals which allow crossing of South Lincoln and
result in greater safety for users of those park and recreational facilities
including children who reside and will reside within the South Lincoln project
area and the improvements to the public parking lots. In addition, certain park
or recreational improvements have been proposed within the project area.
F.   The third amended South Lincoln plan affords maximum opportunity
consistent with the sound needs of the city as a whole for the rehabilitation
and redevelopment of the project area by private enterprises.
G.   The third amended South Lincoln plan provides a feasible method for
relocation of any displaced families residing within the project area.
H.   The base assessment roll of the third amended project area does not exceed
ten percent (10%) of the assessed value of the city of Jerome. (Ord. 940 §1,
2003)
 
Notes
1 1. IC title 50, chapter 20.
2 2. IC title 50, chapter 29.
14.08.020: OPEN LAND:
The city council finds that the third amended project area and third amended
revenue allocation area contain certain open land, that the agency does not
intend to acquire any open land on any widespread basis, and that the third
amended project area is planned to be redeveloped in a manner that will include
both residential and nonresidential uses. Provided, however, that the city
council does find that if portions of the third amended project area and third
amended revenue allocation area are deemed "open land", the criteria set forth
in the law and act have been met. (Ord. 940 §2, 2003)
14.08.030: HOUSING AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT:
One of the third amended South Lincoln plan objectives to increase the
residential opportunity to include affordable housing does meet the sound needs
of the city and will provide housing opportunity in an area that does not now
contain such opportunity, and that portion of the project area which is
identified for nonresidential uses is necessary and appropriate to facilitate
the proper growth and development standards in accordance with the objectives
of the comprehensive plan to overcome economic disuse, the need for improved
traffic patterns and the need for the correlation of this area with other areas
of the city. (Ord. 940 §3, 2003)
14.08.040: APPROVAL OF PLAN:
The third amended South Lincoln plan, a copy of which is attached to the
ordinance codified herein and marked as exhibit 2 and made a part hereof by
attachment and is available for inspection in the office of the city clerk, be
and the same hereby is approved. (Ord. 940 §4, 2003)
14.08.050: AGREEMENT ON THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE REVENUE ALLOCATION:
For any property outside the municipal boundaries of the city of Jerome, an
agreement on the administration of the revenue allocation financing provision
shall be negotiated with Jerome County and formalized by a transfer of power
ordinance as defined in the act for this chapter to be effective against that
property. (Ord. 940 §5, 2003)
14.08.060: ACTION AGAINST PLAN:
No direct or collateral action attacking the third amended South Lincoln plan
shall be brought prior to the effective date hereof or after the elapse of
thirty (30) days from and after the effective date hereof. (Ord. 940 §6, 2003)
14.08.070: COPIES TRANSMITTED:
Upon the effective date hereof, the city clerk is authorized and directed to
transmit to the county recorder, county auditor and tax assessor of Jerome
County, and to the appropriate officials of the Jerome County board of county
commissioners, Jerome County School District, Jerome highway district, College
of Southern Idaho, Jerome recreation district, and to the state tax commission,
a copy of the ordinance codified herein, a copy of the legal description of the
boundaries of the third amended revenue allocation area, and a map or plan
indicating the boundaries of the third amended revenue allocation area. (Ord.
940 §7, 2003)
14.08.080: REVENUE ALLOCATION AREA:
The city council hereby finds and declares that the third amended revenue
allocation area as defined in the third amended South Lincoln plan, includes
that portion of the third amended project area, the equalized assessed
valuation of which the council hereby determines is in and is part of the third
amended South Lincoln plan, is likely to continue to increase as a result of
the initiation and completion of urban renewal projects pursuant to the third
amended South Lincoln plan. (Ord. 940 §8, 2003)
14.08.090: COUNCIL MEMBERS AS COMMISSIONERS:
The city council hereby approves and adopts the following statement of policy
relating to the appointment of city council members as members of the agency's
board of commissioners: If any city council members are appointed to the board,
they are not acting in an ex officio capacity but rather as private citizens
who, although they are also members of the city council, are exercising their
independent judgment as private citizens when they sit on the board. Except for
the powers to appoint and terminate board members and to adopt the third
amended South Lincoln plan the city council recognizes that it has no power to
control the powers or operations of the agency. (Ord. 940 §9, 2003)
14.08.100: COUNCIL AS BOARD:
So long as any agency bonds are outstanding, the city council will not exercise
its power under Idaho Code section 50-2006 to designate itself as the agency
board. (Ord. 940 §10, 2003)
14.08.110: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter shall be in full force and effect immediately upon its passage,
approval and publication, and shall be retroactive to January 1, 2003, to the
extent permitted by the act, with the effective date of the base assessment
roll covered by the original revenue allocation area remaining at January 1,
1998, and the first amended revenue allocation area remaining at January 1,
1999, and the second amended and restated revenue allocation area remaining at
January 1, 2000. (Ord. 940 §11, 2003)
14.08.120: SEVERABILITY:
The provisions of this chapter are severable and if any provision of this
chapter or the application of such provision to any person or circumstance is
declared invalid for any reason, such declaration shall not affect the validity
of remaining portions of this chapter. (Ord. 940 §12, 2003)
14.08.130: SUMMARY:
The summary of this chapter, a copy of which is attached as exhibit 3 to the
ordinance codified herein, and is available for inspection in the office of the
city clerk, is hereby approved. (Ord. 940 §14, 2003)
CHAPTER 14.12
SOUTHEAST INDUSTRIAL URBAN RENEWAL PLAN
SECTION:
14.12.010: Findings
14.12.020: Open Land
14.12.030: Growth And Development
14.12.040: Approval Of Plan
14.12.050: Action Against Plan
14.12.060: Copies Transmitted
14.12.070: Projected Increase Of Assessed Valuation Of Area
14.12.080: Statement Of Policy
14.12.090: Agency Board
14.12.100: Effective Date
14.12.010: FINDINGS:
It is hereby found and determined that:
A.   The project area as defined in the southeast industrial plan is a
deteriorated or a deteriorating area as defined in the Idaho urban renewal law
of 1965 1  ("law") and the local economic development act 2  ("act") and
qualifies as an eligible urban renewal area under the law and act, including
under the act and law a deteriorated or deteriorating area consisting of open
land.
B.   The rehabilitation, conservation, and redevelopment of the project area
pursuant to the southeast industrial plan is necessary in the interest of
public health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the city of Jerome.
C.   There continues to be a need for the agency to function in the city of
Jerome.
D.   The southeast industrial plan conforms to the comprehensive plan of the
city of Jerome.
E.   The southeast industrial plan gives due consideration to the provision of
adequate park and recreation areas and facilities that may be desirable for
neighborhood improvement (recognizing the primary commercial and industrial
component of the southeast industrial plan, the need for overall public
improvements), and shows consideration for the health, safety, and welfare of
any residents or businesses in the general vicinity of the project area as
defined by the southeast industrial urban renewal plan.
F.   The southeast industrial plan affords maximum opportunity consistent with
the sound needs of the city as a whole for the rehabilitation and redevelopment
of the project area by private enterprises.
G.   The southeast industrial plan provides a feasible method for relocation of
any displaced families residing within the project area.
H.   The collective base assessment roll of the southeast industrial area and
the south Lincoln project area do not exceed ten percent (10%) of the assessed
value of the city of Jerome. (Ord. 986 §1, 2005)
 
Notes
1 1. IC title 50, ch. 20.
2 2. IC title 50, ch. 29.
14.12.020: OPEN LAND:
The city council finds that the southeast industrial project area and southeast
industrial revenue allocation area contain certain open land, that the agency
does not intend to acquire any open land on any widespread basis, and that the
southeast industrial project area is planned to be redeveloped in a manner that
will include nonresidential (primarily commercial and industrial) uses.
Provided, however, that the city council does find that if portions of the
southeast industrial project area and southeast industrial revenue allocation
area are deemed "open land", the criteria set forth in the law and act have
been met. (Ord. 986 §2, 2005)
14.12.030: GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT:
That portion of the project area which is identified for nonresidential uses is
necessary and appropriate to facilitate the proper growth and development
standards in accordance with the objectives of the comprehensive plan to
overcome economic disuse, the need for improved traffic patterns and the need
for the correlation of this area with other areas of the city. (Ord. 986 §3,
2005)
14.12.040: APPROVAL OF PLAN:
The southeast industrial plan, a copy of which is marked as exhibit 1 and
attached to the ordinance codified herein and made a part hereof by attachment,
be and the same hereby is approved. The city clerk and/or the agency may make
certain technical corrections or revisions in keeping with the information and
testimony presented at the December 6, 2005, hearing. (Ord. 986 §4, 2005)
14.12.050: ACTION AGAINST PLAN:
No direct or collateral action attacking the southeast industrial plan shall be
brought prior to the effective date hereof or after the elapse of thirty (30)
days from and after the effective date hereof. (Ord. 986 §5, 2005)
14.12.060: COPIES TRANSMITTED:
Upon the effective date hereof, the city clerk is authorized and directed to
transmit to the county recorder, county auditor and tax assessor of Jerome
County, and to the appropriate officials of the city of Jerome, Jerome County
board of county commissioners, Jerome County school district, Jerome highway
district, College of Southern Idaho, Jerome recreation district, Jerome
ambulance district and to the state tax commission, a copy of the ordinance
codified herein, a copy of the legal description of the boundaries of the
southeast industrial revenue allocation area, and a map or plan indicating the
boundaries of the southeast industrial revenue allocation area. (Ord. 986 §6,
2005)
14.12.070: PROJECTED INCREASE OF ASSESSED VALUATION OF AREA:
The city council hereby finds and declares that the southeast industrial
revenue allocation area as defined in the southeast industrial plan includes
that portion of the southeast industrial project area, the equalized assessed
valuation of which the council hereby determines is in and is part of the
southeast industrial plan and is likely to continue to increase as a result of
the initiation and completion of urban renewal projects pursuant to the
southeast industrial plan. (Ord. 986 §7, 2005)
14.12.080: STATEMENT OF POLICY:
The city council hereby approves and adopts the following statement of policy
relating to the appointment of city council members as members of the agency's
board of commissioners: If any city council members are appointed to the board,
they are not acting in an ex officio capacity but rather as private citizens
who, although they are also members of the city council, are exercising their
independent judgment as private citizens when they sit on the board. Except for
the powers to appoint and terminate board members and to adopt the southeast
industrial plan the city council recognizes that it has no power to control the
powers or operations of the agency. (Ord. 986 §8, 2005)
14.12.090: AGENCY BOARD:
So long as any agency bonds are outstanding, the city council will not exercise
its power under Idaho Code section 50-2006 to designate itself as the agency
board. (Ord. 986 §9, 2005)
14.12.100: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter shall be in full force and effect immediately upon its passage,
approval and publication, and shall be retroactive to January 1, 2005, to the
extent permitted by the act. (Ord. 986 §10, 2005)

15.04.010: CODES ADOPTED 1 :
The approved editions of the following nationally recognized codes, as adopted
by the state of Idaho, or the Idaho building code board, are adopted as the
official building codes of the city of Jerome:
A.   International building code, including all rules promulgated by the board
to provide equivalency with the provisions of the Americans with disabilities
act accessibility guidelines;
B.   Federal fair housing act accessibility guidelines, the international
residential code, parts I through IV and IX; and
C.   International energy conservation code.
The adopted versions of the foregoing codes shall be deemed superseded by
successive versions of such codes as they are adopted or approved by the Idaho
building code board effective on the date any such codes are made effective by
the Idaho building code board. (Ord. 938 §1, 2002: Ord. 910 §§2, 3, 2001: Ord.
851 §§2, 3, 1998: Ord. 820 §§2–6, 1997: Ord. 801 §§2, 3, 1996: Ord. 741 §§2, 3,
1992: Ord. 695 §1, 1986)

15.04.020: MOBILE HOMES AS SINGLE DWELLINGS NOT IN VIOLATION OF BUILDING CODE:
Installation and use as a single dwelling of mobile homes under the authority
of the zoning ordinance shall not be deemed to be in violation of the building
code. (Prior code §6-4.2)
15.04.030: PERMIT REQUIREMENT; MISREPRESENTATION OF COSTS UNLAWFUL:
A.   It is unlawful for any person, whether he be the owner, contractor or
employee of an owner, to start any work in connection with the erection,
building, or construction of a building, or to do any work in connection with
the repair, alteration or improvement of a building, whereby the terms of this
chapter a permit for the erection, building, repair, alteration or improvement
is required, before a building permit has been granted under the terms of this
chapter.
B.   It is unlawful for any person to misrepresent the estimated value of the
cost of any building, alteration, repair or improvement. (Prior code §6-5)
15.04.035: PERMIT; APPLICATION REQUIREMENT:
A.   Every application for a building permit shall be accompanied by a drawing
indicating provisions for adequate drainage away from the structure sought in
the application for building permit.
B.   Drainage shall be designated so as to alleviate flooding and to carry
water away from the contemplated structure and any adjacent property, onto a
public street or alley.
C.   Failure of any person to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall
be deemed a misdemeanor. (Ord. 640 §§1–3, 1981)
15.04.036: PERMIT; CONTRACTOR'S REGISTRATION NUMBER:
No building permit will be issued without the contractor's registration number
being presented by the contractor, except when the permit applicant provides
evidence to the satisfaction of the building official that the applicant is
exempt from the registration requirements pursuant to title 54, chapter 52 of
the Idaho Code. (Ord. 991 §1, 2006)
15.04.040: FLOOD HAZARD REQUIREMENTS FOR NEW CONSTRUCTION:
A.   The public works director shall review all building permit applications
for new construction or substantial improvements to determine whether proposed
building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding. If a proposed building
site is in a location that has a flood hazard, any proposed new construction or
substantial improvement, including prefabricated and mobile homes, must:
   1.   Be designed, or modified, and anchored to prevent flotation, collapse
or lateral movement of the structure;
   2.   Use construction materials and utility equipment that are resistant to
flood damage; and
   3.   Use construction methods and practices that will minimize flood damage;
and
B.   The public works director shall review subdivision proposals and other
proposed new developments to assure that:
   1.   All such proposals are consistent with the need to minimize flood
damage;
   2.   All public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical and
water systems are located, elevated and constructed to minimize or eliminate
flood damage; and
   3.   Adequate drainage is provided so as to reduce exposure to flood
hazards; and
C.   The public works director shall require new or replacement water supply
systems or sanitary sewage systems to be designed to minimize or eliminate
infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems
into floodwaters, and require on site waste disposal systems to be located so
as to avoid impairment of them or contamination from them during flooding.
(Prior code §6-6.1)
15.04.050: INSTALLATION OF ELECTRICAL WIRING:
A.   A state of Idaho electrical wiring permit shall be obtained prior to the
installation of electrical wiring in any building or structure.
B.   The workmanship and materials used in the installation of electrical
wiring in any structure shall be inspected and approved by a licensed state
electrical inspector. (Ord. 817 §1, 1997: Ord. 663 §§1, 2, 1983)
CHAPTER 15.05
BUILDING CODE BOARD OF APPEALS
SECTION:
15.05.005: Title
15.05.010: Composition Of The Board
15.05.015: Duties Of The Board
15.05.020: Procedures For Appeals
15.05.025: Administration
15.05.030: Conflict Of Interest
15.05.035: Quorum And Voting
15.05.040: Compensation Of Members
15.05.005: TITLE:
Building Code Board of Appeals (hereinafter referred to as "the Board"). (Ord.
1237, 2025)
15.05.010: COMPOSITION OF THE BOARD:
The Board shall consist of 3 members appointed by the City Council, each of
whom shall have demonstrated knowledge or expertise in one or more of the
following areas: Building construction, Architecture, Engineering (structural,
mechanical, or electrical), Fire safety, and or Legal matters related to
building codes.
The City Council shall appoint members to the Board for a term of 2 years, with
no member serving more than 2 consecutive terms. (Ord. 1237, 2025)
15.05.015: DUTIES OF THE BOARD:
The Building Code Board of Appeals shall have the following duties:
A.   Hear Appeals: The Board shall hear appeals from individuals, businesses,
or organizations that contest the decisions or actions of the building
official, including but not limited to disputes over the application,
interpretation, or enforcement of the building codes.
B.   Grant Variances or Modifications: The Board may grant variances or
modifications to the strict application of the building codes, provided that:
   1.   The granting of such variance or modification does not endanger public
health, safety, or welfare.
   2.   The variance is consistent with the intent of the building code to
ensure safety, accessibility, and structural integrity.
   3.   The variance will not grant privileges to an individual or entity that
are not available to others similarly situated.
C.   Ensure Code Compliance and Safety: In granting variances or resolving
disputes, the Board shall ensure that the fundamental purpose of the building
code - protecting the public health, safety, and welfare - is upheld.
D.   Provide a Forum for Dispute Resolution: The Board shall act as a neutral
body to resolve disputes between parties, including builders, contractors,
property owners, and the City's building official, regarding the interpretation
or application of the building code. Or to review the equivalency of protection
of the code requirements. The Board shall not have the authority to waive the
requirements of the code.
E.   Provide Recommendations on Code Revisions: The Board may, at the request
of the City Council or on its own initiative, provide recommendations for
revisions or updates to the building code to reflect changes in technology,
safety standards, or construction practices.
F.   Issue Decisions: The Board shall issue written decisions on appeals, which
may include the approval or denial of variances, modifications, or other relief
sought by the appellant. Such decisions shall be final unless overturned by the
City Council. (Ord. 1237, 2025)
15.05.020: PROCEDURES FOR APPEALS:
A.   Filing an Appeal: Any person aggrieved by a decision or interpretation of
the building official may file a written appeal to the Board within 20 days of
the decision being rendered. The appeal shall include a statement of the
grounds for the appeal and any supporting documentation.
B.   Notice of Hearing: The Board shall schedule a hearing to consider the
appeal and shall provide written notice to the appellant, the building
official, and any other affected parties at least 5 days prior to the hearing.
C.   Hearing Procedures: The Board shall hold a public hearing and may hear
testimony from the appellant, the building official, and any other interested
parties. The Board may request additional information or documentation as
needed.
D.   Quorum Requirements and Rescheduling: A quorum of the Board shall consist
of 3 members. If a quorum of the Board is not present at the scheduled hearing,
the appellant shall be notified, and the appellant may, at their discretion,
request the hearing be rescheduled. If the appellant requests a rescheduled
hearing, the Board shall work to accommodate the appellant and set a new date
for the hearing within 14 days, unless the appellant agrees to a longer period.
If the appellant chooses not to reschedule, the Board shall proceed with the
hearing, and the decision may be made by the available members of the Board who
are present.
E.   Decision: Following the hearing, the Board shall render a decision, which
shall be communicated to the appellant and the building official in writing
within 3 days. The decision of the Board shall be binding unless reversed by
the City Council. (Ord. 1237, 2025)
15.05.025: ADMINISTRATION:
The building official shall take immediate action in accordance with the
decision of the board. (Ord. 1237, 2025)
15.05.030: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
Members of the Board shall disqualify themselves from participating in any case
in which they have a personal or financial interest. Any Board member who has a
conflict of interest shall recuse themselves from the matter and may be
replaced by an alternate member designated by the City Council. (Ord. 1237,
2025)
15.05.035: QUORUM AND VOTING:
A quorum of the Board shall consist of 3 members. A decision of the Board shall
require the approval of a majority of the members present at the hearing. (Ord.
1237, 2025)
15.05.040: COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS:
Members of the Board of appeals are not required to be compensated unless
required by state law. (Ord. 1237, 2025)
CHAPTER 15.08
CURB AND GUTTER REQUIREMENT
SECTION:
15.08.010: Requirement
15.08.020: Date Of Completion
15.08.030: Contract For Installation
15.08.040: Reserved
15.08.050: Violation Declared Misdemeanor
15.08.010: REQUIREMENT:
All residential or commercial construction, including the siting of a mobile
home and/or manufactured home within the city shall be made only upon lots
containing curb and gutter on street or road frontage in accordance with city
specifications for curb and gutter. (Ord. 850 §1, 1998: Ord. 749A §1, 1993:
Ord. 608 §1, 1978)
15.08.020: DATE OF COMPLETION:
New curb and gutter required to be installed by this chapter shall be
constructed at the expense of the property owner in accordance with city
standards at the same time as all new construction or modification of existing
buildings and shall be fully and properly constructed within one hundred twenty
(120) days of the issued building permit, or a mobile home and/or manufactured
home siting permit by the city and prior to the occupancy of the facility.
Provided, however, that any building permit or mobile home siting permit issued
for the lots (bounded on at least 3 sides by public roads of the city), and
which lots lay between public roads denominated West H and West G, East H and
East G, West 7th and West 8th, or East 7th and East 8th, the period of time for
completion of the construction of the required curb and gutter shall be one
year from the date of the issuance of a building permit or mobile home siting
permit by the city. (Ord. 850 §2, 1998: Ord. 749A §2, 1993: Ord. 608 §2, 1978)
15.08.030: CONTRACT FOR INSTALLATION:
A.   At the request of the property owner and the recommendation of the public
works director the city may, at its option, enter into a written contract
deferring the installation of curb and gutter to a future date in such form as
shall be approved by the city attorney. The contract shall provide, among other
terms, for the time in which installation is to be commenced and completed and
the specifications of construction shall be in recordable form, and shall bind
the current property owner, his heirs, successors and assigns. The contract or
deferral agreement shall require approval of the city council and provide for
the collection of damages, attorney fees and costs in the event of default by
the property owner.
B.   The city public works director may recommend to defer the construction of
curbs and gutter for any one or more of the following reasons:
   1.   If the total length of the existing curb and gutter on the same side of
the street in the same block plus the length of the property in question on
which the new curb and gutter would be installed is less than forty percent
(40%) of the total length of a standard block, unless the new curb and gutter
will connect to an existing curb and gutter section which meets city acceptance
standards for line and grade.
   2.   If another unit of government with jurisdiction over the street or road
along which the curb and gutter will be installed requests that the
installation of curb and gutter be deferred.
   3.   If the street or road would require city financed repair, reshaping,
relocation, or modification in order for the curb and gutter to be installed to
line and grade in an acceptable manner, the installation may be deferred until
street or road improvements are completed.
   4.   Curb and gutter installation may be deferred if, in the opinion of the
public works director, the installation at the time of building permit issuance
would create a traffic hazard or an unusual drainage problem.
   5.   Construction of the curb and gutter has been delayed because of
weather, natural disaster or other causes beyond the control of the owner.
(Ord. 850 §4, 1998: Ord. 749A §4, 1993)
15.08.040: RESERVED:
15.08.050: VIOLATION DECLARED MISDEMEANOR:
Any violation of this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor. (Ord. 749A §5,
1993: Ord. 608 §4, 1978)

PLUMBING REGULATIONS 1

15.12.010: INSPECTIONS:
Any authorized plumbing inspector duly appointed by the state plumbing board,
department of law enforcement of the state, shall perform all plumbing
inspections within the city; provided, however, that the city shall, through
its own officers, agents and employees, make inspections and grant approval of
sewer lines, sewer connections and water lines and water connections. (Prior
code §6-67)
15.12.020: PLUMBERS' LICENSES; REQUIRED:
No person, corporation, copartnership, firm or association shall engage in the
business, trade, practice or work of plumbing in the city, from and after the
passage of this section, unless such person, or a responsible person
representing such firm, copartnership, association or corporation, has been
first licensed by the city. (Prior code §6-68)
15.12.030: PLUMBERS' LICENSES; CLASSIFICATION:
There shall be three (3) classifications of plumbers, namely, plumbing
contractor, also known as master plumber, plumbing journeyman and plumbing
apprentice, each of whom shall have respectively the qualifications set forth
and provided in section 39-2716 of the Idaho Code. (Prior code §6-69)
15.12.040: PLUMBERS' LICENSES; FEES AND RENEWAL:
A.   Before a license is issued by the city for engaging in one of the
classifications of plumbing mentioned in section
15.12.030 of this chapter, the applicant shall pay to the city an original and
a renewal fee as follows:
 
                    Initial Fee Renewal Fee
Plumbing contractor $100.00     $15.00
Plumbing journeyman 15.00       3.00
 
B.   All licenses shall expire on January 1 of each year and may be renewed for
a period of one year upon payment of the renewal fee above provided for.
Licenses which have expired for failure of the holder to pay the renewal fee
shall be reinstated upon the payment of the renewal fee and a penalty of ten
dollars ($10.00), in addition to such renewal fee. All licenses which have
expired for failure to pay such renewal fee and have not been reinstated within
one year shall stand revoked and no new license shall be issued except upon the
payment of the initial fee above provided for; provided, however, that all
persons who were duly licensed under the provisions of the plumbing code of the
city preceding the adoption of this chapter may be relicensed under the terms
of this section by paying the renewal fee provided for in this section, which
such license shall expire on January 1, 1963. (Prior code §6-70)
15.12.050: PLUMBERS' LICENSES; ELIGIBILITY:
Any person who has been duly licensed or issued a certificate of competency by
the state or by any city of the state, having a plumbing code substantially
equivalent to the code adopted by the city, may be licensed by the city without
taking any examination, upon the payment of the fees provided for in section
15.12.040 of this chapter. (Prior code §6-71)
15.12.060: PERMITS; REQUIRED:
A.   It is unlawful for any person whether acting as principal, agent or
employee, to do or cause or permit to be done any plumbing or drainage work in
the city until a permit is obtained, and no work shall be commenced until such
permit has been issued by the city clerk.
B.   All permits shall be void after sixty (60) days from date of issue of such
permit if the work has not been commenced within sixty (60) days after the date
of issuance of the permit.
C.   Permits shall be issued only to a person holding a valid license issued by
the city; provided, however, that a permit shall not be required for the
clearing of stoppage or repairing of leaks in pipes, valves, fixtures,
appliances or appurtenances of any plumbing system when such work does not
involve or require any functional rearrangement of pipes, valves or fixtures
comprising the plumbing system. (Prior code §6-72)
15.12.070: PERMITS; FEES:
The applicant for a permit required by section
15.12.060 of this chapter shall pay to the city clerk at the time of
application, a permit fee for each permit issued, and an inspection fee in
accordance with the schedule duly fixed and adopted by the commissioner of law
enforcement of the state, which shall be kept on file in the office of the city
clerk. (Prior code §6-73)
15.12.080: VIOLATIONS:
Any person who engages in the business, trade, practice or work of plumbing
without a license issued by the city, or performs work without a permit as
provided by section
15.12.060 of this chapter, or who violates any provision of this chapter, or
the rules or regulations made by both the commissioner of law enforcement and
the state plumbing board, or who refuses to perform any duties lawfully
enjoined upon him by this chapter, or by the state plumbing inspector within
the prescribed time, or who fails, neglects or refuses to obey any lawful order
made by the duly authorized officers or agents of the city or the state
plumbing inspector, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code §6-74)
15.12.090: FAILURE TO CORRECT VIOLATIONS DECLARED A NUISANCE:
Any plumbing contractor, plumbing journeyman, or any other person who has had
notice from the plumbing inspector, or who has been found guilty of violating
this chapter by using materials not in accordance with this chapter, shall
remove any such materials or part of plumbing system not complying with this
chapter within ten (10) days following notice of such violation and any
violation of the provisions of this section are declared to be a nuisance.
(Prior code §6-75)

15.20.010: ESTABLISHED AND DESCRIBED:
The fire limits of the city, encompassing the area hereinafter known as the
fire district, shall be the outside limits of the combined business use
district and manufacturing and industrial use district, determined from the
intersection of Main Street and Lincoln Avenue in the city, and the fire
district shall encompass all of both such use districts as such use districts
are presently defined by title 17 of this code, or as such use districts may in
the future be altered, revised, or changed by appropriate ordinance of the city
council or mayor of the city, such alteration, revision or change in such use
districts automatically altering the fire limits and fire district so that the
fire limits and fire district shall at all times include all territory,
streets, intersections and alleyways included inside the business and
manufacturing and industrial use districts. (Prior code §6-7)
